[Prologue]


Incipit liber de Petro Plowman Assit principio Sanctafilius Mariae meo The heading is written in a similar ink to that of the text but in a much less formal style, and is probably later than the main scribe. Though rubbed, it appears originally to have read Assit principio Sancta Maria meo with Sancta then deleted by way of underlining and replaced by filius, and Maria altered to Mariae. In a somer seson ; whan soft was the sonne
Incipit liber de Petro Plowman Assit principio Sanctafilius Mariae meo The heading is written in a similar ink to that of the text but in a much less formal style, and is probably later than the main scribe. Though rubbed, it appears originally to have read Assit principio Sancta Maria meo with Sancta then deleted by way of underlining and replaced by filius, and Maria altered to Mariae. shepe I shope me in shroudes ; as i a shepe were
Incipit liber de Petro Plowman Assit principio Sanctafilius Mariae meo The heading is written in a similar ink to that of the text but in a much less formal style, and is probably later than the main scribe. Though rubbed, it appears originally to have read Assit principio Sancta Maria meo with Sancta then deleted by way of underlining and replaced by filius, and Maria altered to Mariae. shepe In habite as an heremite ; vnholy of workes

Though rubbed, it appears originally to have read Assit principio Sancta Maria meo with Sancta then deleted by way of underlining and replaced by filius, and Maria altered to Mariae. shepe Went wyde in þis world wondres to here

Though rubbed, it appears originally to have read Assit principio Sancta Maria meo with Sancta then deleted by way of underlining and replaced by filius, and Maria altered to Mariae. shepe Ac on a May mornyng ; on Maluerne hulles
Incipit liber de Petro Plowman Assit principio Sanctafilius Mariae meo The heading is written in a similar ink to that of the text but in a much less formal style, and is probably later than the main scribe. Though rubbed, it appears originally to have read Assit principio Sancta Maria meo with Sancta then deleted by way of underlining and replaced by filius, and Maria altered to Mariae. shepe Me byfel a ferly ; of fairy me thouȝte
Incipit liber de Petro Plowman Assit principio Sanctafilius Mariae meo The heading is written in a similar ink to that of the text but in a much less formal style, and is probably later than the main scribe. Though rubbed, it appears originally to have read Assit principio Sancta Maria meo with Sancta then deleted by way of underlining and replaced by filius, and Maria altered to Mariae. shepe I was wery forwandred · and went me to reste
Incipit liber de Petro Plowman Assit principio Sanctafilius Mariae meo The heading is written in a similar ink to that of the text but in a much less formal style, and is probably later than the main scribe. Though rubbed, it appears originally to have read Assit principio Sancta Maria meo with Sancta then deleted by way of underlining and replaced by filius, and Maria altered to Mariae. shepe Vnder a brode banke ; bi a bornes side
Incipit liber de Petro Plowman Assit principio Sanctafilius Mariae meo The heading is written in a similar ink to that of the text but in a much less formal style, and is probably later than the main scribe. Though rubbed, it appears originally to have read Assit principio Sancta Maria meo with Sancta then deleted by way of underlining and replaced by filius, and Maria altered to Mariae. shepe And as I lay and lened ; and loked in þe wateres
Incipit liber de Petro Plowman Assit principio Sanctafilius Mariae meo The heading is written in a similar ink to that of the text but in a much less formal style, and is probably later than the main scribe. Though rubbed, it appears originally to have read Assit principio Sancta Maria meo with Sancta then deleted by way of underlining and replaced by filius, and Maria altered to Mariae. shepe I slombred in a slepyng ; it sweyued so merye

Thanne gan I to meten ; a merueilouse sweuene
That I was in a wildernesse ; wist I neuer where
As I bihelde in-to þe est ; an hiegh to þe sonne
A Tower on a tofte I seigh a toure on a toft ; trielich ymaked
A Tower on a tofte A Dongion in a Dale A depe dale binethe ; a dongeon þere-Inne
A Tower on a tofte A Dongion in a Dale With depe dyches & derke ; and dredful of sight
A Tower on a tofte A Dongion in a Dale A ffaire ffelde bitwynne A faire felde ful of folke ; fonde I there bytwene
A Tower on a tofte A Dongion in a Dale A ffaire ffelde bitwynne Of alle maner of men ; þe mene and þe riche
A Tower on a tofte A Dongion in a Dale A ffaire ffelde bitwynne Ry vont vont John rich RychardA later fifteenth-century scribe. Kane and Donaldson report bond John Rychard. Worchyng and wandryng ; as þe worlde asketh
A Tower on a tofte A Dongion in a Dale A ffaire ffelde bitwynne Ry vont vont John rich RychardA later fifteenth-century scribe. Kane and Donaldson report bond John Rychard. Some put hem to þe plow ; pleyed ful selde
A Tower on a tofte A Dongion in a Dale A ffaire ffelde bitwynne Ry vont vont John rich RychardA later fifteenth-century scribe. Kane and Donaldson report bond John Rychard. In settyng and in sowyng ; swonken ful harde
A Tower on a tofte A Dongion in a Dale A ffaire ffelde bitwynne Ry vont vont John rich RychardA later fifteenth-century scribe. Kane and Donaldson report bond John Rychard. And wonnen that wastours ; with glotonye destruyeth

And some putten hem to pruyde ; apparailed hem þere-after
In contenaunce of clothyng comen disgised

In prayers and in penance ; putten hem manye
Al for loue of owre lorde · lyueden ful streyte
In hope forto haue · heueneriche blisse
As ancres and heremites · that holden hem in here selles
And coueiten nought in contre to kairen aboute
For no likerous liflode · her lykam to plese

And somme chosen chaffare · they cheuen the bettere
As it semeth to owre syȝt · that suche men thryueth
Minystralis And somme murthes to make · as mynstralles conneth
Minystralis And geten gold with here glee · synneles I leue
Minystralis Common Iestars Common Iestas. Ac iapers & iangelers · Iudas chylderen
Minystralis Common Iestars Common Iestas. Common Iestars. [drawing of bird] Feynen hem fantasies · and foles hem maketh
Minystralis Common Iestars Common Iestas. Common Iestars. [drawing of bird] And han here witte at wille · to worche ȝif þei sholde
Minystralis Common Iestars Common Iestas. Common Iestars. [drawing of bird] Qui non laborat non manducet Qui non laborat non manducet That Poule precheth of hem · I nel nought preue it here
Minystralis Common Iestars Common Iestas. Common Iestars. [drawing of bird] Qui non laborat non manducet Qui non laborat non manducet Qui turpiloquium loquitur · &c

Bidders and beggeres · fast aboute ȝede
With her bely and her bagge · of bred ful ycrammed
Fayteden for here fode · fouȝten atte ale
In glotonye god it wote · gon hij to bedde
And risen with ribaudye · tho roberdes knaues
Slepe and sori sleuthe · seweth hem eure

Pylgrymes Pilgrims Pylgrymes. ¶ Pilgrymes and palmers · pliȝted hem togidere
Pylgrymes Pilgrims Pylgrymes. Pilgrimys To seke seynt Iames · and seyntes in rome
Pylgrymes Pilgrims Pylgrymes. Pilgrimys Thei went forth in here wey · with many wise tales
Pylgrymes Pilgrims Pylgrymes. Pilgrimys And hadden leue to lye · al here lyf after
Pylgrymes Pilgrims Pylgrymes. Pilgrimys I seigh somme that seiden · þei had ysouȝt seyntes
Pylgrymes Pilgrims Pylgrymes. Pilgrimys To eche a tale þat þei tolde · here tonge was tempred to lye
Pylgrymes Pilgrims Pylgrymes. Pilgrimys Heremytes More þan to sey soth · it semed bi here speche

Hermets Hermes. ¶ Heremites on an heep · with hoked staues
Hermets Hermes. Wenten to walsyngham · and here wenches after
Hermets Hermes. heremytis Grete lobyes and longe · that loth were to swynke
Hermets Hermes. heremytis Clotheden hem in copis · to ben knowen fram othere
Hermets Hermes. heremytis And shopen hem heremites · here ese to haue

Freers Fryars Friers. IThis I is one of the capitals which indicate the beginnings of chapters. ¶ I fonde þere Freris alle þe foure ordres
Freers Fryars Friers. IThis I is one of the capitals which indicate the beginnings of chapters. contra Glosers euaungeli Freris Preched þe peple · for profit of hem-seluen
Freers Fryars Friers. IThis I is one of the capitals which indicate the beginnings of chapters. contra Glosers euaungeli Freris Glosed þe gospel · as hem good lyked
Freers Fryars Friers. IThis I is one of the capitals which indicate the beginnings of chapters. contra Glosers euaungeli Freris For coueitise of copis · construed it as þei wolde
Freers Fryars Friers. IThis I is one of the capitals which indicate the beginnings of chapters. contra Glosers euaungeli Freris Many of þis maistres Freris mowe clothen hem at lykyng
Freers Fryars Friers. IThis I is one of the capitals which indicate the beginnings of chapters. contra Glosers euaungeli Freris - meten For here money and marchandise · marchen togideres
Freers Fryars Friers. IThis I is one of the capitals which indicate the beginnings of chapters. contra Glosers euaungeli Freris - meten For sith charite haþ be chapman · and chief to shryue lordes
Freers Fryars Friers. IThis I is one of the capitals which indicate the beginnings of chapters. contra Glosers euaungeli Freris - meten charitas Many ferlis han fallen · in a fewe ȝeris
Freers Fryars Friers. IThis I is one of the capitals which indicate the beginnings of chapters. contra Glosers euaungeli Freris - meten charitas But holychirche and hij · holde better togideres
Freers Fryars Friers. IThis I is one of the capitals which indicate the beginnings of chapters. contra Glosers euaungeli Freris - meten charitas + proverb. The moste my[s]chief on molde · is mountyng wel faste

pardonere Pardo=nars Perdonneris ¶ Þere preched a Pardonere · as he a prest were
pardonere Pardo=nars Perdonneris Pardonars. Brouȝte forth a bulle · with bishopes seles
pardonere Pardo=nars Perdonneris Pardonars. And seide þat hym-self myȝte · assoilen hem alle
pardonere Pardo=nars Perdonneris Pardonars. Of falshed of fastyng · of vowes ybroken

contra pardoners ¶ Lewed men leued hym wel · and lyked his wordes
contra pardoners - Comen vp knelyng · to kissen his bulles
contra pardoners - He bonched hem with his breuet · & blered here eyes
contra pardoners - And rauȝte with his ragman · rynges and broches
contra pardoners - Thus þey geuen here golde · glotones to kepe
contra pardoners - And leneth such loseles · þat lecherye haunten
contra pardoners - Were þe bischop yblissed · and worth bothe his eres
contra pardoners - His seel shulde nouȝt be sent · to deceyue þe peple
contra pardoners - Ac it is nauȝt by þe bischop · þat þe boy precheth
contra pardoners - For the parisch prest and þe pardonere · parten þe siluer
contra pardoners - + nota #F1.76 That þe poraille of þe parisch · sholde haue ȝif þei nere

Curatis Nonresi=dence Curatis ¶ Persones and parisch prestes · pleyned hem to þe bischop ·
Curatis Nonresi=dence Curatis Curati non residentes Þat here parisshes were pore · sith þe pestilence tyme
Curatis Nonresi=dence Curatis Curati non residentes contra Episcopos & Curatos To haue a lycence and a leue · at London to dwelle
Curatis Nonresi=dence Curatis Curati non residentes contra Episcopos & Curatos And syngen þere for symonye · for siluer is swete

¶ Bischopes and bachelers · bothe maistres and doctours
Þat han cure vnder criste · and crounyng in tokne
And signe þat þei sholden · shryuen here paroschienes
Prechen and prey for hem · and þe pore fede
Liggen in London · in lenten an elles
Somme seruen þe kyng · and his siluer tellen
In cheker and in chancerye · chalengen his dettes
Of wardes and wardmotes · weyues and streyues

¶ And some seruen as seruantz · lordes and ladyes
And in stede of stuwardes · sytten and demen
Here messe and here matynes · and many of here oures
Arn don vndeuoutlych · drede is at þe laste
- Lest crist in constorie · acorse ful manye
- I parceyued of þe power · þat Peter had to kepe
- To bynde and to vnbynde · as þe boke telleth
- How he it left wiþ loue · as owre lorde hight
- Amonges foure vertues · þe best of alle vertues
- - CP.103m Þat cardinales ben called · & closyng ȝatis
- - CP.103m Þere crist is in kyngdome · to close and to shutte
- - CP.103m mistice loquitur And to opne it to hem · and heuene blisse shewe
- - CP.103m mistice loquitur Cardinales Ac of þe cardinales atte Courte · þat cauȝt of þat name
- - CP.103m mistice loquitur Cardinales - CP.107m And power presumed in hem · a Pope to make
- - CP.103m mistice loquitur Cardinales - CP.107m To han þat power þat peter hadde · inpugnen I nelle
- - CP.103m mistice loquitur Cardinales - CP.107m - CP.109 For in loue and letterure · þe eleccioun bilongeth
- - CP.103m mistice loquitur Cardinales - CP.107m - CP.109 For-þi I can and can nauȝte · of courte speke more

¶ Þanne come þere a kyng · knyȝthod hym ladde
Miȝt of þe comunes · made hym to regne
And þanne cam kynde wytte · and clerkes he made
For to conseille þe kyng · and þe comune saue

¶ The kyng and knyȝthode · and clergye bothe
Casten þat þe comune shulde hem-self fynde

¶ Þe comune contreued · of kynde witte craftes
And for profit of alle þe poeple · plowmen ordeygned
To tilie and trauaile · as trewe lyf askeþ
Þe kynge and þe comune · and kynde witte þe thridde
- CP.121m Shope lawe & lewte · eche man to knowe his owne

¶ Þanne loked vp a lunatik · a lene þing with-alle
para indicatorSP.52 And knelyng to þe kyng · clergealy he seyde
para indicatorSP.52 Crist kepe þe sire kyng · and þi kyngriche
para indicatorSP.52 And lene þe lede þi londe · so leute þe louye
para indicatorSP.52 And for þi riȝtful rewlyng · be rewarded in heuene

¶ And sithen in þe eyre an hiegh · an angel of heuene
Lowed to speke in latyn · for lewed men ne coude .
Iangle ne iugge · þat iustifie hem shulde
But suffren & seruen · for-thi seyde þe angel
vox angeli · versus · CP.131m versus Sum Rex sum Princeps · neutrum fortasse deinceps
vox angeli · versus · CP.131m versus O qui iura regis · cristi specialia regis
vox angeli · versus · CP.131m versus Hoc quod agas melius · iustus es esto pius
vox angeli · versus · CP.131m versus Nudum ius a te · vestiri vult pietate
vox angeli · versus · CP.131m versus Qualia vis metere · talia grana sere
vox angeli · versus · CP.131m versus Si ius nudatur · nudo de iure metatur ·
vox angeli · versus · CP.131m versus Si seritur pietas · de pietate metas ·

X ¶ Thanne greued hym a Goliardeys · a glotoun of wordes
X And to þe angel an heiȝ · answeres after
X · versus · CP.140 versus Dum rex a regere · dicatur nomen habere
X · versus · CP.140 versus Nomen habet sine re · nisi studet iura tenere ·

¶ And þanne gan alle þe comune · crye in vers of latin
To þe kynges conseille · construe ho-so wolde
The tale of the rattons . versus Precepta Regis · sunt nobis vincula legis ·

Nota The route off Ratons Ratounes . ¶ Wiþ þat ran þere a route of ratones at ones

Nota The route off Ratons Ratounes . þe profycyoff þe cattG1.146 The tale of the rattons, The tale of the rattons For a cat of a courte · cam whan hym lyked
Nota The route off Ratons Ratounes . þe profycyoff þe cattG1.146 The tale of the rattons, The tale of the rattons And ouerlepe hem lyȝtlich · and lauȝte hem at his wille
Nota The route off Ratons Ratounes . þe profycyoff þe cattG1.146 The tale of the rattons, The tale of the rattons And pleyde wiþ hem perilouslych · and possed aboute
Nota The route off Ratons Ratounes . þe profycyoff þe cattG1.146 The tale of the rattons, The tale of the rattons For doute of dyuerse dredes · we dar nouȝte wel loke

Nota The route off Ratons Ratounes . þe profycyoff þe cattG1.146 The tale of the rattons, The tale of the rattons That vs lotheth þe lyf · or he lete vs passe
Nota The route off Ratons Ratounes . þe profycyoff þe cattG1.146 The tale of the rattons, The tale of the rattons Myȝte we wiþ any witte · his wille withstonde
Nota The route off Ratons Ratounes . þe profycyoff þe cattG1.146 The tale of the rattons, The tale of the rattons We myȝte be lordes aloft · and lyuen at owre ese

¶ A raton of renon most renable of tonge
¶ Seide for a souereygne · help to hym-selue
I haue ysein segges quod he · in þe cite of london
Beren biȝes ful briȝte · abouten here nekkes
And some colers of crafty werk vncoupled þei wenden
+ Boþe in wareine & in waste · where hem leue lyketh
+ And otherwhile þei aren elles-where · as I here telle
+ Were þere a belle on here beiȝ · bi Ihesu as me thynketh
+ ...?...Likey a guide for alteration to renne. Men myȝte wite where þei went · and awei renne
+ ...?...Likey a guide for alteration to renne. And riȝt so quod þat ratoun · reson me sheweth
+ ...?...Likey a guide for alteration to renne. To bugge a belle of brasse · or of briȝte syluer
+ ...?...Likey a guide for alteration to renne. And knitten on a colere · for owre comune profit
+ ...?...Likey a guide for alteration to renne. And hangen it vp-on þe cattes hals · þanne here we mowen
+ ...?...Likey a guide for alteration to renne. - CP.170 Where he ritt or rest · or renneth to playe
+ ...?...Likey a guide for alteration to renne. - CP.170 And ȝif him list for to laike · þenne loke we mowen
+ ...?...Likey a guide for alteration to renne. - CP.170 And peren in his presence · þer-while hym plaie liketh
+ ...?...Likey a guide for alteration to renne. - CP.170 And ȝif him wrattheth be ywar · and his weye shonye

¶ Alle þis route of ratones · to þis reson þei assented
Ac þo þe belle was ybouȝt · and on þe beiȝe hanged
Þere ne was ratoun in alle þe route · for alle þe rewme of Fraunce
Þat dorst haue ybounden þe belle · aboute þe cattis nekke
Ne hangen aboute þe cattes hals · al Engelonde to wynne
And helden hem vnhardy · and here conseille feble
Myce *Omnium doctissimorum suffragio dicuntur Hec de lassiuis, fatuis, aut ineptis principibus, non de etate tenellis, Quasi dicat, vbi rex puerilis est. And leten here laboure lost · & alle here longe studye

ByshopsCr3.P.216 ¶ Barones an burgeis · and bonde-men als
ByshopsCr3.P.216 I seiȝ in þis assemble · as ȝe shul here after
ByshopsCr3.P.216 Baxsteres & brewesteres · and bocheres manye
ByshopsCr3.P.216 Wollewebsteres · and weueres of lynnen
ByshopsCr3.P.216 Taillours and tynkeres · & tolleres in marketes
ByshopsCr3.P.216 Masons and mynours · and many other craftes
ByshopsCr3.P.216 Of alkin libbyng laboreres · lopen forth somme
ByshopsCr3.P.216 As dykers & delueres · þat doth here dedes ille
ByshopsCr3.P.216 And dryuen forth þe dere day · with dieu vous saue dame Emme ·
ByshopsCr3.P.216 Cookes Cokes and here knaues · crieden hote pies hote
ByshopsCr3.P.216 Cookes Gode gris a gees · go we dyne go we

¶ Tauerners vn-til hem · tolde þe same
White wyn of Oseye · and red wyn of Gascoigne
Of þe Ryne and of þe Rochel · þe roste to defye
Al þis seiȝ I slepyng · and seuene sythes more

Passus primus de visione


What this montaigne bymeneth · and þe merke dale
And þe felde ful of folke · I shal ȝow faire schewe
mater ecclesiaG2.3 A loueli ladi of lere · in lynnen yclothed
mater ecclesiaG2.3 + Come down fram a castel · and called me faire
mater ecclesiaG2.3 + And seide sone slepestow · sestow þis poeple
mater ecclesiaG2.3 + How bisi þei ben · abouten þe mase
mater ecclesiaG2.3 + · nota · The tour Þe moste partie of þis poeple · þat passeth on þis erthe

¶ I was aferd of her face · þeiȝ she faire were
Truthe And seide mercy Madame · what is þis to mene

The tour The tower Þe toure vp þe toft quod she · treuthe is þere-Inne
The tour The tower And wolde þat ȝe wrouȝte · as his worde techeth
The tour The tower For he is fader of feith · fourmed ȝow alle
The tour The tower Bothe with fel and with face · and ȝaf ȝow fyue wittis
The tour The tower Forto worschip hym þer-with · þe while þat ȝe ben here
The tour The tower And þerfore he hyȝte þe erthe · to help ȝow vchone
The tour The tower Of wollen of lynnen · of lyflode at nede
The tour The tower In mesurable manere · to make ȝow at ese

# iij thingis in Comon ¶ And comaunded of his curteisye in comune þree þinges
# iij thingis in Comon Arne none nedful but þo · and nempne hem I thinke
# iij thingis in Comon the iij þinges requisite + ȝe And rekne hem bi resoun · reherce þow hem after
# iij thingis in Comon the iij þinges requisite + ȝe That one is vesture · from chele þe to saue
# iij thingis in Comon the iij þinges requisite + ȝe And mete atte mele · for myseise of þi-selue
# iij thingis in Comon the iij þinges requisite + ȝe And drynke whan þow dryest · ac do nouȝt out of resoun
# iij thingis in Comon the iij þinges requisite + ȝe That þow worth þe werse · whan þow worche shuldest

¶ Madame mercy quod I · me liketh wel ȝowre wordes
Ac þe moneye of þis molde · þat men so faste holdeth
Telle me to whom Madame · þat tresore appendeth

¶ Thanne had I wonder in my witt · what womman it were
Þat such wise wordes · of holywrit shewed
And asked hir on þe hieȝe name · ar heo þennes ȝeode
What she were witterli · þat wissed me so faire

¶ And alle þat hoped it miȝte be so · none heuene miȝte hem holde
But fellen out in fendes liknesse · nyne dayes togideres
Til god of his goodnesse · gan stable and stynte
And garte þe heuene to stekye · and stonden in quiete

- C1.121 ¶ Whan thise wikked went out · wonderwise þei fellen
- C1.121 Somme in eyre somme in erthe · & somme in helle depe
- C1.121 Ac lucifer lowest lith of hem alle ·
- C1.121 For pryde þat he pult out · his peyne hath none ende
- C1.121 And alle þat worche with wronge · wenden hij shulle
- C1.121 After her deth-day · and dwelle wiþ þat shrewe
- C1.121 Ac þo þat worche wel · as holiwritt telleth
- C1.121 + And enden as I ere seide · in treuthe þat is þe best
- C1.121 + Mowe be siker þat her soule · shal wende to heuene
- C1.121 + Þer treuthe is in Trinitee · and troneth hem alle

¶ Ȝet haue I no kynde knowing quod I · ȝet mote ȝe kenne me better
By what craft in my corps · it comseth and where

¶ Þow doted daffe quod she · dulle arne þi wittes
To litel latyn þow lernedest · lede in þi ȝouthe

diliges dominum super omniaL1.143 ¶ It is a kynde knowyng quod he

¶ Loke þow suffre hym to sey · and sithen lere it after
For thus witnesseth his worde · worcheth þow þere-after
nota For trewthe telleþ þat loue · is triacle of heuene
nota nota May no synne be on him sene · þat vseth þat spise
nota nota And alle his werkes he wrouȝte · with loue as him liste
nota nota moisesG2.151 And lered it Moises for þe leuest þing and moste like to heuene
nota nota moisesG2.151 | C1.150 And also þe plente of pees · moste precious of vertues

¶ For heuene myȝte nouȝte holden it · it was so heuy of hym-self
Tyl it hadde of þe erthe · yeten his fylle

¶ And whan it haued of þis folde flessh & blode taken
Was neuere leef vpon lynde · liȝter þer-after
And portatyf and persant · as þe poynt of a nedle
That myȝte non armure it lette · ne none heiȝ walles

¶ For-þi is loue leder of þe lordes folke of heuene
nota And a mene as þe Maire is · bitwene þe kyng and þe comune
nota Riȝt so is loue a ledere · and þe lawe shapeth
nota Vpon man for his mysdedes · þe merciment he taxeth
nota And for to knowe it kyndely · it comseth bi myght
nota - C1.162 heuedM1.166, erased word is legible with ultraviolet light. And in þe herte þere is þe heuede · and þe heiȝ welle

notaM1.167 nota Loked on vs with loue · and lete his sone deye

¶ Here myȝtow see ensamples · in hym-selue one
That he was miȝtful & meke · and mercy gan graunte
To hem þat hongen him an heiȝ · and his herte þirled

¶ For-þi þis wordes ben · wryten in þe gospel

¶ Loue is leche of lyf · and nexte owre lorde selue
And also þe graith gate · þat goth in-to heuene
For-þi I sey as I seide · ere by þe textis
notaW1.209 Whan alle tresores ben ytryed · treuthe is þe beste
notaW1.209 Now haue I tolde þe what treuthe is · þat no tresore is bettere
notaW1.209 I may no lenger lenge þe with · now loke þe owre lorde

Passus secundus de visione vt supra


Ȝet I courbed on my knees · and cryed hir of grace
And seide mercy Madame · for Marie loue of heuene
That bar þat blisful barne · þat bouȝte vs on þe Rode
Kenne me bi somme crafte · to knowe þe fals

¶ Loke vppon þi left half · and lo where he standeth
Bothe fals and fauel · and here feres manye

¶ I loked on my left half · as þe lady me taughte
#primam apparicionem mede And was war of a womman · wortheli yclothed
#primam apparicionem mede Purfiled with pelure · þe fynest vpon erthe
#primam apparicionem mede Ycrounede with a corone · þe kyng hath non better
#primam apparicionem mede Fetislich hir fyngres · were fretted with golde wyre
#primam apparicionem mede And þere-on red rubyes · as red as any glede
#primam apparicionem mede And diamantz of derrest pris · and double manere safferes
#primam apparicionem mede Orientales and ewages · enuenymes to destroye

¶ Hire robe was ful riche · of red scarlet engreyned
With ribanes of red golde · and of riche stones
Hire arraye me rauysshed · suche ricchesse saw I neuere
I had wondre what she was · and whas wyf she were

¶ What is þis womman · quod I so worthily atired

¶ That is Mede þe Mayde quod she · hath noyed me ful oft
And ylakked my lemman · þat lewte is hoten
And bilowen hire to lordes · þat lawes han to kepe
In þe popis paleys · she is pryue as my-self
But sothenesse wolde nouȝt so · for she is a bastarde

nota ¶ For fals was hire fader · þat hath a fykel tonge
nota And neuere sothe seide · sithen he come to erthe

¶ And Mede is manered after hym · riȝte as kynde axeth
Mar.iiiiCr3.2.28 notaW2.28 Qualis pater talis filius · bonus arbor · bonum fructum facit
Mar.iiiiCr3.2.28 notaW2.28 I auȝte ben herre þan she · I cam of a better

¶ Mi fader þe grete god is · and grounde of alle graces
O god with-oute gynnynge · & I his gode douȝter
#M2.32 And hath ȝoue me mercy · to marye with my-self
#M2.32 And what man be merciful · and lelly me loue
#M2.32 Shal be my lorde and I his leef · in þe heiȝe heuene

notaW2.35 That he shal lese for hir loue · a lappe of caritatis
notaW2.35 how construeth dauid þe kynge · of men þat taketh Mede
notaW2.35 And men of þis molde · þat meynteneth treuthe

- C2.41 ¶M2.41 ¶ And now worth þis Mede ymaried · al to a mansed schrewe
- C2.41 ¶M2.41 # maritage medisM2.42 To one fals fikel tonge · a fendes biȝete
- C2.41 ¶M2.41 # maritage medisM2.42 notaW2.42 Fauel þorw his faire speche · hath þis folke enchaunted
- C2.41 ¶M2.41 # maritage medisM2.42 notaW2.42 And al is lyeres ledyng · þat she is þus ywedded

¶ To-morwe worth ymade · þe maydenes bruydale
And þere miȝte þow wite · if þow wolt · which þei ben alle
That longeth to þat lordeship · þe lasse and þe more
Knowe hem þere if þow canst · and kepe þi tonge
And lakke hem nouȝt · but lat hem worth · til lewte be iustice
And haue powere to punyschen hem · þanne put forth þi resoun

¶ Now I bikenne þe criste quod she · and his clene moder
notaW2.52 And lat no conscience acombre þe · for coueitise of Mede

¶ Thus left me þat lady · liggyng aslepe
And how Mede was ymaried · in meteles me þouȝte
Þat alle þe riche retenauns · þat regneth with þe false
Were boden to þe bridale · on bothe two sydes
# thassemble at medis mariageM2.57 Of alle maner of men · þe mene and þe riche
# thassemble at medis mariageM2.57 To marie þis maydene · was many man assembled
# thassemble at medis mariageM2.57 As of kniȝtes and of clerkis · and other comune poeple
# thassemble at medis mariageM2.57 As sysours and sompnours · Shireues and here clerkes
# thassemble at medis mariageM2.57 Bedelles and Bailliues · and brokoures of chaffre
# thassemble at medis mariageM2.57 Forgoeres and vitaillers · and vokates of þe arches
# thassemble at medis mariageM2.57 I can nouȝt rekene þe route · þat ran aboute mede

¶ Ac symonye and cyuile · and sisoures of courtes
Were moste pryue with Mede · of any men me þouȝte
Ac fauel was þe first · þat fette hire out of boure
And as a brokour brouȝte hir to be with fals enioigned
Whan symonye and cyuile · seiȝ here beire wille
+L2.69 Thei assented for siluer · to se as bothe wolde

Medis FefmentM2.77 Carta .O2.76 notaW2.78 Þat Mede is ymaried · more for here goodis
Medis FefmentM2.77 Carta .O2.76 notaW2.78 Þan for ani vertue or fairenesse · or any free kynde

¶ And þe Erldome of enuye · and wratthe togideres
With þe chastelet of chest · and chateryng oute of resoun
Þe counte of coueitise · and alle þe costes aboute
That is vsure and auarice · alle I hem graunte
+ burghM2.90 In bargaines and in brokages · with al þe borgtheborg[h]e of theft

¶ And al þe lordeship of lecherye · in lenthe and in brede
#M2.92 As in werkes and in wordes · and waitynges with eies
#M2.92 And in wedes and in wisshynges · and with ydel thouȝtes
#M2.92 +L2.94 #M2.94 notaW2.94 There as wille ne wolde · wer[k]manship failleth

¶ Glotonye he gaf hem eke · and grete othes togydere
And alday to drynke · at dyuerse tauernes
And there to iangle and to iape · and iugge here euene-cristene
And in fastyngdayes to frete · ar ful tyme were
notaL2.99 And þanne to sitten and soupen · til slepe hem assaille
notaL2.99 And bredun as burgh-swyn · and bedden hem esily
notaL2.99 Tyl sleuth and slepe · slyken his sides
notaL2.99 Robart Bente you shalbe with vs atBudworthe and there to Testyfyyoure knowlegh in a materR2.61, secretary hand. This note may explain the cropped margins of the first few pages of the manuscript: someone appears to have been using them for occasional short notes. Budworth probably refers to one of two ancient parishes in Cheshire, Great Budworth and Little Budworth. And þanne wanhope to awake hym so · with no wille to amende
notaL2.99 Robart Bente you shalbe with vs atBudworthe and there to Testyfyyoure knowlegh in a materR2.61, secretary hand. This note may explain the cropped margins of the first few pages of the manuscript: someone appears to have been using them for occasional short notes. Budworth probably refers to one of two ancient parishes in Cheshire, Great Budworth and Little Budworth. notaM2.103 For he leueth be lost · þis is here last ende

¶ And þei to haue and to holde · and here eyres after
A dwellyng with þe deuel · and dampned be for eure
Wiþ al þe purtenaunces of purgatorie · in-to þe pyne of helle
Ȝeldyng for þis þinge · at one ȝeres ende
Here soules to sathan · to suffre with hym peynes
And with him to wonye with wo · whil god is in heuene

¶ In witnesse of which þing · wronge was þe first
And Pieres þe pardonere · of paulynes doctrine
Bette þe bedel · of Bokyngham-shire
Rainalde þe Reue · of Rotland sokene
Munde þe Mellere · and many moo other
· nota · C2.115 #M2.115 In þe date of þe deuel þis dede I assele
· nota · C2.115 #M2.115 Bi siȝte of sire symonye · and cyuyles leue

/M2.121 ¶ For Mede is moylere · of amendes engendreth
/M2.121 And god graunteth to gyf · Mede to treuthe
/M2.121 And þow hast gyuen hire to a gyloure · now god gyf þe sorwe
/M2.121 Thi tixt telleth þe nouȝt so · treuthe wote þe sothe

/M2.121 Luke,x Cr2.2.125 Luke x. Who it is that shameth holy church.Cr3.2.125 notaW2.125 notaW2.132 And myȝte kisse þe kynge · for cosyn an she wolde

¶ For-þi worcheth bi wisdome · and bi witt also
And ledeth hire to londoun · þere lawe is yshewed
If any lawe wil loke · þei ligge togederes
And þouȝ Iustices iugge hir · to be ioigned with fals
Ȝet beth war of weddyng · for witty is truthe ·
And conscience is of his conseille · and knoweth ȝow vchone
Notate verbaM2.142 And if he fynde ȝow in defaute · and with þe fals holde
Notate verbaM2.142 It shal bisitte ȝowre soules · ful soure atte laste

¶ Here-to assenteth cyuile · ac symonye ne wolde
Tyl he had siluer for his seruise · and also þe notaries

¶ Thanne fette fauel forth · floreynes ynowe
BrybesCr1.2.147 BrybesCr3.2.147 And bad gyle to gyue · golde al aboute
BrybesCr1.2.147 BrybesCr3.2.147 And namelich to þe notaries · þat hem none ne faille
BrybesCr1.2.147 BrybesCr3.2.147 And feffe false witnes · with floreines ynowe
BrybesCr1.2.147 BrybesCr3.2.147 For he may mede amaistrye · and maken at my wille

¶ Tho þis golde was gyue · grete was þe þonkynge
To fals and to fauel · for her faire ȝiftes
And comen to conforte fram care þe fals
And seiden certis sire · cesse shal we neuere
Til Mede be þi wedded wyf · þorw wittis of vs alle
For we haue Mede amaistried · with owre mery speche
That she graunteth to gon with a gode wille
To Londoun to loke · ȝif þat þe lawe wolde
Iugge ȝow ioyntly · in ioye for euere

¶ Thanne was falsenesse fayne · and fauel as blithe
And leten sompne alle segges · in schires aboute
And bad hem alle be bown · beggeres and othere
M M ButteN NNellXXXCXGod from SamR2.122, secretary hand, sixteenth-century pen trials. To wenden wyth hem to westmynstre · to witnesse þis dede

¶ Tho haued notaries none · annoyed þei were
For symonye and cyuile · shulde on hire fete gange

¶ Ac þanne swore symonye · and cyuile bothe
That sompnoures shulde be sadled and serue hem vchone
And lat apparaille þis prouisoures · in palfreis wyse
Sire symonye hym-seluen · shal sitte vpon here bakkes

¶ Paulynes pryues · for pleyntes in þe consistorie
Shul serue my-self · þat cyuile is nempned
And cartesadel þe comissarie · owre carte shal he lede
And fecchen vs vytailles · at fornicatores

¶ And maketh of lyer a longe carte · to lede alle þese othere
As Freres and faitours · þat on here fete rennen
And thus fals and fauel · fareth forth togideres
And Mede in þe myddes · and alle þise men after

¶ I haue no tome to telle þe taille þat hem folweth
Of many maner man · þat on þis molde libbeth
Trueth maketh haste to þe kynge.Cr3.2.190 John naylleR2.149. A sixteenth-century secretary hand: signature written vertically upwards notaW2.189 Ac gyle was forgoer · and gyed hem alle

¶ Sothenesse seiȝ hym wel · and seide but a litel
And priked his palfrey · and passed hem alle
And come to þe kynges courte · and conscience it tolde
And conscience to þe kynge · carped it after

# quo modo Rex Iurauit punicionem maleffactorumM2.195 ¶ Now by cryst quod þe kynge · and I cacche myȝte
# quo modo Rex Iurauit punicionem maleffactorumM2.195 Fals or fauel · or any of his feres
# quo modo Rex Iurauit punicionem maleffactorumM2.195 I wolde be wroke of þo wrecches · þat worcheth so ille
# quo modo Rex Iurauit punicionem maleffactorumM2.195 And don hem hange by þe hals · and alle þat hem meynteneth
# quo modo Rex Iurauit punicionem maleffactorumM2.195 Shal neure man of molde · meynprise þe leste
# quo modo Rex Iurauit punicionem maleffactorumM2.195 But riȝte as þe lawe wil loke · late falle on hem alle

¶ And comanded a constable · þat come atte furst
To attache þo tyrauntz · for eny thynge I hote
And fettereth fast falsenesse · for enykynnes ȝiftes
And gurdeth of gyles hed · and lat hym go no furthere
And ȝif ȝe lacche lyer · late hym nouȝt ascapen
Er he be put on þe pilorye · for eny preyere · I hote
And bryngeth Mede to me · maugre hem alle

¶ ¶ Drede atte dore stode · and þe dome herde
¶ # drede stetit ad hostium & audiuit mandatum Regis And how þe kynge comaunded · constables and seriantz

¶ Liȝtlich lyer · lepe awey þanne
Lorkynge thorw lanes · to-lugged of manye
He was nawhere welcome · for his manye tales

LechesO2.225 Þat he sholde wonye with hem · wateres to loke
LechesO2.225 SpiceersO2.227 Spiceres spoke with hym · to spien here ware

+ ¶Ac mynst[r]alles and messageres · mette with hym ones
+ And helden hym an halfȝere · and elleuene dayes

# FrerisO2.231 ¶ Freres with faire speche · fetten hym þennes
# FrerisO2.231 # And for knowyng of comeres · coped hym as a frere
# FrerisO2.231 # Ac he hath leue to lepe out · as oft as hym liketh
# FrerisO2.231 # And is welcome whan he wil · and woneth wyth hem oft

¶ Alle fledden for fere · and flowen in-to hernes
Saue Mede þe Mayde · na mo durst abide
Ac trewli to telle · she trembled for drede
And ek wept and wronge · whan she was attached

Passus tercius


The king wil know of Mede whom she loueth best. Now is Mede þe Maide · and namo of hem alle
The king wil know of Mede whom she loueth best. With bedellus & wiþ bayllyues · brouȝt bifor þe kyng
The king wil know of Mede whom she loueth best. Nota The kyng called a clerke · can I nouȝt his name
The king wil know of Mede whom she loueth best. Nota To take Mede þe mayde · and make hire at ese
The king wil know of Mede whom she loueth best. Nota I shal assaye hir my-self · and sothelich appose
The king wil know of Mede whom she loueth best. Nota What man of þis molde · þat hire were leueste
The king wil know of Mede whom she loueth best. Nota And if she worche bi my witte · and my wille folwe
The king wil know of Mede whom she loueth best. Nota I wil forgyue hir þis gilte · so me god help

¶ Curteysliche þe clerke þanne as þe Kyng hight
Toke Mede bi þe Middel · and brouȝte hir in-to chaumbre
And þere was myrthe and mynstralcye · Mede to plese
¶ They þat wonyeth in westmynstre · worschiped hir alle
Gentelliche wiþ ioye · þe Iustices somme
Busked hem to þe boure · þere þe birde dwelled
To conforte hire kyndely · by clergise leue
And seiden mourne nought Mede · ne make þow no sorwe
For we wisse þe kynge · and þi wey shape
To be wedded at þi wille · and where þe leue liketh
For al conscience caste · or craft as I trowe

- ¶ Mildeliche Mede þanne · mercyed hem alle
- Of þeire gret goodnesse · and gaf hem vchone
- Coupes of clene golde · and coppis of siluer
- Rynges with rubies · and ricchesses manye
- The leste man of here meyne · a motoun of golde
- Thanne lauȝte þei leue · þis lordes at Mede

Clerkis ¶ With that comen clerkis · to conforte hir þe same
Clerkis And beden hire be blithe · for we beth þine owne
Clerkis Forto worche þi wille · þe while þow myȝte laste

Hendeliche heo þanne · bihight hem þe same
To loue ȝow lelli · and lordes to make
And in þe consistorie atte courte · do calle ȝowre names
Shal no lewdnesse lette · þe leode þat I louye
That he ne worth first auanced · for I am biknowen
· Nota · Þere konnyng clerkes · shul clokke bihynde

¶ Thanne Mede for here mysdedes · to þat man kneled
And shroue hire of hire shrewednesse · shamelees I trowe
Tolde hym a tale · and toke hym a noble
Forto ben hire bedeman · and hire brokour als

¶ Thanne he assoilled hir sone · and sithen he seyde
We han a wyndowe a-wirchyng wil sitten vs wel heigh
- Woldestow glase þat gable · and graue þere-inne þi name
- Siker sholde þi soule be · heuene to haue
- · Nota · bene · Wist I that quod þat womman · I wolde nouȝt spare
- · Nota · bene · The fruites of Popishe penaunce.Cr3.3.53 For to be ȝowre frende frere · and faille ȝow neure
- · Nota · bene · The fruites of Popishe penaunce.Cr3.3.53 Whil ȝe loue lordes · þat lechery haunteþ
- · Nota · bene · The fruites of Popishe penaunce.Cr3.3.53 And lakkeþ nouȝt ladis · þat loueþ wel þe same
- · Nota · bene · The fruites of Popishe penaunce.Cr3.3.53 It is a frelete of flesche · ȝe fynde it in bokes
- · Nota · bene · The fruites of Popishe penaunce.Cr3.3.53 And a course of kynde · wher-of we komen alle
- · Nota · bene · The fruites of Popishe penaunce.Cr3.3.53 Who may scape þe sklaundre · þe skaþe is sone amended
- · Nota · bene · The fruites of Popishe penaunce.Cr3.3.53 It is synne of seuene · sonnest relessed

¶ Haue mercy quod Mede · of men þat it haunte
And I shal keure ȝowre kirke · ȝowre cloystre do maken
- Wowes do whitten · and wyndowes glasen
- Do peynten and purtraye · and paye for þe makynge
- That eury segge shal seyn · I am sustre of ȝowre hous

¶ Ac god to alle good folke · suche grauynge defendeth
To writen in wyndowes · of here wel-dedes
On auenture pruyde be peynted þere · and pompe of þe worlde
For crist knoweþ þi conscience · and þi kynde wille
And þi coste and þi coueitise · and who þe catel ouȝte

¶ For-þi I lere ȝow lordes · leueþ suche werkes
To writen in wyndowes · of ȝowre wel-dedes
Or to greden after goddis men · whan ȝe delen doles
An auenture ȝe han ȝowre hire here · and ȝoure heuene als

Marke,vi.Cr2.3.74 Math.vi.Cr3.3.74 - C3.74 Wyte what þow worchest · with þi riȝt syde
Marke,vi.Cr2.3.74 Math.vi.Cr3.3.74 - C3.74 For þus bit þe gospel · gode men do here almesse

The mayers officeCr3.3.78 What harme yll vitiliers do & what abuseis in regrating.Cr3.3.82 To þe pore peple þat parcel-mele buggen

¶ For they poysoun þe peple · priueliche and oft
Thei rychen þorw regraterye · and rentes hem buggen
With þat þe pore people shulde put in here wombe
For toke þei on trewly · þei tymbred nouȝt so heiȝe
Ne bouȝte non burgages · be ȝe ful certeyne

¶ Ac Mede þe Mayde þe Maire hath bisouȝte
Meyres .O3.89 Of alle suche sellers · syluer to take
Meyres .O3.89 Or presentz withoute pens · as peces of siluer
Meyres .O3.89 Ringes or other ricchesse · þe regrateres to maynetene

¶ For my loue quod that lady loue hem vchone
And soffre hem to selle · somdele aȝeins resoun

¶ Salamon þe sage · a sarmoun he made
For to amende Maires · and men þat kepen lawes
And tolde hem þis teme · þat I telle thynke

Nota · beneC3.97 Iob.xvCr1.3.98 Iob.xv.Cr3.3.98 notaL3.97 +L3.100 Ȝiftes or ȝeresȝyues · bi-cause of here offices

¶ The kynge fro conseille cam · and called after Mede
And ofsent hir alswythe · with seriauntes manye
That brouȝten hir to bowre · with blisse and with ioye

¶ Curteisliche þe kynge þanne · comsed to telle
To Mede þe mayde · melleth þise wordes
Vnwittily womman · wrouȝte hastow oft
Ac worse wrouȝtestow neure · þan þo þow fals toke
But I forgyue þat gilte · and graunte þe my grace
· Nota · C3.111 Hennes to þi deth-day · do so namore

# vtrum Mede vult maritare cum conciencieM3.111 ¶ I haue a knyȝte conscience · cam late fro biȝunde
# vtrum Mede vult maritare cum conciencieM3.111 +L3.112 Ȝif he wilneth þe to wyf · wyltow hym haue

¶ Ȝe lorde quod þat lady · lorde forbede elles
But I be holely at ȝowre heste · lat hange me sone

¶ And þanne was conscience calde · to come and appiere
Bifor þe Kynge and his conseille · as clerkes and othere
Knelynge conscience · to þe kynge louted
To wite what his wille were · and what he do shulde

¶ Woltow wedde þis womman quod þe kynge · ȝif I wil assente
For she is fayne of þi felawship · for to be þi make

Conscience forsaketh Mede for hir euyll condition.Cr3.3.122 Concience ¶ Quod conscience to þe kynge · cryst it me forbede

¶ To be cursed in consistorie · she counteth nouȝte a russhe
#M3.144 notaW3.144 For she copeth þe comissarie · and coteth his clerkis
#M3.144 notaW3.144 She is assoilled as sone · as hir-self liketh
#M3.144 notaW3.144 And may neiȝe as moche do · in a moneth one
#M3.144 notaW3.144 As ȝowre secret seel · in syx score dayes
#M3.144 notaW3.144 For she is priue with þe pope · prouisoures it knoweth
#M3.144 notaW3.144 For sire symonye and hir-selue · seleth hire bulles

¶ She blesseth þise bisshopes · þeiȝe þey be lewed
Prouendreth persones · and prestes meynteneth
To haue lemmannes and lotebies · alle here lif-dayes
And bringen forth barnes · aȝein forbode lawes
# quia ...?...M3.154 ...?...M3.154, erased. There she is wel with þe kynge · wo is þe rewme
# quia ...?...M3.154 ...?...M3.154, erased. For she is fauorable to þe fals · and fouleth trewthe ofte

¶ Bi ihesus with here ieweles · ȝowre iustices she shendeth
And lith aȝein þe lawe · and letteth hym þe gate
That feith may nouȝte haue his forth · here floreines go so þikke
She ledeth þe lawe as hire list · and louedayes maketh
And doth men lese þorw hire loue · þat lawe myȝte wynne
Þe mase for a mene man · þouȝ he mote hir eure
#M3.162 Lawe is so lordeliche · and loth to make ende
#M3.162 With-oute presentz or pens · she pleseth wel fewe

¶ Barounes and burgeys · she bryngeth in sorwe
notaW3.165 And alle þe comune in kare · þat coueyten lyue in trewthe
notaW3.165 For clergye and coueitise · she coupleth togideres
notaW3.165 Þis is þe lyf of that lady · now lorde ȝif hir sorwe
notaW3.165 And alle that meynteneth here men · meschaunce hem bityde
notaW3.165 For pore men mowe haue no powere · to pleyne hem þouȝ þei smerte
notaW3.165 · Nota · C3.170 Suche a maistre is Mede · amonge men of gode

¶ Thanne morned Mede · and mened hire to the kynge
To haue space to speke · spede if she myȝte

¶ The kynge graunted hir grace with a gode wille
Mede hath leue to speakeCr3.3.176 Excuse þe ȝif þow canst · I can namore seggen
Mede hath leue to speakeCr3.3.176 For conscience acuseth þe · to congey þe for euere

#M3.176 # Excusacio medisM3.176 ¶ Nay lorde quod þat lady · leueth hym þe worse
#M3.176 # Excusacio medisM3.176 Whan ȝe wyten witterly · where þe wronge liggeth
#M3.176 # Excusacio medisM3.176 notaW3.178 There þat myschief is grete · Mede may helpe
#M3.176 # Excusacio medisM3.176 notaW3.178 And þow knowest conscience · I cam nouȝt to chide
#M3.176 # Excusacio medisM3.176 notaW3.178 Ne depraue þi persone · with a proude herte
#M3.176 # Excusacio medisM3.176 notaW3.178 Wel þow wost wernard · but ȝif þow wolt gabbe
#M3.176 # Excusacio medisM3.176 notaW3.178 Þow hast hanged on myne half · elleuene tymes
#M3.176 # Excusacio medisM3.176 notaW3.178 And also griped my golde · gyue it where þe liked
#M3.176 # Excusacio medisM3.176 notaW3.178 And whi þow wratthest þe now · wonder me thynketh
#M3.176 # Excusacio medisM3.176 notaW3.178 Ȝit I may as I myȝte · menske þe with ȝiftes
#M3.176 # Excusacio medisM3.176 notaW3.178 And mayntene þi manhode · more þan þow knoweste

¶ Ac þow hast famed me foule · bifor þe Kynge here
For kulled I neuere no kynge · ne conseilled þer-after
Ne dede as þow demest · I do on þe kynge

Mede reherseth what she hath doneCr3.3.192 #M3.190 ¶ In normandye was he nouȝte · noyed for my sake
Mede reherseth what she hath doneCr3.3.192 #M3.190 Ac þow þi-self sothely · shamedest hym ofte
Mede reherseth what she hath doneCr3.3.192 #M3.190 Crope in-to a kaban · for colde of þi nailles
Mede reherseth what she hath doneCr3.3.192 #M3.190 Wendest þat wyntre · wolde haue lasted euere
Mede reherseth what she hath doneCr3.3.192 #M3.190 And draddest to be ded · for a dym cloude
Mede reherseth what she hath doneCr3.3.192 #M3.190 And hiedest homeward · for hunger of þi wombe

#M3.196 ¶ Wiþ-out pite piloure · pore men þow robbedest
#M3.196 And bere here bras at þi bakke · to caleys to selle
#M3.196 There I lafte with my lorde · his lyf for to saue
#M3.196 I made his men meri · and mornyng lette
#M3.196 I batered hem on þe bakke · and bolded here hertis
#M3.196 - C3.201 And dede hem hoppe for hope · to haue me at wille
#M3.196 - C3.201 Had I ben Marschal of his men · bi Marie of heuene
#M3.196 - C3.201 I durst haue leyde my lyf · and no lasse wedde
#M3.196 - C3.201 He shulde haue be lorde of þat londe · a lengthe and a brede
#M3.196 - C3.201 And also Kyng of þat kitthe · his kynne for to helpe
#M3.196 - C3.201 Þe leste brolle of his blode · a barounes pere

¶ Cowardliche þow conscience · conseiledest hym þennes
To leuen his lordeship · for a litel siluer
That is þe richest rewme · þat reyne ouer-houeth

notaW3.210 ¶ It bicometh to a kynge · þat kepeth a rewme

There is an other Mede mesurelees · þat maistres desireth
To meyntene mysdoers · Mede þei take
And þere-of seith þe sauter · in a salmes ende

¶ Prestes and parsones · þat plesynge desireth
That taketh Mede and mone · for messes þat þei syngeth
Taketh here mede here · as Mathew vs techeth
Math,vi.Cr2.3.261 Mat.vi.Cr3.3.261 Amen amen recipiebant mercedem suam ·

¶ That laboreres and lowe folke · taketh of her maistres
notaW3.261 It is no manere Mede · but a mesurable hire
notaW3.261 In marchandise is no mede · I may it wel avowe
notaW3.261 It is a permutacioun apertly · a penyworth for an othre

· nota · C3.264 NotaM3.264 ¶ Ac reddestow neuere Regum · þow recrayed Mede
· nota · C3.264 NotaM3.264 sauvleG4.265, u and v added by hand 1.1. Initial <s> of original saul is cropped. Whi þe veniaunce fel · on saul and on his children

· nota · C3.264 NotaM3.264 sauvleG4.265, u and v added by hand 1.1. Initial <s> of original saul is cropped. Shulde deye for a dede · þat done had here aldres

¶ For-þi seid samuel to saul · god hym-self hoteth
The · be boxome at his biddynge · his wille to fulfille
Wende to amalec with þyn oste · and what þow fyndest þere slee it
Biernes and bestes · brenne hem to ded
Wydwes and wyues · wommen and children
Moebles and vnmoebles · and al þat þow myȝte fynde
Brenne it bere it nouȝte awey · be it neuere so riche
For mede ne for mone · loke þow destruye it
Spille it and spare it nouȝte · þow shalt spede þe bettere

¶ And for he coueyted her catel · and þe kynge spared
Forbare hym and his bestes bothe · as þe bible witnesseth
Otherwyse þan he was · warned of þe prophete
God seide to samuel þat saul shulde deye
And al his sede for þat synne · shenfullich ende
· Nota · C3.283 Such a myschief Mede made saul þe kynge to haue
· Nota · C3.283 That god hated hym for euere · and alle his eyres after

# the CulorumM3.285 ¶ The culorum of þis cas · kepe I nouȝte to shewe
# the CulorumM3.285 An auenture it noyed men · none ende wil I make
# the CulorumM3.285 notaW3.287 For so is þis worlde went · wiþ hem þat han powere
# the CulorumM3.285 notaW3.287 That who-so seyth hem sothes · is sonnest yblamed

¶ Shal namore Mede · be maistre as she is nouthe
IR3.286, probably an I or Q in this hand, though it is unclear what it signifies. Ac loue and lowenesse · and lewte togederes
IR3.286, probably an I or Q in this hand, though it is unclear what it signifies. xM3.297 Þise shul be maistres on molde · treuthe to saue

¶ And who-so trespasseth ayein treuthe · or taketh aȝein his wille
Leute shal don hym lawe · and no lyf elles
Shal no seriaunt for here seruyse · were a silke howue
Ne no pelure in his cloke · for pledyng atte barre
notaW3.302 Mede of mys-doeres · maketh many lordes
notaW3.302 And ouer lordes lawes · reuleth þe rewmes

· Nota · C3.304 # quod lex laborabitM3.304 ¶ Ac kynde loue shal come ȝit · and conscience togideres

# prophesiamM3.310 Axe [o]ther hachet · or eny wepne ellis

[flag-like design]G4.326. This sign also appears in the Table of Contents see f.101v and is clearly intended to enable the reader to find the passage referred to in the Table. As Benson and Blanchfield observe (Manuscripts, 42) there is a tendency for such marks to occur next to references to prophecy. #M3.326 ¶ Kynges courte and comune courte · consistorie and chapitele

¶ I leue wel lady quod conscience · þat þi latyne be trewe
· Nota · C3.345 Tess.v Cr2.3.347 That scripture should be read whole. i.I ell .v.Cr3.3.347 Ac þow art like a lady · þat redde a lessoun ones
· Nota · C3.345 Tess.v Cr2.3.347 That scripture should be read whole. i.I ell .v.Cr3.3.347 notaW3.346 Was omnia probate · and þat plesed here herte
· Nota · C3.345 Tess.v Cr2.3.347 That scripture should be read whole. i.I ell .v.Cr3.3.347 notaW3.346 For þat lyne was no lenger atte leues ende
· Nota · C3.345 Tess.v Cr2.3.347 That scripture should be read whole. i.I ell .v.Cr3.3.347 notaW3.346 Had ȝe loked þat other half · and þe lef torned
· Nota · C3.345 Tess.v Cr2.3.347 That scripture should be read whole. i.I ell .v.Cr3.3.347 notaW3.346 Ȝe shulde haue founden fele wordis · folwyng þer-after
· Nota · C3.345 Tess.v Cr2.3.347 That scripture should be read whole. i.I ell .v.Cr3.3.347 notaW3.346 Quod bonum est tenete · treuthe þat texte made

¶ And so ferde ȝe madame · ȝe couthe namore fynde
Tho ȝe loked on sapience · sittynge in ȝoure studie
Þis tixte þat ȝe han tolde · were gode for lordes
Ac ȝow failled a cunnyng clerke · þat couthe þe lef haue torned
And if ȝe seche sapience eft · fynde shal ȝe þat folweth
A ful teneful tixte · to hem þat taketh Mede
And þat is animam autem aufert accipientium · &c ·
And þat is þe taille of þe tixte · of þat þat ȝe schewed
Þat þeiȝe we wynne worschip · and wiþ mede haue victorie
Þe soule þat þe soude taketh · bi so moche is bounde

Passus Quartus


Cesseth seith þe kynge · I suffre ȝow no lengere
Ȝe shal sauȝtne for-sothe · and serue me bothe
kisse hir quod þe kynge · conscience I hote

Conscience wil haue reasons aduice. ¶ Nay bi criste quod conscience · congeye me for euere
Conscience wil haue reasons aduice. But resoun rede me þer-to · rather wil I deye

# Rex mandauit Conscientiam adquirere Racionem ¶ And I comaunde þe quod þe Kynge · to conscience þanne
# Rex mandauit Conscientiam adquirere Racionem Rape þe to ride · and resoun þow fecche
# Rex mandauit Conscientiam adquirere Racionem Comaunde hym þat he come · my conseille to here
# Rex mandauit Conscientiam adquirere Racionem For he shal reule my rewme · and rede me þe beste
# Rex mandauit Conscientiam adquirere Racionem And acounte with þe conscience · so me cryst helpe
# Rex mandauit Conscientiam adquirere Racionem How þow lernest þe peple · þe lered and þe lewede

¶ I am fayne of þat forwarde · seyde þe freke þanne
- C4.13 And ritte riȝte to resoun · and rowneth in his ere
- C4.13 And seide as þe kynge badde · and sithen toke his leue

¶ I shal arraye me to ride quod resoun reste þe a while

¶ Thanne conscience vppon his caple · kaireth forth faste
And resoun with hym ritte · rownynge togideres
Whiche maistries Mede · maketh on þis erthe

Waren wysdome & wittye folowed Reason #Hm4.23 ¶ One waryn wisdom · and witty his fere
Waren wysdome & wittye folowed Reason #Hm4.23 · Nota · C4.27 +L4.27 Folwed hem faste · haued to done
Waren wysdome & wittye folowed Reason #Hm4.23 · Nota · C4.27 +L4.27 In þe cheker and at þe chauncerie · to be discharged of þinges
Waren wysdome & wittye folowed Reason #Hm4.23 · Nota · C4.27 +L4.27 And riden fast for resoun shulde rede hem þe beste
Waren wysdome & wittye folowed Reason #Hm4.23 · Nota · C4.27 +L4.27 For to saue hem for siluer · fro shame and fram harmes

¶ And conscience knewe hem wel · þei loued coueitise
And bad resoun ride faste · and recche of her noither
Þere aren wiles in here wordes · and with Mede þei dwelleth
notaW4.34 There as wratthe and wranglyng is · þere wynne þei siluer

notaW4.35 ¶ Ac þere is loue and lewte · þei wil nouȝte come þere

And þanne resoun rode faste ; þe riȝte heiȝe gate
As conscience hym kenned · til þei come to þe Kynge

# Rex obuiauit cum racioneM4.46 And bitwene hym-self and his sone · sette hym on benche
# Rex obuiauit cum racioneM4.46 And wordeden wel wyseli · a gret while togideres

¶ The kynge knewe he seide sothe · for conscience hym tolde
Þat wronge was a wikked luft · and wrouȝte moche sorwe

¶ Wronge was afered þanne · and wisdome he souȝte
To make pees with his pens · and profered hym manye
And seide had I loue of my lorde þe kynge · litel wolde I recche
IfCr3.4.69 Theiȝe pees and his powere · pleyned hym eure

+L4.69 # wyt & warin wisdomM4.69 ¶ Þo wan wisdome · and sire waryn þe witty
+L4.69 # wyt & warin wisdomM4.69 For þat wronge had ywrouȝte · so wikked a dede
+L4.69 # wyt & warin wisdomM4.69 And warned wronge þo · with suche a wyse tale
+L4.69 # wyt & warin wisdomM4.69 notaW4.72 Who-so worcheth bi wille · wratthe maketh ofte
+L4.69 # wyt & warin wisdomM4.69 notaW4.72 I seye it bi þi-self · þow shalt it wel fynde
+L4.69 # wyt & warin wisdomM4.69 notaW4.72 But if Mede it make · þi myschief is vppe
+L4.69 # wyt & warin wisdomM4.69 notaW4.72 For bothe þi lyf and þi londe · lyth in his grace

¶ Thanne wowed wronge · wisdome ful ȝerne
#M4.77 To make his pees with his pens · handi-dandi payed
#M4.77 Wisdome and witte þanne wenten togideres
#M4.77 And toke Mede myd hem mercy to winne

¶ Pees put forþ his hed · and his panne blody
Wyth-outen gilte god it wote · gat I þis skaþe
Conscience and þe comune · knowen þe sothe

¶ Ac wisdom and witte · were about faste
To ouercome þe kynge · with catel ȝif þei myȝte

¶ Þe kynge swore bi crist · and bi his crowne bothe
Þat wronge for his werkis · sholde wo þolye
Wrong is committed to prison,Cr3.4.89 And comaunded a constable · to casten hym in yrens
Wrong is committed to prison,Cr3.4.89 And late hym nouȝte þis seuene ȝere · seen his feet ones

¶ God wot quod wysdom · þat were nauȝte þe beste
And he amendes mowe make · late meynprise hym haue
And be borwgh for his bale · and biggen hym bote
notaW4.92 And so amende þat is mysdo · and euermore þe bettere

# notaM4.93, paragraph is marked with lines in the right margin. ¶ Witt acorded þer-with · and seide þe same
# notaM4.93, paragraph is marked with lines in the right margin. Bettere is þat bote · bale adoun brynge
# notaM4.93, paragraph is marked with lines in the right margin. Þan bale be ybette · & bote neuere þe bettere

¶ And þanne gan Mede to mengen here · and mercy she bisought
notaM4.97 And profred pees a present · al of pure golde
notaM4.97 Haue þis man of me quod she · to amende þi skaþe
notaM4.97 For I wil wage for wronge · he wil do so namore

| C4.97 · Nota · C4.97 ¶ Pitously pees þanne · prayed to þe kynge
| C4.97 · Nota · C4.97 To haue mercy on þat man · þat mys-did hym so ofte
| C4.97 · Nota · C4.97 Mede stoppeth Peaces mouthCr3.4.104 For he hath waged me wel · as wisdome hym tauȝte
| C4.97 · Nota · C4.97 Mede stoppeth Peaces mouthCr3.4.104 And I forgyue hym þat gilte · with a goode wille
| C4.97 · Nota · C4.97 Mede stoppeth Peaces mouthCr3.4.104 So þat þe kynge assent · I can seye no bettere
| C4.97 · Nota · C4.97 Mede stoppeth Peaces mouthCr3.4.104 notaW4.105 For Mede hath made me amendes · I may namore axe

notaM4.106 ¶ Nay quod þe Kynge þo · so me cryst helpe
notaM4.106 notaW4.107 Wronge wendeth nouȝte so awaye · arst wil I wite more
notaM4.106 notaW4.107 # Bene Iudicatus est RexM4.108 For loupe he so liȝtly · laughen he wolde
notaM4.106 notaW4.107 # Bene Iudicatus est RexM4.108 And efte þe balder be · to bete myne hewen
notaM4.106 notaW4.107 # Bene Iudicatus est RexM4.108 But resoun haue reuthe on hym · he shal rest in my stokkes
notaM4.106 notaW4.107 # Bene Iudicatus est RexM4.108 And þat as longe as he lyueth · but lowenesse hym borwe

¶ Somme men redde Resoun þo · to haue reuthe on þat schrewe
And for to conseille þe Kynge · and conscience after
That Mede moste be meynpernour · resoun þei bisouȝte

notaW4.115 ¶ Rede me nouȝte quod resoun · no reuthe to haue
notaW4.115 · Nota · C4.113, B/B list this at KD4.113 instead # optime dicit RacioM4.116 Til lordes and ladies · louien alle treuthe
notaW4.115 · Nota · C4.113, B/B list this at KD4.113 instead # optime dicit RacioM4.116 Reasons aduice in the punyshynge of Wronge.Cr3.4.119 And haten al harlotrye · to heren it · or to mouthen it

pilgrimageC2.4.129 PylgrimageO4.129 That no man go to Galis · but if he go for euere

¶ And ȝet quod resoun bi þe Rode · I shal no reuthe haue
While Mede hath þe maistrye ; in þis moot halle
+L4.138 Ac I may shewe ensaumples · as I se other-while
+L4.138 I sey it bi my-self quod he · and it so were
+L4.138 That I were kynge with crowne · to kepen a Rewme
+L4.138 Shulde neuere wronge in þis worlde · þat I wite myȝte
+L4.138 Ben vnpunisshed in my powere · for peril of my soule
+L4.138 Ne gete my grace for giftes · so me god saue
+L4.138 Math.xvi.Cr2.4.145 Ne for no Mede haue mercy · but mekenesse it make

+L4.154 ¶ For I seiȝe mede in þe moot halle · on men of lawe wynke
+L4.154 And þei lawghyng lope to hire · and lafte resoun manye

¶ Waryn wisdome · wynked vppon Mede
And seide Madame I am ȝowre man · what-so my mouth iangleth
I falle in floreines quod þat freke · an faile speche ofte

¶ Alle riȝtful recorded · þat resoun treuthe tolde
And witt acorded þer-with · and comended his wordes
And þe moste peple in þe halle · and manye of þe grete
i-cursidC2.4.163 And leten mekenesse a maistre · and Mede a mansed schrewe

¶M4.163 notaM4.163 ¶ Loue lete of hir liȝte · and lewte ȝit lasse
¶M4.163 notaM4.163 And seide it so heiȝe þat al þe halle it herde
¶M4.163 notaM4.163 notaW4.165 Who-so wilneth hir to wyf · for welth of her godis
¶M4.163 notaM4.163 notaW4.165 notaW4.166 But he be knowe for a kokewolde · kut of my nose

¶ Mede mourned þo · and made heuy chere
# þat mede is Callyd a horeM4.168 For þe moste comune of þat courte called hire an hore
# þat mede is Callyd a horeM4.168 Ac a sysoure and a sompnoure · sued hir faste
# þat mede is Callyd a horeM4.168 And a schireues clerke · byschrewed al þe route
# þat mede is Callyd a horeM4.168 For ofte haue I quod he · holpe ȝow atte barre
# þat mede is Callyd a horeM4.168 And ȝit ȝeue ȝe me neuere · þe worthe of a russhe

¶ The kynge called conscience · and afterwardes resoun
And recorded þat resoun had riȝtfullich schewed
And mowdilich vppon Mede · with myȝte þe Kynge loked
The lawiers kepe the kinge from hys right,Cr3.4.178 And gan wax wrothe with lawe · for Mede almoste had shent it
The lawiers kepe the kinge from hys right,Cr3.4.178 And seide þorw ȝowre lawe as I leue · I lese many chetes
The lawiers kepe the kinge from hys right,Cr3.4.178 notaW4.178 Mede ouer-maistrieth lawe · and moche treuthe letteth
The lawiers kepe the kinge from hys right,Cr3.4.178 notaW4.178 Ac resoun shal rekene with ȝow · ȝif I regne any while
The lawiers kepe the kinge from hys right,Cr3.4.178 notaW4.178 And deme ȝow bi þis day · as ȝe han deserued
The lawiers kepe the kinge from hys right,Cr3.4.178 notaW4.178 Mede shal nouȝte meynprise ȝow · bi þe Marie of heuene
The lawiers kepe the kinge from hys right,Cr3.4.178 notaW4.178 I wil haue leute in lawe · and lete be al ȝowre ianglyng
The lawiers kepe the kinge from hys right,Cr3.4.178 notaW4.178 And as moste folke witnesseth wel · wronge shal be demed

¶ Quod conscience to þe kynge · but þe comune wil assent
It is ful hard bi myn hed · here-to to brynge it
Alle ȝowre lige leodes · to lede þus euene

¶ By hym þat rauȝte on þe rode · quod resoun to þe kynge
Reason taketh vpon hym to rule the realme.Cr3.4.190 But if I reule þus ȝowre rewme · rende out my guttes
Reason taketh vpon hym to rule the realme.Cr3.4.190 Ȝif ȝe bidden buxomnes · be of myne assente

¶ And I assent seith þe kynge · by seynte Marie my lady
Be my conseille comen of clerkis · and of erlis
Ac redili resoun þow shalt nouȝte ride fro me
xM4.193 For as longe as I lyue · lete þe I nelle

¶ I am aredy quod resoun · to reste with ȝow euere
So conscience be of owre conseille · I kepe no bettere
And I graunt quod the kynge · goddes forbode it faile
XC4.193 Als longe as owre lyf lasteth · lyue we togideres

Passus quintus de visione


The kyng and his knightes · to the kirke wente
To here matynes of þe day · and þe masse after
Þanne waked I of my wynkynge and wo was with-alle
Þat I ne hadde sleped sadder · and yseiȝen more
Ac er I hadde faren a fourlonge · feyntise me hente
That I ne myȝte ferther a foot · for defaute of slepynge
And sat softly adown · and seide my bileue
NotaFifteenth-century hand. And so I babeled on my bedes · þei brouȝte me a-slepe

Why pestelence why pestilence ¶ And þanne saw I moche more · þan I bifore tolde
Why pestelence why pestilence For I say þe felde ful of folke · þat I bifore of seyde
Why pestelence why pestilence - And how resoun gan arrayen hym · alle þe reume to preche
Why pestelence why pestilence - And with a crosse afor þe kynge · comsed þus to techen

# quia peccatum est Causa vindicti ¶ He preued þat þise pestilences · was for pure synne
# quia peccatum est Causa vindicti · Nota · And þe southwest wynde · on saterday at euene
# quia peccatum est Causa vindicti · Nota · Was pertliche for pure pryde · and for no poynt elles
# quia peccatum est Causa vindicti · Nota · Piries and plomtrees · were puffed to þe erthe
# quia peccatum est Causa vindicti · Nota · In ensample ȝe segges · ȝe shulden do þe bettere
# quia peccatum est Causa vindicti · Nota · Beches and brode okes · were blowen to þe grounde
# quia peccatum est Causa vindicti · Nota · Torned vpward her tailles · in tokenynge of drede
# quia peccatum est Causa vindicti · Nota · Þat dedly synne ar domesday · shal fordon hem alle

- # þat wattis wyff was to blame ¶ He warned watt · his wyf was to blame
- # þat wattis wyff was to blame Þat hire hed was worth halue a marke · his hode nouȝte worth a grote
- # þat wattis wyff was to blame And bad bette kut · a bow other tweyne
- # þat wattis wyff was to blame Due correction muste be had And bete betoun þer-with · but if she wolde worche
- # þat wattis wyff was to blame Due correction muste be had And þanne he charged chapmen · to chasten her childeren
- # þat wattis wyff was to blame Due correction muste be had Late no wynnynge hem forweny · whil þei be ȝonge
- # þat wattis wyff was to blame Due correction muste be had Ne for no pouste of pestilence · plese hem nouȝte out of resoun

¶ My syre seyde so to me · and so did my dame
Þat þe leuere childe · þe more lore bihoueth
And Salamon seide þe same · þat sapience made

Inuidia InuidiaC5.78 EnvieC2.5.78 Enuy . Cr1.5.76 Enuye.Cr3.5.78 InuidiaG6.78 InuidiaHm5.78 InuidiaL5.78 InuidiaM5.78 InuidiaW5.78 Envie .O5.79 InuidiaY5.79, H1? #M5.81 # the Freris Fore-slevisM5.83 id est emptiO5.85, gloss for lere. So loked he with lene chekes · lourynge foule

· Nota · C5.86 ¶ His body was to-bolle for wratthe · þat he bote his lippes ·
· Nota · C5.86 And wryngynge he ȝede with þe fiste · to wreke hym-self he þouȝte
· Nota · C5.86 With werkes or with wordes · whan he seighe his tyme
· Nota · C5.86 Eche a worde þat he warpe · was of an addres tonge
· Nota · C5.86 Of chydynge and of chalangynge · was his chief lyflode
· Nota · C5.86 With bakbitynge and bismer · and beryng of fals witnesse
· Nota · C5.86 Þis was al his curteisye · where þat euere he shewed hym

¶ I wolde ben yshryue quod þis schrewe · and I for shame durst
I wolde be gladder bi god · þat gybbe had meschaunce
· Nota · C5.95 Enuious worckes.Cr3.5.95 Than þouȝe I had þis woke ywonne · a weye of essex chese

= C5.96 ¶ I haue a neighbore neyȝe me · I haue ennuyed hym ofte
= C5.96 And lowen on hym to lordes · to don hym lese his siluer
= C5.96 And made his frendes ben his foon · thorw my false tonge
= C5.96 His grace and his good happes · greueth me ful sore
= C5.96 nota Bitwene many · and many · I make debate ofte
= C5.96 nota Þat bothe lyf and lyme · is lost þorw my speche

# discripcionem invidieM5.102 ¶ And whan I mete him in market · þat I moste hate
# discripcionem invidieM5.102 I hailse hym hendeliche · as I his frende were
# discripcionem invidieM5.102 For he is douȝtier þan I · I dar do non other
# discripcionem invidieM5.102 Ac hadde I maystrye and myȝte · god wote my wille

¶ And whan I come to þe kirke · and sholde knele to þe Rode
And preye for þe pople · as þe prest techeth
For pilgrimes and for palmers · for alle þe poeple after
Þanne I crye on my knees · þat cryste ȝif hem sorwe
Þat bar awey my bolle · and my broke schete

¶ Awey fro þe auter þanne · turne I myn eyghen
And biholde how Eleyne · hath a newe cote
I wisshe þanne it were myne · and al þe webbe after

per dicereGloss on "lesynge" ¶ And of mennes lesynge I laughe · þat liketh myn herte
per dicereGloss on "lesynge" And for her wynnynge I wepe · and waille þe tyme

nota ¶ And deme þat hij don ille · þere I do wel worse
nota Who-so vndernymeth me here-of · I hate hym dedly after
nota I wolde þat vche a wyght · were my knaue
nota For who-so hath more þan I · þat angreth me sore
nota And þus I lyue louelees · lyke a luther dogge
nota That al my body bolneth · for bitter of my galle

¶ I myȝte nouȝte eet many ȝeres · as a man ouȝte
For enuye and yuel wille · is yuel to defye
May no sugre ne swete þinge · asswage my swellynge
Ne no diapenidion · dryue it fro myne herte
Ne noyther schrifte ne shame · but ho-so schrape my mawe

Se howe Enuy repenteth.Cr3.5.127 theS5.124 ¶ Ȝus redili quod repentaunce · and radde hym to þe beste
Se howe Enuy repenteth.Cr3.5.127 theS5.124 Sorwe of synnes · is sauacioun of soules

- C5.129 ¶ I am sori quod þat segge · I am but selde other
- C5.129 And þat maketh me þus megre · for I ne may me venge
- C5.129 Amonges Burgeyses haue I be · dwellynge at Londoun
- C5.129 And gert bakbitinge be a brocoure · to blame mennes ware
- C5.129 Whan he solde and I nouȝte · þanne was I redy
- C5.129 To lye and to loure on my neighbore · and to lakke his chaffare
- C5.129 I wil amende þis ȝif I may · þorw myȝte of god almyȝty

# the Cause off grugge betwen Curatis & FrerisM5.145 ¶ And now persones parceyued · þat Freres parte with hem
# the Cause off grugge betwen Curatis & FrerisM5.145 Þise possessioneres preche · and depraue freres
# the Cause off grugge betwen Curatis & FrerisM5.145 And freres fyndeth hem in defaute · as folke bereth witnes
# the Cause off grugge betwen Curatis & FrerisM5.145 That whan þei preche þe poeple · in many place aboute
# the Cause off grugge betwen Curatis & FrerisM5.145 A good scholemaster.Cr3.5.149 I wrath walke with hem · and wisse hem of my bokes
# the Cause off grugge betwen Curatis & FrerisM5.145 A good scholemaster.Cr3.5.149 Þus þei speken of spiritualte · þat eyther despiseth other
# the Cause off grugge betwen Curatis & FrerisM5.145 A good scholemaster.Cr3.5.149 Til þei be bothe beggers · and by my spiritualte libben
# the Cause off grugge betwen Curatis & FrerisM5.145 A good scholemaster.Cr3.5.149 Or elles alle riche and riden aboute
# the Cause off grugge betwen Curatis & FrerisM5.145 A good scholemaster.Cr3.5.149 I wrath rest neuere · þat I ne moste folwe
# the Cause off grugge betwen Curatis & FrerisM5.145 A good scholemaster.Cr3.5.149 This wykked folke · for suche is my grace

Nunnes.Cr3.5.154 ¶ I haue an aunte to nonne · and an abbesse bothe
Nunnes.Cr3.5.154 NunnesCr1.5.153 Hir were leuere swowe or swelte · þan soeffre any peyne
Nunnes.Cr3.5.154 NunnesCr1.5.153 I haue be cook in hir kichyne · and þe couent serued
Nunnes.Cr3.5.154 NunnesCr1.5.153 Many monthes with hem · and with monkes bothe
Nunnes.Cr3.5.154 NunnesCr1.5.153 #M5.159 I was þe priouresses potagere · and other poure ladyes

¶ Of wykked wordes I wrath · here wortes I-made
Til þow lixte and þow lixte · lopen oute at ones
#M5.166 And eyther hitte other · vnder þe cheke
#M5.166 +M5.167 Hadde þei had knyues bi cryst · her eyther had killed other

GregorieCr1.5.165 Gregory wold not suffer womenne to bear confession.Cr3.5.167 GregoriusR5.168, 15th century hand ¶ Seynt Gregorie was a gode pope · and had a gode forwit

GregorieCr1.5.165 Gregory wold not suffer womenne to bear confession.Cr3.5.167 GregoriusR5.168, 15th century hand Þei had þanne ben infamis þe firste day · þei can so yuel hele conseille

¶ Amonge monkes I miȝte be · ac many tyme I shonye
For þere ben many felle frekis · my feres to aspye
Bothe Prioure an supprioure · and owre pater abbas
And if I telle any tales · þei taken hem togyderes
And do me faste frydayes · to bred and to water
And am chalanged in þe chapitelhous · as I a childe were
#M5.177 And baleised on þe bare ers · and no breche bitwene
#M5.177 For-þi haue I no lykyng · with þo leodes to wonye
#M5.177 I ete there vnthende fisshe · and fieble ale drynke
#M5.177 Ac otherwhile whan wyn cometh · whan I drynke wyn at eue
#M5.177 # the Flix off the Foule mowthM5.181 I haue a fluxe of a foule mouthe · wel fyue dayes after
#M5.177 # the Flix off the Foule mowthM5.181 Al þe wikkednesse þat I wote · bi any of owre bretheren
#M5.177 # the Flix off the Foule mowthM5.181 make knoweO5.182, gloss on couþe I couth it in owre cloistre · þat al owre couent wote it

¶ Now repent þe quod Repentaunce · and reherce þow neure
Conseille þat þow cnowest · bi contenaunce ne bi riȝte

¶ I haue ben coueytouse quod þis caityue · I biknowe it here
For some tyme I serued · symme atte stile
And was his prentis ypliȝte · his profit to wayte

¶ My wyf was a webbe · and wollen cloth made
She spak to spynnesteres · to spynnen it oute
Ac þe pounde þat she payed by · poised a quarteroun more
NotaR5.221, fifteenth century hand Than myne owne auncere · who-so weyȝed treuthe

¶ I bouȝte hir barly malte · she brewe it to selle
Peny ale and podyng ale · she poured togideres
For laboreres and for low folke · þat lay by hym-selue

¶ The best ale lay in my boure · or in my bedchambre
- C5.225 #M5.225 And who-so bummed þer-of · bouȝte it þer-after
- C5.225 #M5.225 A galoun for a grote · god wote na lesse
- C5.225 #M5.225 And ȝit it cam in cupmel · þis crafte my wyf vsed
- C5.225 #M5.225 Rose þe regratere · was hir riȝte name
- C5.225 #M5.225 She hath holden hokkerye · al hire lyf-tyme

¶ Ac I swere now so the ik · þat synne wil I lete
And neuere wikkedliche weye · ne wikke chaffare vse
| C5.232 But wenden to walsyngham · and my wyf als ·
| C5.232 And bidde þe Rode of bromeholme · brynge me oute of dette

# questiones RepentencieM5.234 ¶ Repentestow þe euere quod repentance · ne restitucioun madest

The restitution that nowe is vsed.Cr3.5.235 ¶ Ȝus ones I was herberwed quod he · with an hep of chapmen
The restitution that nowe is vsed.Cr3.5.235 notaM5.236 XM5.236 I roos whan þei were arest · and yrifled here males

¶ That was no restitucioun quod repentance · but a robberes thefte
Þow haddest better worthy · be hanged þerfore
Þan for al þat · þat þow hast here shewed ·

notaM5.240 ¶ I wende ryflynge were restitucioun quod he · for I lerned neuere rede on boke
notaM5.240 And I can no frenche in feith · but of þe ferthest ende of norfolke

¶ Vsedestow euere vsurie quod repentaunce · in alle þi lyf-tyme

¶ Nay sothly he seyde · saue in my ȝouthe
I lerned amonge lumbardes · and iewes a lessoun
To wey pens with a peys · and pare þe heuyest
And lene it for loue of þe crosse · to legge a wedde and lese it
Suche dedes I did wryte · ȝif he his day breke
I haue mo maneres þorw rerages · þan þorw miseretur & comodat

¶ I haue lent lordes · and ladyes my chaffare
And ben her brocour after · and bouȝte it my-self
Eschaunges and cheuesances · with suche chaffare I dele
And lene folke þat lese wol · a lyppe at euery noble
And with lumbardes lettres · I ladde golde to Rome
And toke it by taille here · and tolde hem þere lasse

Len[t]estow euere lordes · for loue of her mayntenaunce

notaW5.255 ¶ Ȝe I haue lent lordes · loued me neuere after
notaW5.255 And haue ymade many a knyȝte · bothe mercere & drapere
notaW5.255 Þat payed neuere for his prentishode · nouȝte a peire gloues

¶ Hastow pite on pore men · þat mote nedes borwe

· Nota · C5.260, B/B mark at 5.254 instead #M5.260 notaW5.259 ¶ I haue as moche pite of pore men · as pedlere hath of cattes

¶ Artow manlyche amonge þi neiȝbores · of þi mete and drynke

¶ I am holden quod he as hende · as hounde is in kychyne
Amonges my neighbores namelich · such a name ich haue

¶ Now god lene neure quod repentance · but þow repent þe rather
Þe grace on þis grounde · þi good wel to bisette

¶ Thow art an vnkynde creature · I can þe nouȝte assoille
Til þow make restitucioun · and rekne with hem alle
And sithen þat resoun rolle it · in þe regystre of heuene

¶ For-þi haue mercy in þi mynde · and marchandise leue it
For þow hast no good grounde · to gete þe with a wastel
But if it were with thi tonge · or ellis with þi two hondes

notaW5.298 And as longe as þow lyuest þer-with · þow ȝeldest nouȝte but borwest

¶ Ac Beton þe brewestere · bad hym good morwe
And axed of hym with þat · whiderward he wolde

¶ To holicherche quod he · forto here masse
And sithen I wil be shryuen · and synne namore

¶ I haue peper and piones quod he · and a pounde of garlike
A ferthyngworth of fenel-seed · for fastyngdayes

¶ Þanne goth glotoun in · and grete othes after
Cesse þe souteresse · sat on þe benche

¶ Clement þe cobelere · cast of his cloke
And atte new faire · he nempned it to selle
Hikke þe hakeneyman · hitte his hood after
And badde bette þe bochere · ben on his side
Þere were chapmen ychose · þis chaffare to preise
NotaR5.329, 15th century hand Who-so haueth þe hood · shuld haue amendes of þe cloke

¶ Two risen vp in rape · and rouned togideres
And preised þese penyworthes · apart bi hem-selue
Þei couth nouȝte bi her conscience · acorden in treuthe
Tyl Robyn þe ropere · arose bi þe southe
And nempned hym for a noumpere · þat no debate nere

¶ Hikke þe hostellere · hadde þe cloke
In couenaunte þat Clement shulde þe cuppe fille
And haue hikkes hode hostellere · and holde hym yserued
xM5.346 And who-so repented rathest · shulde arise after
xM5.346 And grete sire glotoun with a galoun ale

¶ Þere was laughyng and louryng · and let go þe cuppe
And seten so til euensonge · and songen vmwhile
Tyl glotoun had yglobbed · a galoun an a Iille
+L5.351 His guttis gunne to godly · as two gredy sowes
+L5.351 #M5.352 He pissed a potel · in a pater noster while
+L5.351 #M5.352 And blew his rounde ruwet · at his rigge-bon ende
+L5.351 #M5.352 That alle þat herde þat horne · held her nose after
+L5.351 #M5.352 And wissheden it had be wexed · with a wispe of firses

¶ And whan he drowgh to þe dore · þanne dymmed his eighen

¶ With al þe wo of þis worlde · his wyf and his wenche
Baren hym home to his bedde · and brouȝte hym þer-inne
And after al þis excesse · he had an accidie
Þat he slepe saterday and sonday · til sonne ȝede to reste
Þanne waked he of his wynkyng · and wiped his eyghen
Þe fyrste worde þat he warpe · was where is þe bolle
His witte gan edwite hym þo · how wikkedlich he lyued
And repentance riȝte so · rebuked hym þat tyme

¶ As þow with wordes and werkes · hast wrouȝte yuel in þi lyue
Shryue þe and be shamed þer-of · and shewe it with þi mouth

- C5.380 ¶ I glotoun quod þe gome · gylti me ȝelde
- C5.380 Þat I haue trespassed with my tonge · I can nouȝte telle how ofte
- C5.380 Sworen goddes soule · and so god me help and halidom
- C5.380 Þere no nede ne was · nyne hundreth tymes

¶ And ouer-seye me at my sopere · and some-tyme at nones
Þat I glotoun girt it vp · er I hadde gone a myle
And yspilte þat myȝte be spared · and spended on somme hungrie
Ouerdelicatly on fastyng-dayes · drunken and eten bothe
And sat some-tyme so longe þere · þat I slepe and ete at ones
For loue of tales in tauernes · to drynke þe more I dyned
And hyed to þe mete er none · whan fastyng-dayes were

¶ This shewyng shrifte quod repentance · shal be meryte to þe

¶ And þanne gan glotoun grete · and gret doel to make
For his lither lyf · þat he lyued hadde
