What awake renke quod repentance · and rape þe to shrifte

¶ If I shulde deye bi þis day · me liste nouȝte to loke
I can nouȝte parfitly my pater noster · as þe prest it syngeth
But I can rymes of Robyn hood · and Randolf erle of Chestre
Ac neither of owre lorde ne of owre lady · þe leste þat euere was made

¶ I haue made vowes fourty · and forȝete hem on þe morne
I parfourned neure penaunce · as þe prest me hiȝte
Ne ryȝte sori for my synnes · ȝet was I neuere
And ȝif I bidde any bedes · but if it be in wrath
notaW5.410 Þat I telle with my tonge · is two myle fro myne herte
notaW5.410 I am occupied eche day · haliday and other
notaW5.410 With ydel tales atte ale · and otherwhile in cherches
notaW5.410 Goddes peyne and his passioun · ful selde þynke I þere-on

¶ I visited neuere fieble men · ne fettered folke in puttes
I haue leuere here an harlotrie · or a somer game of souteres
Or lesynges to laughe at · and belye my neighbore
Þan al þat euere Marke made · Mathew Iohan & lucas
And vigilies and fastyng-dayes · alle þise late I passe
And ligge abedde in lenten · an my lemman in myn armes
Tyl matynes and masse be do · and þanne go to þe freres
Come I to ite missa est · I holde me yserued
I nam nouȝte shryuen some-tyme · but if sekenesse it make
Nouȝt tweies in two ȝere · and þanne vp gesse I shcryue me

¶ I haue be prest and parsoun · passynge thretti wynter
# de presbiteris venatoribusM5.428 Ȝete can I neither solfe ne synge · ne seyntes lyues rede
# de presbiteris venatoribusM5.428 But I can fynde in a felde · or in a fourlonge an hare
# de presbiteris venatoribusM5.428 · notaC5.431, B/B mark at 5.419 Better þan in beatus vir · or in beati omnes
# de presbiteris venatoribusM5.428 · notaC5.431, B/B mark at 5.419 Construe oon clause wel · and kenne it to my parochienes
# de presbiteris venatoribusM5.428 · notaC5.431, B/B mark at 5.419 I can holde louedayes · and here a Reues rekenynge
# de presbiteris venatoribusM5.428 · notaC5.431, B/B mark at 5.419 Ac in canoun ne in þe decretales · I can nouȝte rede a lyne

+L5.423 ¶ Ȝif I bigge and borwe it · but ȝif it be ytailled
+L5.423 I forȝete it as ȝerne · and ȝif men me it axe
+L5.423 Sixe sithes or seuene · I forsake it with othes
+L5.423 And þus tene I trewe men · ten hundreth tymes

¶ And my seruauntz some-tyme · her salarye is bihynde
Reuthe is to here rekenynge · whan we shal rede acompted
So with wikked wille and wraththe · my werkmen I paye

¶ Ȝif any man doth me a benfait · or helpeth me at nede
notaW5.439 I am vnkynde aȝein his curteisye · and can nouȝte vnderstonde it
notaW5.439 For I haue and haue hadde · some-dele haukes maneres
notaW5.439 I nam nouȝte lured with loue · but þere ligge auȝte vnder þe thombe

¶ The kyndenesse þat myne euene-cristene · kidde me farnere
Sixty sythes I sleuthe · haue fo[r]ȝete it sith
In speche and in sparynge of speche · yspilte many a tyme
Bothe flesche & fissche · and many other vitailles
Bothe bred and ale · butter melke and chese
Forsleuthed in my seruyse · til it myȝte serue noman

¶ I ran aboute in ȝouthe · and ȝaf me nouȝte to lerne
+L5.451 And euere sith be beggere · for my foule sleuthe
+L5.451 Heu michi quia sterilem vitam duxi Iuuenilem

¶ Repentestow þe nauȝte · quod repentance · and riȝte with þat he swowned
An admonition to beware of dispair in repentaunceCr3.5.451 Til vigilate þe veille · fette water at his eyȝen
An admonition to beware of dispair in repentaunceCr3.5.451 And flatte it on his face · and faste on hym criede

¶ Þanne sat sleuthe vp · and seyned hym swithe
And made avowe to-fore god · for his foule sleuthe
Shal no sondaye be þis seuene ȝere · but sykenesse it lette
Þat I ne shal do me er day · to þe dere cherche
And heren matines and masse · as I a monke were
Shal none ale after mete · holde me þennes
Tyl I haue euensonge herde · I behote to þe Rode
And ȝete wil I ȝelde aȝein · if I so moche haue
Al þat I wikkedly wan · sithen I wytte hadde

¶ And þough my liflode lakke · leten I nelle
Þat eche man ne shal haue his · ar I hennes wende
And with þe residue · and þe remenaunt · bi þe Rode of chestre
I shal seke treuthe arst · ar I se Rome

¶ What bifel of þis feloun · I can nouȝte faire schewe
#M5.485 Wel I wote he wepte faste · water with boþe his eyen
#M5.485 And knowleched his gult · to cryst ȝete eftsones
#M5.485 Þat penitencia his pyke · he shulde polsche newe
#M5.485 And lepe with hym ouer londe · al his lyf-tyme
#M5.485 For he had leyne bi latro · luciferes aunte

the prayer of RepentanceM5.490 ¶ And þanne had repentaunce reuthe · and redde hem alle to knele
the prayer of RepentanceM5.490 For I shal biseche for al synful · owre saueoure of grace
the prayer of RepentanceM5.490 To amende vs of owre mysdedes · and do mercy to vs alle

nota beneM5.493 ¶ Now god quod he · þat of þi goodnesse · gonne þe worlde make
nota beneM5.493 And of nauȝte madest auȝte · and man moste liche to þi-selue
nota beneM5.493 And sithen suffredest for to synne · a sikenesse to vs alle
nota beneM5.493 And al for þe best as I bileue · what-euere þe boke telleth

For þourgh þat synne þi sone · sent was to þis erthe
And bicam man of a mayde · mankynde to saue

¶C2.5.531 ¶ A thousand of men þo · thrungen togyderes
¶C2.5.531 Criede vpward to cryst · and to his clene moder
¶C2.5.531 To haue grace to go with hem treuthe to seke

¶ Ac þere was wyȝte non so wys · þe wey þider couthe
But blustreden forth as bestes · ouer bankes and hilles
Til late was and longe · þat þei a lede mette
Apparailled as a paynym · in pylgrymes wyse
He bare a burdoun ybounde · with a brode liste
In a withewyndes wise · ywounden aboute
A bolle and a bagge · he bare by his syde
- C5.534 An hundreth of ampulles · on his hatt seten
- C5.534 Signes of synay and shelles of galice
- C5.534 And many a cruche on his cloke · and keyes of Rome
- C5.534 And þe vernicle bifore · for men shulde knowe
- C5.534 And se bi his signes · whom he souȝte hadde

¶ Þis folke frayned hym firste · fro whennes he come

¶ Fram synay he seyde · and fram owre lordes sepulcre
In bethleem and in babiloyne · I haue ben in bothe
In ermonye in alisaundre · in many other places
#M5.549 Ȝe may se bi my signes · þat sitten on myn hatte
#M5.549 Þat I haue walked ful wyde · in wete and in drye
#M5.549 And souȝte gode seyntes · for my soules helth

¶ For þouȝe I seye it my-self · I serue hym to paye
- C5.564 Ich haue myn huire wel · and otherwhiles more
- C5.564 He is þe prestest payer · þat pore men knoweth
- C5.564 He ne with-halt non hewe his hyre · þat he ne hath it at euen
- C5.564 He is as low as a lombe · and loueliche of speche

¶ Þanne shaltow come by a crofte · but come þow nouȝte þere-Inne
That crofte hat coueyte nouȝte · mennes catel ne her wyues
Ne none of her seruauntes · þat noyen hem myȝte
Loke ȝe breke no bowes þere · but if it be ȝowre owne

¶ Two stokkes þere stondeth · ac stynte ȝe nouȝte þere
They hat stele nouȝte ne slee nouȝte stryke forth by bothe
And leue hem on þi left halfe · and loke nouȝte þere-after
+M5.601 And holde wel þyne haliday heighe · til euen
+M5.601 Thanne shaltow blenche at a bergh · bere no false witnesse
+M5.601 He is frithed in with floreines · and other foes many
+M5.601 Loke þow plukke no plante þere · for peril of þi soule

¶ Þanne shal ȝe se sey soth · so it be to done
In no manere ellis nauȝte · for no mannes biddyng

¶ Þanne shaltow come to a courte · as clere as þe sonne
Þe mote is of mercy · þe manere · aboute
And alle þe wallis ben of witte · to holden wille oute
And kerneled with crystendome · man-kynde to saue
· NotaC5.606 eG6.609. No codicological reason. Boterased with bileue so · or þow beest nouȝte ysaued

¶ And alle þe houses ben hiled · halles and chambres
+L5.612 Wit no lede but with loue · and lowe speche as bretheren
+L5.612 Þe brugge is of bidde wel · þe bette may þow spede
+L5.612 Eche piler is of penaunce · of preyeres to seyntes
+L5.612 Of almes-dedes ar þe hokes · þat þe gates hangen on

¶ For he hath þe keye and þe clikat · þouȝ þe kynge slepe
And if grace graunte þe · to go in in þis wise
Þow shalt see in þi-selue · treuthe sitte in þine herte

¶ Ac bewar þanne of wrath þe · þat is a wikked shrewe
He hath enuye to hym · þat in þine herte sitteth
And pukketh forþ pruyde to prayse þi-seluen

¶ And who is sibbe to þis seuene · so me god helpe
He is wonderliche welcome · and faire vnderfongen
And but if ȝe be syb · to summe of þise seuene
It is ful harde bi myne heued quod Peres · for any of ȝow alle
To geten ingonge at any gate þere ; but grace be þe more

passus sextu[s]F5.653. A later secretary hand. The final character has been lost to cropping. The text of KD6.1 is marked in the left margin by a later secretary hand for the passus division. How Pi=ers assigneth women to worke . How Peers assigneth women to worke. I wil wende with ȝow · and þe way teche

¶ Þis were a longe lettynge · quod a lady in a sklayre
What sholde we wommen · worche þere-whiles

¶ Somme shal sowe sakke quod Piers · for shedyng of þe whete
And ȝe louely ladyes · with ȝoure longe fyngres
Þat ȝe han silke and sendal · to sowe whan tyme is
Chesibles for chapelleynes · cherches to honoure

¶ Wyues and wydwes · wolle & flex spynneth
nota Maketh cloth I conseille ȝow · and kenneth so ȝowre douȝtres
nota . nota .accompanied by a flourish at the bottom. Þe nedy and þe naked · nymmeth hede how hij liggeth
nota . nota .accompanied by a flourish at the bottom. And casteth hem clothes · for so comaundeth treuthe
nota . nota .accompanied by a flourish at the bottom. For I shal lene hem lyflode · but ȝif þe londe faille
nota . nota .accompanied by a flourish at the bottom. Flesshe and bred bothe · to riche and to pore
nota . nota .accompanied by a flourish at the bottom. As longe as I lyue · for þe lordes loue of heuene

¶ And alle manere of men · þat þorw mete and drynke lybbeth
Helpith hym to worche wiȝtliche · þat wynneth ȝowre fode

¶ Bi crist quod a knyȝte þo · he kenneth vs þe best
Ac on þe teme trewly · tauȝte was I neuere
# quomodo miles optulit seipsum ad aratrumM6.24 Ac kenne me quod þe knyȝte · and bi cryst I wil assaye

¶ Bi seynt Poule quod Perkyn · ȝe profre ȝow so faire
PierceCr3.6.26 # the Covenaunt by-twene the knyght & the plowmanM6.26 Þat I shal swynke and swete · and sowe for vs bothe

The flourish resembles those surrounding words written in the main scribal hand. Fro wastoures and fro wykked men · þat þis worlde struyeth

¶ And go hunte hardiliche to hares and to foxes
To bores and to brockes · þat breketh adown myne hegges
And go affaite þe faucones · wilde foules to kille
For suche cometh to my croft · and croppeth my whete

¶ Curteislich þe knyȝte þanne · comsed þise wordes
By my power Pieres quod he · I pliȝte þe my treuthe
To fulfille þis forward · þowȝ I fiȝte sholde
Als longe as I lyue · I shal þe mayntene

¶ I assente bi seynt Iame · seyde þe kniȝte þanne
Forto worche bi þi wordes · þe while my lyf dureth

¶ Ac who-so helpeth me to erie · or sowen here ar I wende
Shal haue leue bi owre lorde · to lese here in heruest

¶ Þe kirke shal haue my caroigne · and kepe my bones
For of my corne and catel · he craued þe tythe
to pay preestly is nothing for they be all receyversM6.96m I payed it hym prestly · for peril of my soule
to pay preestly is nothing for they be all receyversM6.96m For-thy is he holden I hope · to haue me in his masse
to pay preestly is nothing for they be all receyversM6.96m And mengen in his memorye · amonge alle crystene

¶ My wyf shal haue of þat I wan · with treuthe and nomore
And dele amonge my douȝtres · and my dere children
For þowgh I deye to-daye · my dettes ar quitte
I bare home þat I borwed · ar I to bedde ȝede

¶ And with þe residue and þe remenaunte · bi þe Rode of Lukes
I wil worschip þer-with · treuthe bi my lyue
And ben his pilgryme atte plow · for pore mennes sake
My plow-fote shal be my pyk-staf · and picche atwo þe rotes
And helpe my culter to kerue · and clense þe forwes

¶M6.108 ¶ Now is perkyn and his pilgrymes · to þe plowe faren
¶M6.108 To erie þis halue acre · holpyn hym manye
¶M6.108 Dikeres & delueres · digged vp þe balkes
¶M6.108 Þere-with was perkyn apayed · and preysed hem faste
¶M6.108 Other werkemen þere were · þat wrouȝten ful ȝerne
¶M6.108 Eche man in his manere · made hym-self to done
¶M6.108 And some to plese perkyn · piked vp þe wedes

¶ At heighe pryme peres · lete þe plowe stonde
To ouersen hem hym-self · and who-so best wrouȝte
He shulde be huyred þer-after · whan heruest-tyme come

¶ And þanne seten somme · and songen atte nale
Iolye workmenCr3.6.121 And hulpen erie his half acre · with how trolli lolli

¶ Now bi þe peril of my soule quod Pieres · al in pure tene
But ȝe arise þe rather · and rape ȝow to worche
Shal no greyne þat groweth · glade ȝow at nede
And þough ȝe deye for dole · þe deuel haue þat reccheth

¶ Tho were faitoures aferde · and feyned hem blynde

¶ Ac we preye for ȝow pieres · and for ȝowre plow bothe
Þat god of his grace · ȝowre grayne multiplye

# Contra wastersM6.137 He shal ete whete bred · and drynke with my-selue
# Contra wastersM6.137 Tyl god of his goodnesse · amendement hym sende

¶ And þanne gan a wastoure to wrath hym · and wolde haue yfouȝte

¶ Hunger in haste þo · hent wastour bi þe mawe
# quod Fames venit ad puniendum vastumM6.178 And wronge hym so bi þe wombe · þat bothe his eyen wattered

¶ Faitoures for fere her-of · flowen in-to bernes
And flapten on with flayles · fram morwe til euen
That hunger was nouȝt so hardy · on hem forto loke
For a potful of peses · þat peres hadde ymaked

An heep of heremites · henten hem spades
And ketten here copes · and courtpies hem made
how beggers andwastouris ben schasticedC2.6.194 And wenten as werkemen · with spades and with schoueles

+L6.195 nota how beggers & wastouris been chastisedO6.196. The word nota is accompanied by flourishes at left, right, and bottom. # that was baken For I bayerdM6.197 ye be so wanton so pro.e soR6.200, secretary hand And ȝaf hem mete as he myȝte aforth · and mesurable huyre

¶ Þanne hadde peres pite · and preyed hunger to wende
Home in-to his owne erd · and holden hym þere
For I am wel awroke now · of wastoures þorw þi myȝte
Ac I preye þe ar þow passe · quod Pieres to hunger
Of beggeres and of bidderes · what best be done
For I wote wel be þow went · þei wil worche ful ille
For myschief it maketh · þei beth so meke nouthe
And for defaute of her fode · þis folke is at my wille
Þey are my blody bretheren quod pieres · for god bouȝte vs alle
Treuthe tauȝte me ones · to louye hem vchone
And to helpen hem of alle þinge · ay as hem nedeth
And now wolde I witen of þe · what were þe best
How beg=ers mai be made to worke . Cr1.6.214 How begers maye be made to worke.Cr3.6.217 +L6.215 An how I myȝte amaistrien hem · and make hem to worche

¶ And if þow fynde any freke · þat fortune hath appeyred
Or any maner fals men · fonde þow suche to cnowe
Conforte hym with þi catel · for crystes loue of heuene
Loue hem and lene hem · so lawe of god techeth

¶ I wolde nouȝt greue god quod piers · for al þe good on grounde
Miȝte I synnelees do as þow seist · seyde pieres þanne

¶ Ȝe I bihote þe quod hunger · or ellis þe bible lieth
Go to Genesis þe gyaunt · þe engendroure of vs alle
In sudore and swynke · þow shalt þi mete tilye
And laboure for þi lyflode · and so owre lorde hyȝte
And sapience seyth þe same · I seigh it in þe bible

¶ Kynde witt wolde · þat eche a wyght wrouȝte
Or in dykynge or in deluynge · or trauaillynge in preyeres
Contemplatyf lyf or actyf lyf · cryst wolde men wrouȝte
Þe sauter seyth in þe psalme · of beati omnes
Þe freke þat fedeth hym-self · with his feythful laboure
He is blessed by þe boke · in body and in soule

¶ I wote wel quod hunger · what sykenesse ȝow eyleth

¶ By seynt Poule quod pieres · þise aren profitable wordis
Wende now hunger whan þow wolt · þat wel be þow euere
For þis is a louely lessoun · lorde it þe forȝelde

¶ By-hote god quod hunger · hennes ne wil I wende
Til I haue dyned bi þis day · and ydronke bothe

¶ I haue no peny quod peres · poletes · forto bigge
Ne neyther gees ne grys · but two grene cheses
A fewe cruddes and creem · and an hauer cake
And two loues of benes and bran · ybake for my fauntis
And ȝet I sey by my soule · I haue no salt bacoun
Ne no kokeney bi cryst coloppes forto maken
Ac I haue percil and porettes · and many kole plantes
notaW6.294 And eke a cow · and a kalf · and a cart mare
notaW6.294 To drawe afelde my donge · þe while þe drought lasteth
notaW6.294 And bi þis lyflode we mot lyue · til lammasse tyme
notaW6.294 And bi þat I hope to haue · heruest in my croft
notaW6.294 And þanne may I diȝte þi dyner · as me dere liketh
notaW6.294 | C6.294 Alle þe pore peple þo · pesecoddes fetten
notaW6.294 | C6.294 Benes and baken apples · þei brouȝte in her lappes
notaW6.294 | C6.294 Pore folk fede hun=ger . Cr1.6.300 Pore folk fede hunger.Cr3.6.300 ripe +M6.301, legible under ultraviolet light. Chibolles and cheruelles · and ripe chiries manye
notaW6.294 | C6.294 Pore folk fede hun=ger . Cr1.6.300 Pore folk fede hunger.Cr3.6.300 ripe +M6.301, legible under ultraviolet light. And profred peres þis present · to plese with hunger

¶ Al hunger eet in hast · and axed after more
Þanne pore folke for fere · fedde hunger ȝerne
With grene poret and pesen · to poysoun hunger þei þouȝte
By þat it neighed nere heruest · newe corne cam to chepynge
Þanne was folke fayne · and fedde hunger with þe best
With good ale as glotoun tauȝte · and gerte hunger go slepe

¶ And þo wolde wastour nouȝt werche · but wandren aboute
Ne no begger ete bred · þat benes Inne were
But of coket or clerematyn · or elles · of clene whete
Ne none halpeny ale · in none wise drynke
But of þe best and of þe brounest · þat in borgh is to selle

notaW6.314 ¶ Laboreres þat haue no lande · to lyue on but her handes
notaW6.314 notaW6.315 Deyned nouȝt to dyne a-day · nyȝt-olde wortes
notaW6.314 notaW6.315 notaW6.316 May no peny-ale hem paye · ne no pece of bakoun ·

¶ He greueth hym aȝeines god · and gruccheth aȝeines resoun
And þanne curseth he þe kynge · and al his conseille after
Suche lawes to loke · laboreres to greue
Ac whiles hunger was her maister · þere wolde none of hem chyde
Ne stryue aȝeines his statut · so sterneliche he loked

Passus septimus


Treuthe herde telle her-of · and to peres he sent
To taken his teme and tulyen þe erthe

Piercis Pardon . Piercis Pardon. A pena & a culpaO7.3. Three ticks, the first underlined in red, follow. And bad hym holde hym at home · and eryen his leyes
Piercis Pardon . Piercis Pardon. A pena & a culpaO7.3. Three ticks, the first underlined in red, follow. And alle þat halpe hym to erie · to sette or to sowe

Piercis Pardon . Piercis Pardon. A pena & a culpaO7.3. Three ticks, the first underlined in red, follow. Pardoun with pieres plowman · treuthe hath ygraunted

¶ Kynges and knyȝtes · þat kepen holycherche
And ryȝtfullych in reumes · reulen þe peple
Han pardoun thourgh purgatorie · to passe ful lyȝtly
With patriarkes and prophetes · in paradise to be felawes

¶ Bisshopes yblessed · ȝif þei ben as þei shulden
Legistres of bothe þe lawes · þe lewed þere-with to preche
And in as moche as þei mowe · amende alle synful
Aren peres with þe apostles · þus pardoun Piers sheweth
And at þe day of dome · atte heigh deyse to sytte

Marchundis # quod mercatores non sunt soluti a pena & culpa quia non sanctificant sabatum MarchauntisO7.18. Another hand, apparently hand 3, has substituted a supralinear <d> for the <t> in Marchauntis. Aȝein clene conscience · her catel to selle

What merchauntes shuld do. ¶ Ac vnder his secret seel · treuthe sent hem a lettre
What merchauntes shuld do. That þey shulde bugge boldely · þat hem best liked
What merchauntes shuld do. And sithenes selle it aȝein · and saue þe wynnyge
What merchauntes shuld do. how þou shalt doþin almes How þou schalt do þin almes And amende mesondieux þere-myde · and myseyse folke helpe
What merchauntes shuld do. how þou shalt doþin almes How þou schalt do þin almes And wikked wayes · wiȝtlich hem amende
What merchauntes shuld do. how þou shalt doþin almes How þou schalt do þin almes And do bote to brugges þat to-broke were
What merchauntes shuld do. how þou shalt doþin almes How þou schalt do þin almes Marien maydenes · or maken hem nonnes
What merchauntes shuld do. how þou shalt doþin almes How þou schalt do þin almes Pore peple and prisounes · fynden hem here fode
What merchauntes shuld do. how þou shalt doþin almes How þou schalt do þin almes #M7.31 And sette scoleres to scole · or to somme other craftes
What merchauntes shuld do. how þou shalt doþin almes How þou schalt do þin almes #M7.31 Releue Religioun · and renten hem bettere
What merchauntes shuld do. how þou shalt doþin almes How þou schalt do þin almes #M7.31 And I shal sende ȝow my-selue · seynt Michel myn archangel
What merchauntes shuld do. how þou shalt doþin almes How þou schalt do þin almes #M7.31 Þat no deuel shal ȝow dere · ne fere ȝow in ȝowre deying
What merchauntes shuld do. how þou shalt doþin almes How þou schalt do þin almes #M7.31 And witen ȝow fro wanhope · if ȝe wil þus worche
What merchauntes shuld do. how þou shalt doþin almes How þou schalt do þin almes #M7.31 #M7.36 And sende ȝowre sowles in safte · to my seyntes in ioye

¶ Þanne were Marchauntz mery · many wepten for ioye
And preyseden Pieres þe plowman · þat purchaced þis bulle

¶ Whan þei drawen on to deye · and Indulgences wolde haue
Her pardoun is ful petit · at her partyng hennes
Þat any Mede of mene men for her motyng taketh
Ȝe legistres and lawyeres · holdeth þis for treuthe
Þat ȝif þat I lye · Mathew is to blame

¶ Þe prest and perkyn · apposeden eyther other
And I þorw here wordes awoke · and waited aboute
And seighe þe sonne in þe south sitte þat tyme

Of the dreames of IosephCr3.7.173 · Nota · C7.176, B/B mark at 7.161 Of þe dre=mes of Iosephe . Cr1.7.175 I my-self and my sones · seche þe for nede

¶ It bifel as his fader seyde · in pharaoes tyme
Þat ioseph was iustice · egipte to loken
It bifel as his fader tolde · his frendes þere hym souȝte
And al þis maketh me · on þis meteles to þynke

¶ And how þe prest preued · no pardoun to dowel
# quod dowell superest IndulgenciasM7.184 And demed þat dowel · indulgences passed
# quod dowell superest IndulgenciasM7.184 Dowell passith the pardon of petres churcheL7.185 Biennales and triennales · and bisschopes lettres
# quod dowell superest IndulgenciasM7.184 Dowell passith the pardon of petres churcheL7.185 And how dowel at þe day of dome · is dignelich vnderfongen

XL7.197 now haþ þe per .Any text that may have followed has been lost to cropping; it would have appeared as a continuation of the first marginal line, since per appears alone on the second with blank space following it. It would seem to have been a version of the first missing line following l. 186, "Now haþ þe pope power pardon to graunte." ¶ For-þi I rede ȝow renkes · þat riche ben on þis erthe

¶ For-þi I conseille alle cristene · to crye god mercy
And Marie his moder · be owre mene bitwene
Þat god gyue vs grace here · ar we gone hennes
Suche werkes to werche · while we ben here
Þat after owre deth-day · dowel reherce
finitur visionemG8.217. Note that this script is very similar to that used for the title on f.1r. This could be a more formal version of the script of the main scribe but it bears a somewhat closer resemblance to the marginalia initialled by WH (ff.69v, 70r and 103r. notaG8.217. Marginal "nota" is in brown ink. Compare with the marginalia by WH cited above. The explicit has been underlined in the same brown ink. ...?...?...M7.216. The erasure damaged the passus heading for passus 8, which was subsequently repaired in brown ink. At þe day of dome · we dede as he hiȝte

Passus octauus de visione & primus de dowel


quintus / sextusF6.1, marks passus division + ...?... Thus yrobed in russet · I rowmed aboute
quintus / sextusF6.1, marks passus division + ...?... Al a somer sesoun · for to seke dowel
quintus / sextusF6.1, marks passus division + ...?... And frayned ful oft · of folke þat I mette
quintus / sextusF6.1, marks passus division + ...?... If ani wiȝte wiste · where dowel was at Inne
quintus / sextusF6.1, marks passus division + ...?... And what man he miȝte be · of many man I axed

# the questioun askyn of Freris of dowell ¶ Was neuere wiȝte as I went · þat me wisse couthe
# the questioun askyn of Freris of dowell Where þis lede lenged · lasse ne more

· Nota · [drawing of bird] ¶ Tyl it bifel on a fryday · two freres I mette
· Nota · [drawing of bird] Maistres of þe Menoures · men of grete witte
· Nota · [drawing of bird] I hailsed hem hendely as I hadde lerned
· Nota · [drawing of bird] And preyed hem par charitee · ar þei passed forther
· Nota · [drawing of bird] + If þei knewe any contre · or costes as þei went
· Nota · [drawing of bird] + Where þat dowel dwelleth · doth me to wytene

¶ For þei ben men on þis molde · þat moste wyde walken
And knowen contrees · and courtes · and many kynnes places
Bothe prynces paleyses · and pore mennes cotes
And dowel and doyuel · where þei dwelle bothe

¶ Amonges vs quod þe Menours · þat man is dwellyng
And euere hath as I hope · and euere shal here-after

¶ I shal sey þe my sone · seide þe frere þanne
similitudoG9.28 How seuene sithes þe sad man · on þe day synneth

notaW8.30 ¶ Lat brynge a man in a bote · amydde a brode water
notaW8.30 notaW8.31 Þe wynde and þe water · and þe bote waggynge
notaW8.30 notaW8.31 notaW8.32 Maketh þe man many a tyme · to falle and to stonde
notaW8.30 notaW8.31 notaW8.32 notaW8.33 For stonde he neuere so styf · he stombleth ȝif he moeue
notaW8.30 notaW8.31 notaW8.32 notaW8.33 notaW8.34 Ac ȝit is he sauf and sounde · and so hym bihoueth
notaW8.30 notaW8.31 notaW8.32 notaW8.33 notaW8.34 notaW8.35 For ȝif he ne arise þe rather · and rauȝte to þe stiere
notaW8.30 notaW8.31 notaW8.32 notaW8.33 notaW8.34 notaW8.35 notaW8.36 Þe wynde wolde wyth þe water · þe bote ouerthrowe
notaW8.30 notaW8.31 notaW8.32 notaW8.33 notaW8.34 notaW8.35 notaW8.36 notaW8.37 And þanne were his lyf loste · þourgh lacchesse of hym-self

notaW8.38 ¶ And þus it falleth quod þe frere · bi folke here on erthe
notaW8.38 notaW8.39 Þe water is likned to þe worlde · þat wanyeth and wexeth
notaW8.38 notaW8.39 notaW8.40 Þe godis of þis grounde aren like · to þe grete wawes
notaW8.38 notaW8.39 notaW8.40 notaW8.41 Þat as wyndes and wederes · walweth aboute
notaW8.38 notaW8.39 notaW8.40 notaW8.41 notaW8.42 Þe bote is likned to owre body · þat brutel is of kynde
notaW8.38 notaW8.39 notaW8.40 notaW8.41 notaW8.42 +L8.43 notaW8.43 Þat þorugh þe fende and þi flessh · and þe frele worlde

kepethM8.45 ¶ Ac dedly synne doth he nouȝt · for dowel hym kepith
kepethM8.45 # quod Caritas maxime adiuuat contra peccatumM8.46 And þat is charite þe champioun · chief help aȝein synne

¶ I haue no kynde knowyng quod I · to conceyue alle ȝowre wordes
Ac if I may lyue and loke · I shal go lerne bettere
I bikenne þe cryst · þat on þe crosse deyde
And I seyde þe same · saue ȝow fro myschaunce
And ȝiue ȝow grace on þis grounde · good men to worthe

· Nota · ¶ And þus I went wide-where walkyng myne one
· Nota · By a wilde wildernesse · and bi a wode-syde
· Nota · nota Blisse of þo briddes · brouȝte me aslepe
· Nota · nota And vnder a lynde vppon a launde · lened I a stounde
· Nota · nota To lythe þe layes · þo louely foules made
· Nota · nota + nota Murthe of her mouthes · made me þere to slepe
· Nota · nota + nota Þe merueillousest meteles · mette me þanne
· Nota · nota + nota + Þat euer [dremed] wyȝte · in worlde as I wene

# quomodo thought primo apparuit in sompno ¶ A moche man as me þouȝte · and lyke to my-selue
# quomodo thought primo apparuit in sompno Come and called me · by my kynde name
# quomodo thought primo apparuit in sompno What artow quod I þo · þat þow my name knowest
# quomodo thought primo apparuit in sompno Þat þow wost wel quod he · and no wyȝte bettere

· thouȝt · ¶ Wote I what þow art ; þought · seyde he þanne
· thouȝt · ThoughteC2.8.73 I haue suwed þe þis seuene ȝere · sey þow me no rather

¶ Art þow thought quod I þo · þow couthest me wisse
Where þat dowel dwelleth · and do me þat to knowe

Do . bettC2.8.82 dobettreG9.84. As Benson and Blanchfield point out (pp.42 and 132.1) the form of the letters here suggests that the scribe and rubricator are the same using different scripts. ¶ Dobet doth ryȝt þus · ac he doth moche more

¶ Thus dowel and dobet · and dobest þe thridde
Crouned one to be kynge · to kepin hem alle
And to reule þe Reume · bi her thre wittes
And none other wise · but as þei thre assented

¶ I thonked thouȝt þo · þat he me þus tauȝte
· Nota · C8.107, B/B mark at 8.109 Ac ȝete sauoureth me nouȝt þi seggyng · I coueite to lerne
· Nota · C8.107, B/B mark at 8.109 How dowel dobet and dobest · don amonges þe peple

¶ But witte conne wisse þe quod þouȝt · where þo thre dwelle
Ellis wote I none þat can · þat now is alyue

What was dowel · fro dobet · and dobest fram hem bothe

Passus nonus


nota bene Sire dowel dwelleth quod witte · nouȝt a day hennes
nota bene In a castel þat kynde made · of foure kynnes þinges
nota bene Of erthe and eyre is it made · medled togideres
nota bene With wynde and with water · witterly enioyned
nota bene Kynde hath closed þere-Inne · craftily with-alle
nota bene A lemman þat he loueth · like to hym-selue
nota bene Anima she hatte · ac enuye hir hateth
nota bene A proude pryker of Fraunce · prynceps huius mundi
nota bene And wolde winne hir awey · with wyles and he myȝte

¶ Ac kynde knoweth þis wel · and kepeth hir þe bettere
And hath do hir with sire dowel · is duke of þis marches
# secunda discripcio de dowell Dobet is hir damoisele · sire doweles douȝter
# secunda discripcio de dowell To serue þis lady lelly · bothe late and rathe
# secunda discripcio de dowell Dobest is aboue bothe · a bisschopes pere
# secunda discripcio de dowell Þat he bit mote be do · he reuleth hem alle
# secunda discripcio de dowell Anima þat lady · is ladde bi his lerynge

In wytte hath fyue sonnes, ¶ Ac þe constable of þat castel · þat kepeth al þe wacche

¶ What kynnes thyng is kynde quod I · canstow me telle

natura naturans # quod natura est Creator omnium rerum ¶ Kynde quod witte is a creatour · of alle kynnes þinges
natura naturans # quod natura est Creator omnium rerum Fader and fourmour · of al þat euere was maked
natura naturans # quod natura est Creator omnium rerum And þat is þe gret god þat gynnynge had neuere
natura naturans # quod natura est Creator omnium rerum Lorde of lyf and of lyȝte · of lysse and of peyne
natura naturans # quod natura est Creator omnium rerum Angeles and al þing aren at his wille

id est adamBx9.34: id est adam: This gloss appears above the line in LM, and was incorporated into the text in CrHmF. It was therefore presumably a feature of the archetypal text. In R man is a correction in a second hand, perhaps indicating the scribe's confusion. id est adam  .id est. adamgloss on "man" ¶ And made man likkest · to hym-self one

¶ And so it semeth · bi hym ; as þe bible telleth
# quia non solum verbo sed opere facta sunt Þere he seyde dixit · & facta sunt
# quia non solum verbo sed opere facta sunt He moste worche with his worde · and his witte shewe
# quia non solum verbo sed opere facta sunt And in þis manere was man made · þorugh myȝte of god almiȝti
# quia non solum verbo sed opere facta sunt With his worde and werkemanschip · and with lyf to laste
# quia non solum verbo sed opere facta sunt And þus god gaf hym a goost · of þe godhed of heuene
# quia non solum verbo sed opere facta sunt And of his grete grace graunted hym blisse
# quia non solum verbo sed opere facta sunt And þat is lyf þat ay shal last · to al lynage after
# quia non solum verbo sed opere facta sunt And þat is þe castel þat kynde made · caro it hatte
# quia non solum verbo sed opere facta sunt # the makyng off man with the sowle And is as moche to mene · as man with a soule
# quia non solum verbo sed opere facta sunt # the makyng off man with the sowle And þat he wrouȝt with werke · and with worde bothe
# quia non solum verbo sed opere facta sunt # the makyng off man with the sowle Þorugh myȝte of þe maieste · man was ymaked

¶ Inwit and alle wittes closed ben þer-inne
anima Anima For loue of þe lady anima · þat lyf is ynempned
anima Anima Ouer-al in mannes body · he walketh and wandreth
anima Anima Ac in þe herte is hir home · and hir moste reste
anima Anima Ac Inwitte is in þe hed · and to the herte he loketh
anima Anima What anima is lief or loth · he lat hir at his wille
anima Anima nota For after þe grace of god · þe grettest is Inwitte

¶ Of þis matere I myȝte · make a longe tale
And fynde fele witnesses · amonges þe foure doctours
And þat I lye nouȝt of þat I lere þe · luke bereth witnesse

Lesynge of tymeC2.9.106 Is moste yhated vp erthe · of hem þat beth in heuene

Ne his gleman a gedelyng · a goer to tauernes

¶ To alle trew tidy men · þat trauaille desyren
Owre lorde loueth hem and lent · loude other stille
Grace to go to hem · and agon her lyflode
Psa.34.Cr3.9.115 Inquirentes autem dominum non minuentur omni bono

Mariage is praisedCr3.9.116 # Quarta discripcio de dowellM9.116 ¶ Trewe wedded libbing folk · in þis worlde is dowel
Mariage is praisedCr3.9.116 # Quarta discripcio de dowellM9.116 For þei mote worche & wynne · and þe worlde susteyne
Mariage is praisedCr3.9.116 # Quarta discripcio de dowellM9.116 For of her kynde þei come · þat confessoures ben nempned

# that Seem and Caymes kynd shuld not CopleM9.136 ¶ Ȝet some aȝein þe sonde of owre saueoure of heuene
# that Seem and Caymes kynd shuld not CopleM9.136 Caymes kynde & his kynde · coupled togideres
# that Seem and Caymes kynd shuld not CopleM9.136 Tyl god wratthed for her werkis · and suche a worde seyde
# that Seem and Caymes kynd shuld not CopleM9.136 Þat I maked man · now it me athynketh
# that Seem and Caymes kynd shuld not CopleM9.136 Gene.vi.Cr2.9.139 Gene.vi.Cr3.9.140 Penitet me fecisse hominem

¶ And come to Noe anon · and bad hym nouȝt lette
Swithe go shape a shippe · of shides and of bordes
Þiself and þi sones three · and sithen ȝowre wyues
Buske ȝow to þat bote · and bideth ȝe þer-inne
Tyl fourty dayes be fulfilde · þat flode haue ywasshen
Clene awey þe cursed blode · þat caym hath ymaked

¶ Bestes þat now ben · shulle banne þe tyme
Þat euere þat cursed caym · come on þis erthe
Alle shal deye for his dedes · bi dales and bi hulles
And þe foules þat fleeghen · for[th] with other bestes
Excepte oneliche of eche kynde a couple
Þat in þi shyngled shippe · shul ben ysaued

notaW9.157 notaW9.158 Þat somdel þe sone · shal haue þe sires tacches

Passus decimus


Wyttes wyfe nota Thanne hadde witte a wyf · was hote dame studye
Wyttes wyfe nota Þat lene was of lere · and of liche bothe
Wyttes wyfe nota The wyfe of Wytty She was wonderly wroth · þat witte me þus tauȝte
Wyttes wyfe nota The wyfe of Wytty And al starynge dame studye · sternelich seyde
Wyttes wyfe nota The wyfe of Wytty Wel artow wyse quod she to witte · any wysdomes to telle
Wyttes wyfe nota The wyfe of Wytty To flatereres or to folis · þat frantyk ben of wittes
Wyttes wyfe nota The wyfe of Wytty # quod perlis non debent mitteri Coram porcis And blamed hym and banned hym · and badde hym be stylle
Wyttes wyfe nota The wyfe of Wytty # quod perlis non debent mitteri Coram porcis With suche wise wordes · to wissen any sottes
Wyttes wyfe nota The wyfe of Wytty # quod perlis non debent mitteri Coram porcis # And seyde noli mittere man · margerye perlis
Wyttes wyfe nota The wyfe of Wytty # quod perlis non debent mitteri Coram porcis # Amanges hogges þat han · hawes at wille
Wyttes wyfe nota The wyfe of Wytty # quod perlis non debent mitteri Coram porcis # Þei don but dryuele þer-on draffe were hem leuere
Wyttes wyfe nota The wyfe of Wytty # quod perlis non debent mitteri Coram porcis # # Þan al þe precious perre · þat in paradys wexeth
Wyttes wyfe nota The wyfe of Wytty # quod perlis non debent mitteri Coram porcis # # I sey it bi suche quod she þat sheweth bi her werkes
Wyttes wyfe nota The wyfe of Wytty # quod perlis non debent mitteri Coram porcis # # By their workes know them Þat hem were leuer londe · and lordship on erthe
Wyttes wyfe nota The wyfe of Wytty # quod perlis non debent mitteri Coram porcis # # By their workes know them Or ricchesse or rentis · and reste at her wille
Wyttes wyfe nota The wyfe of Wytty # quod perlis non debent mitteri Coram porcis # # By their workes know them Þan alle þe sothe sawes · þat salamon seyde euere

nota d nota ¶ Wisdome and witte now is nouȝt worth a carse
nota d nota nota But if it be carded with coueytise · as clotheres kemben here wolle
nota d nota nota Who is nowadaiescalled to counsaille nota Who-so can contreue deceytes · an conspire wronges
nota d nota nota Who is nowadaiescalled to counsaille nota nota And lede forth a loue-day · to latte with treuthe
nota d nota nota Who is nowadaiescalled to counsaille nota nota nota He þat suche craftes can · to conseille is clepid

All men loue baudryeCr3.10.51 ¶M10.51 notaW10.51 ¶ Ac murthe and mynstralcye · amonges men is nouthe

notaL10.54 notaW10.54 ¶ Ac if þei carpen of cryst · þis clerkis and þis lewed

notaL10.61 notaW10.61 ¶ Ac þe careful may crye · and carpen atte ȝate
notaL10.61 notaW10.61 notaW10.62 Bothe afyngred and a-thurst · and for chele quake
notaL10.61 notaW10.61 notaW10.62 notaW10.63 Is none to nymen hym nere · his noye to amende
notaL10.61 notaW10.61 notaW10.62 notaW10.63 notaW10.64 But heon on hym as an hounde · and hoten hym go þennes

¶ I haue yherde hiegh men etyng atte table
Carpen as þei clerkes were · of cryste and of his miȝtes
And leyden fautes vppon þe fader · þat fourmed vs alle
And carpen aȝeine clerkes · crabbed wordes
Whi wolde owre saueoure suffre suche a worme in his blisse
Þat bigyled þe womman · and þe man after
Þorw whiche wyles and wordes · þei went to helle
And al her sede for here synne · þe same deth suffred

notaM10.115 .id est. mentiturM10.115, unique gloss on "lieþ" ¶ Here lyeth ȝowre lore · þise lordes gynneth dispute
notaM10.115 .id est. mentiturM10.115, unique gloss on "lieþ" Of þat ȝe clerkes vs kenneth · of cryst by þe gospel

¶ Ymaginatyf her-after-ward · shal answere to ȝowre purpos

notaL10.124 ¶ Augustyne to suche argueres · he telleth hem þis teme
notaL10.124 Rom.xii.Cr3.10.125 Non plus sapere quam oportet
notaL10.124 Rom.xii.Cr3.10.125 Wilneth neuere to wite · whi þat god wolde
notaL10.124 Rom.xii.Cr3.10.125 Suffre sathan his sede to bigyle
notaL10.124 Rom.xii.Cr3.10.125 Rom.xii.Cr2.10.128 Ac bileue lelly · in þe lore of holicherche
notaL10.124 Rom.xii.Cr3.10.125 Rom.xii.Cr2.10.128 xM10.129 And preye hym of pardoun · and penaunce in þi lyue
notaL10.124 Rom.xii.Cr3.10.125 Rom.xii.Cr2.10.128 xM10.129 And for his moche mercye · to amende ȝow here
notaL10.124 Rom.xii.Cr3.10.125 Rom.xii.Cr2.10.128 xM10.129 notaM10.131 non sunt omnes cause querendeM10.131 For alle þat wilneth to wyte · þe weyes of god almiȝty
notaL10.124 Rom.xii.Cr3.10.125 Rom.xii.Cr2.10.128 xM10.129 notaM10.131 non sunt omnes cause querendeM10.131 [pointing hand]F7.134, possibly the same hand that underlined "in his ers" in the text. I wolde his eye were in his ers · and his fynger after

¶ And þo þat vseth þis hauelounes · to blende mennes wittes
What is dowel fro dobet · now def mote he worthe
Sitthe he wilneth to wyte · whiche þei ben bothe
But if he lyue in þe lyf · þat longeth to dowel
bene loquiturM10.142 For I dar ben his bolde borgh · þat dobet wil he neuere
bene loquiturM10.142 Þeigh dobest drawe on hym day after other

notaL10.144 ¶ And whan þat witte was ywar what dame studye tolde
notaL10.144 He bicome so confus · he couth nouȝte loke
notaL10.144 And as doumbe a[s] deth · and drowe hym arrere

+L10.147 ¶ And for no carpyng I couth after · ne knelyng to þe grounde
+L10.147 I myȝte gete no greyne · of his grete wittis
+L10.147 But al laughyng he louted · and loked vppon studye
+L10.147 The maner of \ them þat be in office,Cr3.10.150 In signe þat I shulde · biseche hir of grace

¶ And whan I was war of his wille · to his wyf gan I loute
And seyde mercy madame ȝowre man shal I worthe
As longe as I lyue · bothe late & rathe
Forto worche ȝowre wille · þe while my lyf dureth
With þat ȝe kenne me kyndely · to knowe what is dowel

¶ For þi mekenesse man quod she · and for þi mylde speche

¶ Saye hym þis signe · I sette hym to scole
Studye teacheth, al thingsCr3.10.178 ...?...M10.178 And þat I grette wel his wyf · for I wrote hir many bokes

¶ Plato þe poete · I put hym fyrste to boke
Arestotle and other moo · to argue I tauȝte
Grammer for gerles · I garte first wryte
And bette hem with a baleis · but if þei wolde lerne
Of alkinnes craftes · I contreued toles
Of carpentrie of kerueres and compassed masouns
And lerned hem leuel and lyne · þough I loke dymme

notaL10.189 NotaM10.189 ¶ Ac theologie hath tened me · ten score tymes

notaL10.189 NotaM10.189 notaW10.191 notaW10.192 And þe depper I deuyne · þe derker me it þinketh

¶ Poule preched þe peple þat parfitnesse loued
notaW10.212 To do good for goddes loue · and gyuen men þat asked
notaW10.212 And nameliche to suche · þat sueth owre bileue
notaW10.212 notaW10.214 And alle þat lakketh vs or lyeth vs · owre lorde techeth vs to louye
notaW10.212 notaW10.214 notaW10.215 And nouȝt to greuen hem þat greueth vs · god hym-self for-badde it

¶ Ac astronomye is an harde þynge · and yuel forto knowe

# FybicchisM10.222 ¶ Ȝet ar þere fybicches in forceres · of fele mennes makyng
# FybicchisM10.222 Ars AlcumisticaC2.10.223 Experimentz of alkamye · þe poeple to deceyue
# FybicchisM10.222 Ars AlcumisticaC2.10.223 If þow þinke to dowel · dele þer-with neuere
# FybicchisM10.222 Ars AlcumisticaC2.10.223 Alle þise science I my-self · sotiled and ordeyned
# FybicchisM10.222 Ars AlcumisticaC2.10.223 XL10.226 And founded hem formest · folke to deceyue

¶ Telle clergye þise tokenes · and scripture after
To conseille þe kyndely · to knowe what is dowel ·

¶ I seide graunt mercy madame · and mekeliche hir grette
And went wiȝtlich awey · with-oute more lettynge
And til I come to clergye · I couthe neuere stynte
And gret þe good man · as studye me tauȝte
And afterwardes þe wyf · and worshiped hem bothe
And tolde hem þe tokenes · þat me tauȝte were
Was neuere gome vppon þis grounde · sith god made þe worlde
Fairer vnder-fongen · ne frendeloker at ese
Þan my-self sothly · sone so he wist
Þat I was of wittis hous · and with his wyf dame studye
I seyde to hem sothely · þat sent was I þider
Dowel and dobet · and dobest to lerne

Do-WellC2.10.241 ¶ It is a comune lyf quod clergye · on holycherche to bileue
Do-WellC2.10.241 # de trinitateM10.242 With alle þe artikles of þe feithe · þat falleth to be knowe
Do-WellC2.10.241 # de trinitateM10.242 And þat is to bileue lelly · bothe lered and lewed
Do-WellC2.10.241 # de trinitateM10.242 On þe grete god · þat gynnyng had neuere
Do-WellC2.10.241 # de trinitateM10.242 And on þe sothfaste sone · þat saued mankynde
Do-WellC2.10.241 # de trinitateM10.242 Fro þe dedly deth · and þe deueles power
Do-WellC2.10.241 # de trinitateM10.242 Þorwgh þe helpe of þe holy goste · þe whiche goste is of bothe
Do-WellC2.10.241 # de trinitateM10.242 Three persones · ac nouȝt in plurel noumbre
Do-WellC2.10.241 # de trinitateM10.242 For al is but on god · and eche is god hym-selue

¶ Austyn þe olde · here-of he made bokes
And hym-self ordeyned · to sadde vs in bileue

# to abbottis and prioursM10.283 ¶ I rede eche a blynde bosarde · do bote to hym-selue

¶ Ac it semeth now sothly · to þe worldes syght
Þat goddes worde worcheth nauȝte · on lered ne on lewede
Agaynste leawde prystes . Cr1.10.291 But in suche a manere · as Marke meneth in þe gospel

Agaynst lewed priestesCr3.10.292 And þe festu is fallen · for ȝowre defaute

¶ And þanne shal borel clerkes ben abasched · to blame ȝow or to greue
And carpen nouȝte as þei carpen now · and calle ȝow doumbe houndes
Esaye.iviCr2.10.304 Esaie.lviCr3.10.304 Canes non valentes latrare
Esaye.iviCr2.10.304 Esaie.lviCr3.10.304 And drede to wratthe ȝow in any worde · ȝowre werkemanship to lette

Esaye.iviCr2.10.304 Esaie.lviCr3.10.304 And al for ȝowre holynesse · haue ȝe þis in herteHereafter follow 10.297-308 in KD; however, none of these lines are annotated; could that argue to their lateness?

¶ Þat is in extremis quod scripture · amonges saracenes and iewes
Þei mowen be saued so · and þat is owre byleue

¶ Ac crysten men with-oute more · may nouȝt come to heuene
For þat cryst for cristen men · deyde ; and confermed þe lawe
Þat who-so wolde and wylneth · with cryste to aryse

Col.iii.Cr2.10.363 Col iii,Cr3.10.362 +M10.370 +L10.372 id est panniL10.373  .id est. vestes clothisM10.373, gloss vestes is the same ink and hand as the main text. The hand of the later gloss clothis resembles that of the Latin note at the top of fol 104v (flyleaf), as well as that of the verses about the mace at the foot of that leaf. The sidenote "fiat voluntas" on fol. 64v may also be compared. And owre bakkes þat moth-eten be · and sen beggers go naked

¶ Þis is a longe lessoun quod I · and litel am I þe wyser
Where dowel is or dobet · derkelich ȝe shewen

Nota · C10.393 ¶ And if I shulde worke bi here werkes to wynne me heuene
Nota · C10.393 Þat for her werkes and witte · now wonyeth in pyne
Nota · C10.393 Þanne wrouȝte I vnwysely · what-so-euere ȝe preche

¶ Ac of fele witty in feith · litel ferly I haue
Þough her goste be vngraciouse · god for to plese
notaW10.403 For many men on þis molde · more sette here hertis

· Nota · C10.406 Mat.xxixi?Cr2.10.408 Thei that made Noe a shippe were vnsauedCr3.10.408 # archam NoeM10.414 Of wriȝtes þat it wrouȝte was none of hem ysaued

¶ God lene it fare nouȝt so bi folke · þat þe feith techen
Of holicherche þat he[r]berwe is · and goddes hous to saue
And shelden vs fram shame þer-inne · as noes shippe did bestes
And men þat maden it · amydde þe flode adreynten
Þe culorum of þis clause · curatoures is to mene
#M10.422 Þat ben carpenteres holykirke to make · for crystes owne bestes
#M10.422 CHECK MARGINCr2.10.420 Psalm.36Cr3.10.419 Homines & iumenta saluabis domine · &c ·

Hm.10.424-426, ilegible pen trials. ¶ On gode fridaye I fynde · a feloun was ysaued
Hm.10.424-426, ilegible pen trials. Þat had lyued al his lyf with lesynges and with thefte
Hm.10.424-426, ilegible pen trials. +L10.426 # Felon on Good FrydayM10.426 And for he biknewe on þe crosse · and to cryste s[h]rof hym

¶ Þanne Marye Magdaleyne · what womman dede worse
Or who worse þan dauid · þat vries deth conspired
Or Poule þe apostle · þat no pitee hadde
Moche crystene kynde · to kylle to deth
+L10.436 And ben þise as souereynes · wyth seyntes in heuene
+L10.436 Þo þat wrouȝte wikkedlokest · in worlde þo þei were

¶ And þo þat wisely wordeden · and wryten many bokes
Of witte and of wisdome · with dampned soules wonye
Þat salamon seith I trowe be soth · and certeyne of vs alle
Ecclesiastes. ivCr3.10.437 Sine iusti atque sapientes · & opera eorum in manu dei sunt &c

¶ Þere aren witty and wel libbyng ac her werkes ben yhudde
Eccle.ii?Cr2.10.440 XL10.443 In þe hondes of almiȝty god · and he wote þe sothe
Eccle.ii?Cr2.10.440 XL10.443 - C10.438 Wher for loue a man worth allowed þere · and his lele werkes
Eccle.ii?Cr2.10.440 XL10.443 - C10.438 Or elles for his yuel wille · & enuye of herte
Eccle.ii?Cr2.10.440 XL10.443 - C10.438 And be allowed as he lyued so · for bi lyther · men knoweth þe gode

¶ And wherby wote men whiche is whyte · if alle þinge blake were
And who were a gode man · but if þere were some shrewe
hijC10.443 For-þi lyue we forth with lither men · I leue fewe ben gode
hijC10.443 For qant oportet vyent en place · yl nyad que pati
hijC10.443 And he þat may al amende · haue mercy on vs alle
hijC10.443 · Nota · C10.446 Nemo bonusM10.452 For sothest worde þat euere god seyde · was þo he seyde nemo bonus

¶ Clergye þo of crystes mouth · commended was it litel
XL10.454 For he seyde to seynt Peter · and to suche as he loued
XL10.454 Matthew . xiCr3.10.451 Dum steteritis ante Reges et presides &c ·
XL10.454 Matthew . xiCr3.10.451 Math.xiCr2.10.453 Þough ȝe come bifor kynges · and clerkes of þe lawe
XL10.454 Matthew . xiCr3.10.451 Math.xiCr2.10.453 Beth nouȝte abasched · for I shal be in ȝoure mouthes
XL10.454 Matthew . xiCr3.10.451 Math.xiCr2.10.453 And ȝyue ȝow witte at wille · and kunnynge to conclude
XL10.454 Matthew . xiCr3.10.451 Math.xiCr2.10.453 Hem alle þat aȝeines ȝow · of crystenedome disputen

¶ Dauyd maketh mencioun · he spake amonges kynges
And miȝte no kynge ouercome hym · as bi kunnyng of speche
But witte ne wisdome · wan neuere þe maystrye
Whan man was at myschief · with-oute þe more grace

AugustinusC2.10.464 ¶ Þe doughtiest doctour · and deuynoure of þe trinitee
AugustinusC2.10.464 Was augustyn þe olde · and heighest of þe foure
AugustinusC2.10.464 Sayde þus in a sarmoun · I seigh it writen ones
AugustinusC2.10.464 Ecce ipsi idioti rapiunt celum · vbi nos sapientes in inferno mergimur ·

notaW10.471 ¶ Ne none sonner saued · ne sadder of bileue
notaW10.471 notaW10.472 Þan plowmen and pastoures · & pore comune laboreres
notaW10.471 notaW10.472 notaG11.472 notaW10.473 Souteres and sheperdes · suche lewed iottes

notaW10.471 notaW10.472 notaG11.472 notaW10.473 - notaW10.474 And passen purgatorie penaunceles · at her hennes-partyng
notaW10.471 notaW10.472 notaG11.472 notaW10.473 - notaW10.474 In-to þe blisse of paradys · for her pure byleue
notaW10.471 notaW10.472 notaG11.472 notaW10.473 - notaW10.474 Þat inparfitly here · knewe and eke lyued

¶ Ȝee men knowe clerkes · þat han cursed þe tyme
· nota · Þat euere þei couth or knewe more · þan credo in deum patrem
· nota · And pryncipaly her pater noster · many a persone hath wisshed

Passus undecimus


presensdauidsecretary hand Thanne scripture scorned me · and a skile tolde
presensdauidsecretary hand And lakked me in latyne · and liȝte by me she sette
presensdauidsecretary hand And seyde multi multa sciunt & seipsos nesciunt
presensdauidsecretary hand presens primesecretary hand Þo wepte I for wo · and wratth of her speche
presensdauidsecretary hand presens primesecretary hand your for me elin Bower Rondull wyllysecretary hand And in a wynkyng wratth · wex I aslepe
presensdauidsecretary hand presens primesecretary hand your for me elin Bower Rondull wyllysecretary hand A merueillouse meteles · mette me þanne
presensdauidsecretary hand presens primesecretary hand your for me elin Bower Rondull wyllysecretary hand fortune Þat I was rauisshed riȝt þere · and fortune me fette
presensdauidsecretary hand presens primesecretary hand your for me elin Bower Rondull wyllysecretary hand fortune And in-to þe londe of longynge · allone she me brouȝte
presensdauidsecretary hand presens primesecretary hand your for me elin Bower Rondull wyllysecretary hand fortune And in a myroure þat hiȝt mydlerd · she mad me to biholde
presensdauidsecretary hand presens primesecretary hand your for me elin Bower Rondull wyllysecretary hand fortune Sitthen she sayde to me · here myȝtow se wondres
presensdauidsecretary hand presens primesecretary hand your for me elin Bower Rondull wyllysecretary hand fortune And knowe þat þow coueytest · and come þer-to par-aunter

Of dam=sels of fortune ¶ Þanne hadde fortune folwyng hir two faire damoyseles
Of dam=sels of fortune Omne quod est in mundo aut estconcupiscentia carnis . Con-cupiscentia oculorum aut superbia vite The damsels of Fortune . Concupiscencia carnis · men called þe elder mayde
Of dam=sels of fortune Omne quod est in mundo aut estconcupiscentia carnis . Con-cupiscentia oculorum aut superbia vite The damsels of Fortune . And coueytise of eyes · ycalled was þat oþer
Of dam=sels of fortune Omne quod est in mundo aut estconcupiscentia carnis . Con-cupiscentia oculorum aut superbia vite The damsels of Fortune . Pryde of parfyte lyuynge · pursued hem bothe
Of dam=sels of fortune Omne quod est in mundo aut estconcupiscentia carnis . Con-cupiscentia oculorum aut superbia vite The damsels of Fortune . And badde me for my contenaunce · acounte clergye liȝte

¶ Concupiscencia carnis · colled me aboute þe nekke
nota And seyde þow art ȝonge and ȝepe · and hast ȝeres ynowe
nota nota For to lyue longe · and ladyes to louye
nota nota deusG12.20 And in þis myroure þow myȝte se · myrthes ful manye
nota nota deusG12.20 Þat leden þe wil to lykynge · al þi lyf-tyme

¶ Þe secounde seide þe same · I shal suwe þi wille
Til þow be a lorde and haue londe · leten þe I nelle
Þat I ne shal folwe þi felawship · if fortune it lyke
He shal fynde me his frende · quod fortune þer-after
nota Þe freke þat folwed my wille · failled neuere blisse

id est age ¶ Thanne was þere one þat hiȝte elde þat heuy was of chere
id est age Man quod he if I mete with þe · bi Marie of heuene
id est age Age, Þow shalt fynde fortune þe faille · at þi moste nede
id est age Age, And concupiscencia carnis · clene þe forsake
id est age Age, Bitterliche shaltow banne þanne · bothe dayes and niȝtes
id est age Age, Coueytise of eyghe · þat euere þow hir knewe
id est age Age, And pryde of parfyt lyuynge · to moche peril þe brynge

The counsel of Rechles # Recheles ¶ Ȝee recche þe neuere quod recchelesnes · stode forth in ragged clothes
The counsel of Rechles # Recheles Folwe forth þat fortune wole · þow hast wel · fer til elde
The counsel of Rechles # Recheles nota A man may stoupe tymes ynow · whan he shal tyne þe croune

¶ Homo proponit quod a poete · and plato he hyght
And deus disponit quod he · lat god done his wille
If trewthe wil witnesse it be wel do · fortune to folwe
Concupiscencia carnis · ne coueityse of eyes
Ne shal nouȝt greue þe gretly · ne bigyle þe but þow wolt

.id est. yowthGloss on Fauntelee ¶ Ȝee farewel phippe quod fauntelte and forth gan me drawe
.id est. yowthGloss on Fauntelee Til concupiscencia carnis · acorded alle my werkes

¶ Allas eye quod elde · and holynesse bothe
nota Þat witte shal torne to wrecchednesse · for wille to haue his lykyng

¶ Coueityse of eyghes · conforted me anon after
And folwed me fourty wynter · and a fyfte more
Þat of dowel ne dobet · no deyntee me ne þouȝte
I had no lykynge leue me if þe leste · of hem auȝte to knowe

¶ Coueytyse of eyes · cam ofter in mynde
Þan dowel or dobet amonge my dedes alle
nota Coueytise of eyes conforted me ofte
nota nota pro fratribus nota And seyde haue no conscience how þow come to gode
nota nota pro fratribus nota ffreris + nota Freris nota Go confesse to sum frere · and shewe hym þi synnes
nota nota pro fratribus nota ffreris + nota Freris nota # nota For whiles fortune is þi frende · Freres wil þe louye
nota nota pro fratribus nota ffreris + nota Freris nota # nota nota And fecche þe to her fraternite · and for þe biseke
nota nota pro fratribus nota ffreris + nota Freris nota # nota nota nota To her priour prouyncial · a pardoun forto haue
nota nota pro fratribus nota ffreris + nota Freris nota # nota nota nota nota And preyen for þe pol bi pol · ȝif þow be peccuniosus
nota nota pro fratribus nota ffreris + nota Freris nota # nota nota nota nota Set pena pecuniar[i]a non sufficit pro spiritualibus delictis

¶ By wissynge of þis wenche I wrouȝte · here wordes were so swete

notaL11.85 ¶ Ac a barne with-oute bapteme · may nouȝt so be saued
notaL11.85 Iohn.iii.Cr3.11.85. This note properly belongs to KD11.83. Nisi quis renatus fuerit loke ȝe lettred men · whether I lye or do nouȝte
notaL11.85 Iohn.iii.Cr3.11.85. This note properly belongs to KD11.83. And lewte loked on me · and I loured after
notaL11.85 Iohn.iii.Cr3.11.85. This note properly belongs to KD11.83. Wherfore lourestow quod lewte · and loked on me harde
notaL11.85 Iohn.iii.Cr3.11.85. This note properly belongs to KD11.83. Ȝif I durste quod I amonges men · þis meteles auowe
notaL11.85 Iohn.iii.Cr3.11.85. This note properly belongs to KD11.83. Ȝe bi peter and bi poule quod he · and take hem bothe to witnesse
notaL11.85 Iohn.iii.Cr3.11.85. This note properly belongs to KD11.83. Leuit.xixCr3.11.90 Non oderis fratres secrete in corde tuo · set publice argue illos

¶ Þei wol alleggen also quod I · and by þe gospel preuen
Rom.ii.Cr3.11.92 Nolite iudicare quemquam ·

¶ And wher-of serueth lawe quod lewte · if no lyf vndertoke it
Falsenesse ne faytrye · for sumwhat þe apostle seyde
Non oderis fratrem · and in þe sauter also seithe dauid þe prophete
Psal.115.Cr3.11.96 Existimasti inique quod ero tui similis &c
Psal.115.Cr3.11.96 notaW11.98 It is licitum for lewed men · to segge þe sothe
Psal.115.Cr3.11.96 notaW11.98 notaW11.99 If hem lyketh and leste · eche a lawe it graunteth
Psal.115.Cr3.11.96 notaW11.98 notaW11.99 notaW11.100 Excepte parsones and prestes · and prelates of holycherche
Psal.115.Cr3.11.96 notaW11.98 notaW11.99 notaW11.100 notaW11.101 It falleth nouȝte for þat folke · no tales to telle
Psal.115.Cr3.11.96 notaW11.98 notaW11.99 notaW11.100 notaW11.101 notaW11.102 Þough þe tale were trewe · and it touched synne

¶ Þinge þat al þe worlde wote · wherfore shuldestow spare
And reden it in Retoryke · to arate dedly synne
#M11.104 Ac be neuere-more þe fyrste · þe defaute to blame
#M11.104 Þouȝe þow se yuel sey it nouȝte fyrste · be sorye it nere amended
#M11.104 notaW11.107 No þinge þat is pryue · publice þow it neuere
#M11.104 notaW11.107 notaW11.108 Neyther for loue laude it nouȝt · ne lakke it for enuye
#M11.104 notaW11.107 notaW11.108 +L11.109 Parum lauda vitupera parcius

¶ He seith sothe quod scripture þo · and skipte an heigh & preched
Ac þe matere þat she meued · if lewed men it knewe
Þe lasse as I leue · louyen it þei wolde

multi sunt vocatiM11.112 ¶ This was her teme and her tyxte · I toke ful gode hede
multi sunt vocatiM11.112 Math.xx and.xxiiCr3.11.113 Multi to a maungerye · and to þe mete were sompned
multi sunt vocatiM11.112 Math.xx and.xxiiCr3.11.113 And whan þe peple was plenere comen · þe porter vnpynned þe ȝate
multi sunt vocatiM11.112 Math.xx and.xxiiCr3.11.113 Eccle,ii pauci vero electiM11.115 And plukked in pauci priueliche · and lete þe remenaunt go rowme

¶ Al for tene of her tyxte · trembled myn herte
And in a were gan I waxe · and with my-self to dispute
Whether I were chosen or nouȝt chosen · on holicherche I þouȝte
Þat vnderfonge me atte fonte · for one of goddis chosne
For cryste cleped vs alle · come if we wolde
Sarasenes and scismatikes · and so he dyd þe iewes
Esai.iv.Cr3.11.122 O vos omnes [si]cientes venite &c
Esai.iv.Cr3.11.122 And badde hem souke for synne · saufly at his breste
Esai.iv.Cr3.11.122 And drynke bote for bale · brouke it who-so myȝte

¶ And exciteth vs bi þe euangelye · þat when we maken festes
We shulde nouȝte clepe owre kynne þer-to · ne none kynnes riche
Cum facitis conuiuia nolite inuitare amicos

notaW11.189 ¶ Ac for þe pore I shal paye · and pure wel quyte her trauaille
notaW11.189 notaW11.190, KD11.197 not in W. Þat ȝiueth hem mete or moneye · and loueth hem for my sake

notaW11.191 For þe best ben somme riche · and somme beggers and pore
notaW11.191 notaW11.192 For alle are we crystes creatures · and of his coffres riche
notaW11.191 notaW11.192 notaW11.193 And bretheren as of o blode · as wel beggares as erles ·

notaW11.191 notaW11.192 notaW11.193 +L11.194 notaW11.194 no vileyn butt by SynM11.194 notaW11.195 notaW11.196 Ioh.viii.Cr3.11.196 Qui facit peccatum seruus est peccati &c

¶ In þe olde lawe · as holy lettre telleth
Mennes sones · men called vs vchone
Of adames issue and Eue · ay til god-man deyde
And after his resurreccioun · Redemptor was his name
And we his bretheren þourgh hym ybouȝt · bothe riche and pore
# quia Iocundum est habitare Fratres in vnumM11.203 notaW11.204 For-þi loue we as leue bretheren shal · and vche man laughe vp other
# quia Iocundum est habitare Fratres in vnumM11.203 notaW11.204 notaW11.205 And of þat eche man may forbere · amende þere it nedeth
# quia Iocundum est habitare Fratres in vnumM11.203 notaW11.204 notaW11.205 notaW11.206 And euery man helpe other · for hennes shal we alle

¶ Þanne is byleue a lele helpe aboue logyke or lawe
Logick and LawC2.11.217 Of logyke ne of lawe in legenda sanctorum
Logick and LawC2.11.217 Is litel allowaunce made · but if bileue hem helpe
Logick and LawC2.11.217 For it is ouerlonge ar logyke · any lessoun assoille
Logick and LawC2.11.217 nota legisM11.218 And lawe is loth to louye · but if he lacche syluer
Logick and LawC2.11.217 nota legisM11.218 Bothe logyke and lawe · þat loueth nouȝte to lye
Logick and LawC2.11.217 nota legisM11.218 I conseille alle crystene · cleue nouȝte þer-on to sore
Logick and LawC2.11.217 nota legisM11.218 For sum wordes I fynde ywryten · were of faithes techyng
Logick and LawC2.11.217 nota legisM11.218 Þat saued synful men · as seynt Iohan bereth wytnesse
Logick and LawC2.11.217 nota legisM11.218 Mat.vii.Cr3.11.222 Eadem mensura qua mensi fueritis remecietur vobis

notaW11.225 ¶ For-þi lerne we þe lawe of loue · as owre lorde tauȝte
notaW11.225 notaW11.226 And as seynte Gregory seide · for mannes soule helthe
notaW11.225 notaW11.226 Melius est scrutari scelera nostra · quam naturas rerum

¶ Why I moue þis matere ; is moste for þe pore
NotaC11.228 For in her lyknesse owre lorde · ofte hath ben yknowe
NotaC11.228 Witnesse in þe Paske-wyke · whan he ȝede to Emaus
NotaC11.228 Cleophas ne knewe hym nauȝte · þat he cryste were
NotaC11.228 For his pore paraille · and pylgrymes wedes
NotaC11.228 # quia in Fraccione panis cognouerunt eumM11.232 Tyl he blessed and brak · þe bred þat þei eten
NotaC11.228 # quia in Fraccione panis cognouerunt eumM11.232 So bi his werkes þei wisten · þat he was Ihesus
NotaC11.228 # quia in Fraccione panis cognouerunt eumM11.232 Ac by clothyng þei knewe hym nouȝte · ne bi carpynge of tonge

notaW11.236 ¶ And al was in ensample · to vs synful here
notaW11.236 notaW11.237 Þat we shulde be low · and loueliche of speche
notaW11.236 notaW11.237 · Nota · C11.237 in vestitum miletentioR11.248, fifteenth century hand notaW11.238 And apparaille vs nouȝte ouer-proudly · for pylgrymes ar we alle
notaW11.236 notaW11.237 · Nota · C11.237 in vestitum miletentioR11.248, fifteenth century hand notaW11.238 notaW11.239 And in þe apparaille of a pore man · and pilgrymes lyknesse
notaW11.236 notaW11.237 · Nota · C11.237 in vestitum miletentioR11.248, fifteenth century hand notaW11.238 notaW11.239 notaW11.240 Many tyme god hath ben mette · amonge nedy peple
notaW11.236 notaW11.237 · Nota · C11.237 in vestitum miletentioR11.248, fifteenth century hand notaW11.238 notaW11.239 notaW11.240 to punysh mR11.251, 15th century hand \ þeR11.251. Between R11.251-252 (KD11.245-246), Hand2 has tried to indicate an insertion point for þe in the previous line where the scribe had already written þe. Also Hand2 has drawn a tail on the original character's descender to make its identity more explicit. Apparently, he understood the scribe's form in line 251 (KD11.245) as ye and was attempting to fix it. notaW11.241 Þere neuere segge hym seigh · in secte of þe riche

pureO11.243. Because pore is accompanied by a solidus/punctus above, and marginal pure by a caret/punctus, it seems clear that substitution is intended. ¶ Seynt Iohan and other seyntes · were seyne in pore clothynge
pureO11.243. Because pore is accompanied by a solidus/punctus above, and marginal pure by a caret/punctus, it seems clear that substitution is intended. And as pore pilgrymes · preyed mennes godis
pureO11.243. Because pore is accompanied by a solidus/punctus above, and marginal pure by a caret/punctus, it seems clear that substitution is intended. · nota. · C11.243 Ihesu cryste on a iewes douȝter alyȝte · gentil woman þough she were
pureO11.243. Because pore is accompanied by a solidus/punctus above, and marginal pure by a caret/punctus, it seems clear that substitution is intended. · nota. · C11.243 To ponyshe me in shriftR11.255, secretary hand Was a pure pore mayde · and to a pore man wedded

XL11.296 notaW11.296 ¶ For made neuere no kynge no knyȝte · but he hadde catel to spende
XL11.296 notaW11.296 As bifel for a kniȝte · or fonde hym for his strengthe
XL11.296 notaW11.296 # a Careffull knyghtM11.297 notaW11.298 It is a careful knyȝte · and of a caytyue kynges makynge

¶ Þis lokynge on lewed prestes · haþ don me lepe fram pouerte
Þe whiche I preyse þere pacyence is · more parfyt þan ricchesse

¶ Resoune I seighe sothly suen alle bestes
In etyng in drynkynge · and in engendrynge of kynde
And after course of concepcioun · none toke kepe of other
As whan þei hadde ryde in rotey-tyme · anon riȝte þer-after
Males drowen hem to males · a-mornynges bi hem-self
+L11.344 And in euenynges also · [þ]e males fro femeles
+L11.344 Þere ne was cow ne cowkynde · þat conceyued hadde
+L11.344 Þat wolde belwe after boles · ne bore after sowe
+L11.344 Bothe horse and houndes · and alle other bestes
+L11.344 Medled nouȝte wyth here makes · þat with fole were

¶ Briddes I bihelde · þat in buskes made nestes
- C11.349 Hadde neuere wye witte · to worche þe leest
- C11.349 # pye NestM11.350 I hadde wonder at whom · and where þe pye lerned
- C11.349 # pye NestM11.350 To legge þe stykkes · in whiche she leythe and bredeth
- C11.349 # pye NestM11.350 Þere nys wriȝte as I wene · shulde worche hir neste to paye
- C11.349 # pye NestM11.350 If any masoun made a molde þer-to · moche wonder it were

¶ And ȝet me merueilled more · how many other briddes
Hudden and hileden · her egges ful derne
In mareys and mores · for men sholde hem nouȝt fynde
...?...M11.357, belonging to the line in M that corresponds to KD11.354b, 353b. Likely a guide for the addition of þai to the line. And hudden here egges · whan þei þere-fro wente
...?...M11.357, belonging to the line in M that corresponds to KD11.354b, 353b. Likely a guide for the addition of þai to the line. For fere of other foules · and for wylde bestis

¶ And some troden her makes · and on trees bredden
# concepcionem ByleM11.360 And brouȝten forth her bryddes so · al aboue þe grounde
# concepcionem ByleM11.360 And some bryddes at þe bille · þorwgh brethynge conceyued
# concepcionem ByleM11.360 And some kauked I toke kepe · how pekokes bredden
# concepcionem ByleM11.360 Moche merueilled me · what maister þei hadde
# concepcionem ByleM11.360 And who tauȝte hem on trees · to tymbre so heigh
# concepcionem ByleM11.360 Þere noither buirn ne beste · may her briddes rechen

¶ And sythen I loked vpon þe see · and so forth vpon þe sterres
Luk.xiii.Cr2.11.366 Many selcouthes I seygh · ben nought to seye nouthe

¶ I seigh floures in þe fritthe · and her faire coloures
And how amonge þe grene grasse · grewe so many hewes
+L11.371 And somme soure and some swete · selcouthe me þouȝte
+L11.371 Of her kynde and her coloure · to carpe it were to longe

¶ And resoun arated me · and seyde recche þe neuere

¶ Þe wyse and þe witty · wrote þus in þe bible

¶ And badde euery creature · in his kynde encrees
Al to murthe with man · þat most woo tholye
In fondynge of þe flesshe · and of þe fende bothe
For man was made of suche a matere · he may nouȝt wel astert
Þat ne some tymes hym bitit · to folwen his kynde
Catoun acordeth þere-with · nemo sine crimine viuit

¶ Tho cauȝte I coloure anon · and comsed to ben aschamed
And awaked þer-with · wo was me þanne
Þat I in meteles ne myȝte · more haue yknowen
And þanne seyde I to my-self · and chidde þat tyme
Now I wote what dowel is quod I · by dere god as me þinketh
And as I caste vp myn eyghen · one loked on me and axed
Of me what þinge it were · ywisse sire I seide
Do-WellC2.11.391 Septima discriptio de dowellM11.405 notaW11.406 To se moche and suffre more · certes quod I is dowel

¶ Haddestow suffred he seyde · slepyng þo þow were
Þow sholdest haue knowen þat clergye can · and conceiued more þorugh resoun
For resoun wolde haue reherced þe · riȝte as clergye saide
| C11.407 Ac for þine entermetyng · here artow forsake
| C11.407 Philosophus esses si tacuisses

notaW11.412 ¶ Adam w[h]iles he spak nouȝt · had paradys at wille
notaW11.412 notaW11.413 Ac whan he mameled aboute mete · and entermeted to knowe
notaW11.412 notaW11.413 notaW11.414 Þe wisdom and þe witte of god · he was put fram blisse
notaW11.412 notaW11.413 notaW11.414 And riȝt so ferde resoun bi the · þow with rude speche
notaW11.412 notaW11.413 notaW11.414 Lakkedest and losedest þinge · þat longed nouȝt to be done
notaW11.412 notaW11.413 notaW11.414 Þo hadde he no lykynge · forto lere þe more

¶ Pruide now and presumpcioun · par-auenture wole þe appele
That clergye þi compaignye · ne kepeth nouȝt to sue
notaW11.420 Shal neuere chalangynge ne chydynge · chaste a man so sone
notaW11.420 notaW11.421 As shal shame and shenden hym · and shape hym to amende

¶ Ȝe seggen soth quod I · ich haue yseyne it ofte
Þere smitte no þinge so smerte · ne smelleth so soure
+L11.430 As shame þere he sheweth him · for euery man hym shonyeth
+L11.430 Why ȝe wisse me þus quod I · was for I rebuked resoun

¶ Certes quod he þat is soth · and shope hym forto walken
And I aros vp riȝt with þat · and folwed hym after
And preyed hym of his curteisye · to telle me his name

Passus Duodecimus


I am ymagynatyf quod he · Idel was I neuere
Þouȝe I sitte bi my-self · in sikenesse ne in helthe
I haue folwed þe in feithe · þis fyue and fourty wyntre
And many tymes haue moeued þe · to þinke on þine ende
And how fele fernȝeres are faren · and so fewe to come
And of þi wylde wantounesse · þo þow ȝonge were
To amende it in þi myddel age · lest miȝte þe faylled
In þyne olde elde · þat yuel can suffre
Pouerte or penaunce · or preyeres bidde
Si non in prima vigilia · nec in secunda &c

¶ I seigh wel he sayde me soth · and somwhat me to excuse
Seid catoun conforted his sone · þat clerke þough he were
1 Iohn iiiCr2.12.25 To solacen hym sum-tyme · as I do whan I make
1 Iohn iiiCr2.12.25 Interpone tuis interdum gaudia curis · &c ·

Holy man vsed recreation,Cr3.12.27 ¶ And of holy men I herde quod I · how þei otherwhile
Holy man vsed recreation,Cr3.12.27 Pleyden þe parfiter · to be in many places
Holy man vsed recreation,Cr3.12.27 Ac if þere were any wight · þat wolde me telle
Holy man vsed recreation,Cr3.12.27 What were / dowel / and / dobet / · and dobest / atte laste
Holy man vsed recreation,Cr3.12.27 Wolde I neuere do werke · but wende to holicherche
Holy man vsed recreation,Cr3.12.27 And þere bydde my bedes · but whan ich eet or slepe

pilgrimageC2.12.40 ¶ Riȝt so if þow be Religious · renne þow neuere ferther
pilgrimageC2.12.40 - C12.41 To Rome ne to Rochemadore · but as þi reule techeth
pilgrimageC2.12.40 - C12.41 And holde þe vnder obedyence · þat heigh wey is to heuene

¶ And if þow be mayden to marye · and miȝte wel contynue
Seke þow neuere seynt forther · for no soule helthe
For what made Lucyfer · to lese þe heigh heuene
Or salamon his sapience · or sampson his strengthe
Iob þe Iewe his ioye · dere he it abouȝte
nota bene · C12.47 Arestotle and other mo · ypocras & virgyle
nota bene · C12.47 Alisaundre þat al wan · elengelich ended

¶ Catel and kynde witte · was combraunce to hem alle
Felyce hir fayrnesse · fel hir al to sklaundre
RosamondeC2.12.52 # Rosamondis BeauteM12.52 And Rosamounde riȝt so reufully bysette
RosamondeC2.12.52 # Rosamondis BeauteM12.52 Þe bewte of hir body · in badnesse she dispended

¶ And riche renkes riȝt so · gaderen and sparen
And þo men þat þei moste haten · mynistren it atte laste
And for þei suffren & se · so many nedy folkes
And loue hem nouȝt as owre lorde bytte · lesen her soules

¶ And ricchesse riȝt so · but if þe Rote be trewe

notaW12.92 ¶ For goddes body myȝte nouȝte be of bred · with-outen clergye
notaW12.92 Chrieste his bodyin SacramentoC2.12.93 notaW12.93 Þe which body is bothe · bote to þe riȝtful
notaW12.92 Chrieste his bodyin SacramentoC2.12.93 notaW12.93 notaW12.94 And deth and dampnacioun · to hem þat dyeth yuel

¶ For-þi lakke þow neuere logyke · lawe ne his custumes
· nota · C12.105 Ne countreplede clerkes · I conseille þe for eure
· nota · C12.105 notaW12.107 For as a man may nouȝt se · þat mysseth his eyghen
· nota · C12.105 notaW12.107 notaW12.108 Namore can no klerke · but if he cauȝt it first þorugh bokes
· nota · C12.105 notaW12.107 notaW12.108 notaW12.109 Al-þough men made bokes · god was þe maistre

- C12.120 ClergieC2.12.121 ¶ Archa dei in þe olde lawe · leuites it kepten
- C12.120 ClergieC2.12.121 Hadde neuere lewed man leue · to leggen honde on þat chest
- C12.120 ClergieC2.12.121 +L12.123 # quia in veteri testamento licitum erat presbiter procreare FiliosM12.123 But he were preste or prestes sone · patriarke or prophete

[¶ Saul for he sacrifised  sorwe hym be-tydde .KD12.116-125α are given here from R; they are lost in the beta tradition but annotated in R.
And his sones al-so  for þat synne myscheued .
And many mo other men  þat were no leuites .
Þat with archa dei ȝeden  in reuerence and in worchippe .
And leyden honde þeron to liften it vp  and loren her lif after .
For-þi I conseil alle creatures  no clergie to dispise .
notaR12.132 Ne sette schorte be here science  what-so þei don hem-selue .
notaR12.132 Take we her wordes at worthe  for here witnesse be trewe .
notaR12.132 And ne medle we nauȝt muche with hem  to meuen any wrathe .
notaR12.132 Lest cheste chasen vs  to choppe vche man other .
notaR12.132 Nolite tangere christos meos  &cetera .]

¶ For clergye is kepere vnder cryst of heuene
Was þere neuere no knyȝte · but clergye hym made
how kynde wyttis engendredC2.12.126 Ac kynde witte cometh of alkynnes siȝtes
how kynde wyttis engendredC2.12.126 Of bryddes and of bestes · of tastes of treuthe and of deceytes

...?...M11.128 ¶ Lyueres to-forn vs · vseden to marke
...?...M11.128 Þe selkouthes þat þei seighen · her sones for to teche
...?...M11.128 And helden it an heighe science · her wittes to knowe
...?...M11.128 Ac þorugh her science sothely · was neuere no soule ysaued
...?...M11.128 Ne brouȝte by her bokes · to blisse ne to ioye
...?...M11.128 For alle her kynde knowynges · come but of dyuerse sightes

¶ Patriarkes and prophetes · repreued her science
And seiden her wordes ne her wisdomes · nas but a folye
As to þe clergye of cryst · counted it but a trufle
notaW12.136 Sapiencia huius mundi · stulticia apud deum
notaW12.136 For þe heihe holigoste · heuene shal to-cleue
notaW12.136 And loue shal lepe out after · in-to þis lowe erthe
notaW12.136 And clennesse shal cacchen it · and clerkes shullen it fynde
notaW12.136 Luke.ii,Cr3.12.140 Pastores loquebantur ad inuicem

¶ He speketh þere of riche men riȝt nouȝt · ne of riȝt witty
Ne of lordes þat were lewed men · but of þe hexte lettred oute
Ibant magi ab oriente &c

Math.iiCr3.12.143 contra fratres molestus est ¶ If any frere were founde þere · Ich ȝif þe fyue shillynges
Math.iiCr3.12.143 contra fratres molestus est # quia non natus erat Cristus in diuersorio Ne in none beggares cote · was þat barne borne
Math.iiCr3.12.143 contra fratres molestus est # quia non natus erat Cristus in diuersorio But in a burgeys place · of bethlem þe best
Math.iiCr3.12.143 contra fratres molestus est # quia non natus erat Cristus in diuersorio Set non erat locus in diuersorio / & pauper non habet diuersorium

¶ To pastours and to poetes appiered þat aungel
Luke.ii,Cr3.12.147 And bad hem go to bethlem · goddis burth · to honoure
Luke.ii,Cr3.12.147 Luke.i And songe a songe of solas · gloria in excelsis deo

¶ Clerkes knewe it wel · and comen with here presentz
And deden her homage honourablely · to hym þat was almyȝty
Why I haue tolde al þis · I toke ful gode hede
How þow contraryedest clergye · with crabbed wordes
How þat lewed men liȝtloker · þan lettred were saued
[illegible characters, with legible "a" and partially legible ". .g . ll"]F9.278. may have been intended to identify the speaker (the he of l.270) with the angel of l.268. The text of this line in F is "& Clerkys / þan cleer wittyd men / of þe cristene peple." Þan clerkes or kynde-witted men · of crystene peple

¶ And þow seidest soth of somme · ac se in what manere
Similitudo # de duobus natatoribusM12.159 notaW12.158 Take two stronge men · and in themese caste hem
Similitudo # de duobus natatoribusM12.159 notaW12.158 Two men caste into Temmes .Cr3.12.159 notaW12.159 And bothe naked as a nedle · her none syker þan other

¶ Þat swymme can nouȝt I seide · it semeth to my wittes

XM12.169 ¶ Riȝt so quod þe Renke resoun it sheweth
XM12.169 notaW12.169 Þat he þat knoweth clergye can sonner aryse
XM12.169 notaW12.169 notaW12.170 Out of synne and be sauf · þough he synne ofte
XM12.169 notaW12.169 notaW12.170 # quod contricio delit peccatumM12.172 notaW12.171 If hym lyketh and lest · þan any lewed lelly
XM12.169 notaW12.169 notaW12.170 # quod contricio delit peccatumM12.172 notaW12.171 notaW12.172 For if þe clerke be konnynge · he knoweth what is synne

¶ And riȝt as troianus þe trewe knyȝt · tilde nouȝt depe in helle
Þat owre lorde ne had hym liȝtlich oute · so leue I þe thef be in heuene
For he is in þe lowest of heuene · if owre bileue be trewe
And wel loselyche he lolleth þere · by þe lawe of holycherche
Mat.xvi.Cr3.12.214 Quia reddit vnicuique iuxta opera sua &c

..M11.216 ¶ And why þat one thef on þe crosse · creaunt hym ȝelt
..M11.216 · nota · C12.217 Rather þan þat other thef · þough þow wolde appose
..M11.216 · nota · C12.217 Math xvi.Cr2.12.218 Alle þe clerkes vnder cryst · ne couthe þe skil assoille
..M11.216 · nota · C12.217 Math xvi.Cr2.12.218 Quare placuit quia voluit
..M11.216 · nota · C12.217 Math xvi.Cr2.12.218 And so I sey by þe · þat sekest after þe whyes
..M11.216 · nota · C12.217 Math xvi.Cr2.12.218 And aresonedest resoun · a rebukyng as it were
..M11.216 · nota · C12.217 Math xvi.Cr2.12.218 And of þe floures in þe fryth · and of her feire hewes
..M11.216 · nota · C12.217 Math xvi.Cr2.12.218 Where-of þei cacche her coloures · so clere and so briȝte
..M11.216 · nota · C12.217 Math xvi.Cr2.12.218 And willest of briddes and of bestes · and of hire bredyng to knowe
..M11.216 · nota · C12.217 Math xvi.Cr2.12.218 Why somme be alowe and somme alofte · þi lykyng it were
..M11.216 · nota · C12.217 Math xvi.Cr2.12.218 And of þe stones and of þe sterres · þow studyest as I leue
..M11.216 · nota · C12.217 Math xvi.Cr2.12.218 Onli god knoweth þe causes of thyngsCr3.12.226 How euere beste or brydde · hath so breme wittes

¶ Clergye ne kynde witte ne knewe neuere þe cause
# quia naturale scimusM12.229 Ac kynde knoweth þe cause hym-selue · no creature elles
# quia naturale scimusM12.229 He is þe pyes patroun · and putteth it in hire ere
# quia naturale scimusM12.229 Þat þere þe þorne is thikkest · to buylden and brede
# quia naturale scimusM12.229 And kynde kenned þe pecok · to cauken in swich a kynde
# quia naturale scimusM12.229 And kenned Adam · to knowe his pryue membres
# quia naturale scimusM12.229 And tauȝte hym and Eue · to hylien hem with leues

¶ Lewed men many tymes · maistres þei apposen

nota ¶ Riȝt so þe riche if he his ricchesse kepe
nota nota And deleth it nouȝt tyl his deth-day · þe taille of al sorwe
nota nota nota Riȝt as þe pennes of þe pecok · payned hym in his fliȝte
nota nota nota nota So is possessioun payne · of pens · and of nobles
nota nota nota nota nota To alle hem þat it holdeth · til her taille be plukked
nota nota nota nota nota And þough þe riche repente þanne · and birewe þe tyme
nota nota nota nota nota contra auaros & cupidosM12.254 Þat euere he gadered so grete · and gaf þere-of so litel
nota nota nota nota nota contra auaros & cupidosM12.254 Þough he crye to cryst þanne · with kene wille I leue
nota nota nota nota nota contra auaros & cupidosM12.254 +L12.256 His ledne be in owre lordes ere · lyke a pyes
nota nota nota nota nota contra auaros & cupidosM12.254 +L12.256 [A series of characters of the alphabet: a, b, c, d, e, f, I, g, h, i, m, n, o, p, ,etc.]S12.254 And whan his caroigne shal come · in caue to be buryed
