nota ¶ Þe larke þat is a lasse foule · is more louelich of ledne
nota nota And wel awey of wenge swifter þan þe pecok
nota nota nota And of flesch by fele-folde · fatter and swetter
nota nota nota nota To lowe-lybbyng men · þe larke is resembled ·

# quia de aristotile dubitatum vtrum saluaturM12.269 ¶ Arestotle þe grete clerke ; suche tales he telleth
nota · ¶ Thus he lykneth in his logyk · þe leste foule oute
nota · And where he be sauf or nouȝt sauf · þe sothe wote no clergye
nota · SortesSalomonC2.12.273 Ne of sortes ne of salamon · no scripture can telle
nota · SortesSalomonC2.12.273 Ac god is so good I hope · þat sitth he gaf hem wittis
nota · SortesSalomonC2.12.273 To wissen vs weyes þere-with · þat wissen vs to be saued
nota · SortesSalomonC2.12.273 And þe better for her bokes · to bidden we ben holden
nota · SortesSalomonC2.12.273 Þat god for his grace gyue her soules reste
nota · SortesSalomonC2.12.273 For lettred men were lewed men ȝut · ne were lore of her bokes

¶ Alle þise clerkes quod I þo · þat on cryst leuen
Seggen in her sarmones · þat noyther sarasenes ne iewes
Ne no creature of cristes lyknesse · with-outen crystendome worth saued

1i PeterCr2.12.281 ¶ Contra quod ymagynatyf þo · and comsed for to loure
1i PeterCr2.12.281 i.Pet.iiii And seyde saluabitur vix iustus in die iudicij

¶ Ergo saluabitur quod he · and seyde namore latyne
Troianus TroianusM12.284 # quia Troianus saluatur propter iusticiamM12.284, over erased "Trojanus" Troianus was a trewe knyȝte · and toke neuere cristendome
Troianus TroianusM12.284 # quia Troianus saluatur propter iusticiamM12.284, over erased "Trojanus" psal.xxiiiCr2.12.285 +L12.285 And he is sauf so seith þe boke · and his soule in heuene
Troianus TroianusM12.284 # quia Troianus saluatur propter iusticiamM12.284, over erased "Trojanus" psal.xxiiiCr2.12.285 +L12.285 Baptismus TriplexC2.12.287 For þere is fullyng of fonte · and fullyng in blode shedyng

Troianus TroianusM12.284 # quia Troianus saluatur propter iusticiamM12.284, over erased "Trojanus" psal.xxiiiCr2.12.285 +L12.285 Baptismus TriplexC2.12.287 Aduenit ignis diuinus non comburens sed illuminans &c ·

¶ Ac trewth þat trespassed neuere · ne transuersed aȝeines his lawe
Nota beneM12.290 But lyueth as his lawe techeth · and leueth þere be no bettere
Nota beneM12.290 And if þere were he wolde amende · and in suche wille deyeth
Nota beneM12.290 Ne wolde neuere trewe god · but treuth were allowed
Nota beneM12.290 And where it worth or worth nouȝt · þe bileue is grete of treuth
Nota beneM12.290 And an hope hangyng þer-inne · to haue a Mede for his treuth
Nota beneM12.290 Psa.xxiiiCr3.12.294 For deus dicitur quasi dans vitam eternam · suis hoc est fidelibus
Nota beneM12.290 Psa.xxiiiCr3.12.294 et alibi si ambulauero in medio vmbre mortis
Nota beneM12.290 Psa.xxiiiCr3.12.294 Þe glose graunteth vpon þat vers · a gret mede to treuthe
Nota beneM12.290 Psa.xxiiiCr3.12.294 And witt and wisdome quod þat wye · was somme-tyme tresore
Nota beneM12.290 Psa.xxiiiCr3.12.294 To kepe with a comune · no katel was holde bettere
Nota beneM12.290 Psa.xxiiiCr3.12.294 And moche murth and manhod · and riȝt with þat he vanesched

Passus terciodecimus


And I awaked þere-with · witles nerehande
And as a freke þat fre were · forth gan I walke
In manere of a mendynaunt · many a ȝere after
And of þis metyng many tyme · moche þouȝt I hadde
First how fortune me failled · at my moste nede
And how þat elde manaced me · myȝt we euere meten

ffreris nota contra fratres Freris ¶ And how þat freris folwed · folke þat was riche
ffreris nota contra fratres Freris And folke þat was pore · at litel prys þei sette
ffreris nota contra fratres Freris And no corps in her kirkeȝerde · ne in her kyrke was buryed
ffreris nota contra fratres Freris But quikke he biquethe hem auȝte · or shulde helpe quyte her dettes
ffreris nota contra fratres Freris Curatis vnlerned Curatis And how þis coueitise ouercome · clerkes and prestes
ffreris nota contra fratres Freris Curatis vnlerned Curatis # quia in defectis Curatoribus multi periunt ☜ And how þat lewed men ben ladde · but owre lorde hem helpe
ffreris nota contra fratres Freris Curatis vnlerned Curatis # quia in defectis Curatoribus multi periunt ☜ Þorugh vnkonnyng curatoures · to incurable peynes

- ¶ And how þat ymagynatyf · in dremeles me tolde
- Of kynde and of his connyng · and how curteise he is to bestes
- And how louynge he is to bestes · on londe and on water
- Leneth he no lyf · lasse ne more
- Þe creatures þat crepen · of kynde ben engendred
- And sitthen how ymagynatif seyde vix iustus saluabitur
- And whan he had seyde so · how sodeynelich he passed

¶ I lay down longe in þis þouȝte · and atte laste I slepte
Conscience And as cryste wolde þere come conscience · to conforte me þat tyme
Conscience And bad me come to his courte · with clergye sholde I dyne

¶ And for conscience of clergye spake · I come wel þe rather
And þere I say a maistre · what man he was I neste
Þat lowe louted · and loueliche to scripture

# conveuium consciencie ¶ Conscience knewe hym wel · and welcomed hym faire
# conveuium consciencie Þei wesshen and wypeden · and wenten to þe dyner
# conveuium consciencie pacience Ac pacience in þe paleis stode in pilgrymes clothes
# conveuium consciencie pacience And preyde mete for charite · for a pore heremyte

¶ Conscience called hym in · and curteisliche seide
Welcome wye go and wasshe · þow shalt sitte sone

¶ Þis maister was made sitte · as for þe moste worthy
And þanne clergye and conscience · and pacience cam after

¶ Pacience and I were put to be macches
And seten by owre-selue at a syde borde

Scripture ¶ Conscience called after mete · and þanne cam scripture
Scripture And serued hem þus sone · of sondry metes manye
Scripture Of austyn of ambrose · of alle þe foure euangelistes

+L13.48 Bifor pacience bred to brynge · and me þat was his macche
+L13.48 He sette a soure lof to-for vs · and seyde agite penitenciam

+L13.48 # diuersitatem ciborum ad Conuiuium ConsciencieM13.51 As longe quod I as I lyue · and lycame may dure
+L13.48 # diuersitatem ciborum ad Conuiuium ConsciencieM13.51 Here is propre seruice quod pacience · þer fareth no prynce bettere

psalm.iiCr2.13.62 ¶ Pacience was proude of þat propre seruice
psalm.iiCr2.13.62 And made hym muirth with his mete · ac I morned euere
psalm.iiCr2.13.62 For þis doctoure on þe heigh dese · dranke wyn so faste

· Nota · C13.74 ¶ Ac o worde þei ouerhuppen · at ech a tyme þat þei preche
· Nota · C13.74 Þat poule in his pistel · to al þe peple tolde
· Nota · C13.74 Periculum est in falsis fratribus
· Nota · C13.74 holywrit bit men be war · I wil nouȝt write it here
· Nota · C13.74 On englisch an auenture · it sholde be reherced to ofte
· Nota · C13.74 And greue þere-with þat good men ben · ac gramarienes shul rede

notaC2.13.82 ☞C2.13.82 Iocose loquitur & vera quidem dicitM13.80 +L13.87 # wynkyng off paciensM13.92 a good diuine,Cr3.13.92 - C13.96 Doctouris of ffrerisC2.13.98 Doctours of frerisO13.97 NotaC13.98 Of dowel and of dobet · and if dobest be any penaunce

¶ And I sete stille as pacience seyde · and þus sone þis doctour
As rody as a rose · rubbed his chekes
Coughed and carped · and conscience hym herde
And tolde hym of a trinite · and toward vs he loked

¶ What is dowel sire doctour quod I · is dowel any penaunce

nona discriptio de dowellM13.110 ¶ Dowel quod þis doctour · and toke þe cuppe and dranke
nona discriptio de dowellM13.110 Do non yuel to þine euenecrystene · nouȝt by þi powere

¶ By þis day sire doctour quod I þanne be ȝe nouȝt in dowel
For ȝe han harmed vs two · in þat ȝe eten þe puddyng
Mortrewes and other mete · and we no mussel hade
And if ȝe fare so in ȝowre fermorie · ferly me þinketh
- C13.117 But chest be þere charite shulde be · & ȝonge childern dorste pleyne
- C13.117 I wolde permute my penaunce with ȝowre · for I am in poynte to dowel

¶ Þanne conscience curteisliche · a contenaunce he made
- C13.120 And preynte vpon pacience · to preie me to be stille
- C13.120 And seyde hym-self sire doctour · and it be ȝowre wille
- C13.120 nota #F10.115, later hand. What is dowel and dobet · ȝe deuynours knoweth

Do-WellC2.13.124 decima discriptio de dowellM13.122. Arabic numeral "10" has been written 01, placing the numeral indicating units to the left of the numeral indicating tens. Treatises on computation instruct writers to begin writing numerals with the units and to proceed with the tens, hundreds, etc., moving, as Arabic scripts do, from right to left. The form here reflects that order of digits, but not that direction of the script. Cf. The Earliest Arithmetics in English, ed. Robert Steele. EETS ES 118, pp. 1-8. ¶ Dowel quod þis doctour · do as clerkes techeth
Do-WellC2.13.124 decima discriptio de dowellM13.122. Arabic numeral "10" has been written 01, placing the numeral indicating units to the left of the numeral indicating tens. Treatises on computation instruct writers to begin writing numerals with the units and to proceed with the tens, hundreds, etc., moving, as Arabic scripts do, from right to left. The form here reflects that order of digits, but not that direction of the script. Cf. The Earliest Arithmetics in English, ed. Robert Steele. EETS ES 118, pp. 1-8. Do-BettC2.13.125 doe well doe better doe bestL13.123 And dobet is he þat techeth · and trauailleth to teche other
Do-WellC2.13.124 decima discriptio de dowellM13.122. Arabic numeral "10" has been written 01, placing the numeral indicating units to the left of the numeral indicating tens. Treatises on computation instruct writers to begin writing numerals with the units and to proceed with the tens, hundreds, etc., moving, as Arabic scripts do, from right to left. The form here reflects that order of digits, but not that direction of the script. Cf. The Earliest Arithmetics in English, ed. Robert Steele. EETS ES 118, pp. 1-8. Do-BettC2.13.125 doe well doe better doe bestL13.123 · Nota · C13.125 hic qui facitY13.126, in blank line below KD13.118 And dobest doth hym-self so · as he seith & precheth
Do-WellC2.13.124 decima discriptio de dowellM13.122. Arabic numeral "10" has been written 01, placing the numeral indicating units to the left of the numeral indicating tens. Treatises on computation instruct writers to begin writing numerals with the units and to proceed with the tens, hundreds, etc., moving, as Arabic scripts do, from right to left. The form here reflects that order of digits, but not that direction of the script. Cf. The Earliest Arithmetics in English, ed. Robert Steele. EETS ES 118, pp. 1-8. Do-BettC2.13.125 doe well doe better doe bestL13.123 · Nota · C13.125 hic qui facitY13.126, in blank line below KD13.118 Do-BesteC2.13.127 Math iviCr2.13.125 Math.v.Cr3.13.123 NotaG14.126. The symbol expanded here as "Nota" corresponds to that found at G11.193, which Benson and Blanchfield interpret as "Nota." Qui facit et docuerit magnus vocabitur in regno celorum

Cleargye hath seuen sonnes, þat is the . vii sciences .Cr3.13.124 ¶ Now þow clergye quod conscience carpest what is dowel
Cleargye hath seuen sonnes, þat is the . vii sciences .Cr3.13.124 Nota beneM13.127 I haue seuene sones he seyde · seruen in a castel
Cleargye hath seuen sonnes, þat is the . vii sciences .Cr3.13.124 Nota beneM13.127 Þere þe lorde of lyf wonyeth · to leren hym what is dowel

¶ Til I se þo seuene · and my-self acorden
I am vnhardy quod he · to any wyȝt to preue it
For one pieres þe ploughman hath inpugned vs alle
piersM13.132, very faint. And sette alle sciences at a soppe · saue loue one
piersM13.132, very faint. And no tixte ne taketh to meyntene his cause
piersM13.132, very faint. Psa. xv.Cr3.13.132 But dilige deum · and domine quis habitabit &c
piersM13.132, very faint. Psa. xv.Cr3.13.132 And seith þat dowel and dobet aren two infinites
piersM13.132, very faint. Psa. xv.Cr3.13.132 psal.xvCr2.13.136 Whiche infinites with a feith fynden oute dobest
piersM13.132, very faint. Psa. xv.Cr3.13.132 psal.xvCr2.13.136 Which shal saue mannes soule · þus seith piers þe ploughman

¶ I can nouȝt her-on quod conscience · ac I knowe wel pieres
He wil nouȝt aȝein holy writ speken · I dar wel vndertake
Þanne passe we ouer til piers come · and preue þis in dede
Pacience hath be in many place · and par-auntre cnoweth
Þat no clerke ne can · as cryst bereth witnesse
Pacientes vincunt &c
Ac ȝowre preyere quod pacyence þo · so no man displese hym
disce / doce / et diligeL13.145 Disce quod he doce · dilige inimicos
disce / doce / et diligeL13.145 Disce and dowel · / doce / & dobet
disce / doce / et diligeL13.145 Dilige / and dobest · þus tauȝte me ones
disce / doce / et diligeL13.145 A lemman þat I loued · loue was hir name
disce / doce / et diligeL13.145 With wordes and with werkes quod she · and wille of þyne herte
disce / doce / et diligeL13.145 Þow loue lelly þi soule al þi lyf-tyme
disce / doce / et diligeL13.145 And so þow lere þe to louye · for þe lordes loue of heuene
disce / doce / et diligeL13.145 Þine enemye in al wyse · euene-forth with þi-selue
disce / doce / et diligeL13.145 Cast coles on his hed · and al kynde speche
disce / doce / et diligeL13.145 Bothe with werkes and with wordes fonde his loue to wynne
disce / doce / et diligeL13.145 And lay on hym þus with loue · til he laghe on þe
disce / doce / et diligeL13.145 - C13.157 And but he bowe for þis betyng blynde mote he worthe

contra quodM13.156 ¶ Ac for to fare þus with þi frende · foly it were
contra quodM13.156 For he þat loueth þe lelly · lyte of þyne coueiteth
contra quodM13.156 Kynde loue coueiteth nouȝte · no catel but speche

memorandumO13.161 ¶ I bere þere-inne aboute · fast ybounde dowel
memorandumO13.161 In a signe of þe saterday · þat sette firste þe kalendare
memorandumO13.161 solucioL13.163 # MisticumM13.162 And al þe witte of þe wednesday · of þe nexte wyke after
memorandumO13.161 solucioL13.163 # MisticumM13.162 Þe myddel of þe mone is þe miȝte of bothe
memorandumO13.161 solucioL13.163 # MisticumM13.162 And here-with am I welcome · þere I haue it with me

¶ Vndo it late þis doctour deme · if dowel be þer-inne
For bi hym þat me made · miȝte neuere pouerte
Miseise ne myschief ne man with his tonge
Colde ne care ne compaignye of theues
Ne noither hete ne haille · ne non helle pouke
Ne noither fuire ne flode · ne fere of þine enemy
Tene þe eny tyme · and þow take it with þe
i.Cor.xiiCr3.13.169 Caritas nichil timetHereafter follows 13.164-171α in KD, but they are not annotated.

¶ It is but a dido quod þis doctour · a dysoures tale
Al þe witt of þis worlde · and wiȝte mennes strengthe
Can nouȝt confourmen a pees · bytwene þe pope and his enemys
Ne bitwene two cristene kynges · can no wiȝte pees make
Profitable to ayther peple · and put þe table fro hym
And toke clergye and conscience · to conseille as it were
Þat pacience þo moste passe · for pilgrimes kunne wel lye

[poitning hand]F10.182, later hand ¶ Ac conscience carped loude and curteislich seide
[poitning hand]F10.182, later hand Frendes fareth wel · and faire spake to clergye
[poitning hand]F10.182, later hand - C13.184 Cleargye is loth þat Conscience should go withpatienceCr3.13.179 For I wil go with þis gome · if god wil ȝiue me grace
[poitning hand]F10.182, later hand - C13.184 Cleargye is loth þat Conscience should go withpatienceCr3.13.179 And be pilgryme with pacience · til I haue proued more

¶ What quod clergye to conscience · ar ȝe coueitouse nouthe
After ȝeresȝyues or ȝiftes · or ȝernen to rede redeles
I shal brynge ȝow a bible · a boke of þe olde lawe
And lere ȝow if ȝow lyke · þe leest poynte to knowe
Þat pacience þe pilgryme · parfitly knewe neuere

¶ Nay bi cryste quod conscience to clergye god þe forȝelde
For al þat pacience me profreth · proude am I litel
Ac þe wille of þe wye · and þe wille folke here
Hath moeued my mode · to mourne for my synnes
Goode WillC2.13.195 Þe good wille of a wiȝte · was neure bouȝte to þe fulle
Goode WillC2.13.195 For þere nys no tresore þerto · to a trewe wille

¶ Haued nouȝt Magdeleigne more · for a boxe of salue
Nota · C13.198 luke.xixCr2.13.196 Luke.xix,Cr3.13.193 Þan zacheus for he seide · dimidium bonorum meorum do pauperibus
Nota · C13.198 luke.xixCr2.13.196 Luke.xix,Cr3.13.193 And þe pore widwe for a peire of mytes

# how Consiens Conged the Frere M13.199 ¶ Þus curteislich conscience · congeyde fyrst þe Frere
# how Consiens Conged the Frere M13.199 And sithen softliche he seyde · in clergyes ere
# how Consiens Conged the Frere M13.199 Me were leuer by owre lorde · and I lyue shulde
# how Consiens Conged the Frere M13.199 Haue pacience parfitlich · þan half þi pakke of bokes

Patience passeth a packe of bokesCr3.13.200 ¶ Clergye to conscience · no congeye wolde take
Patience passeth a packe of bokesCr3.13.200 But seide ful sobreliche · þow shalt se þe tyme
Patience passeth a packe of bokesCr3.13.200 Concience . Clergy . andPacience . be able to makepees betwixte all kyngisC2.13.207 Whan þow art wery for-walked · wilne me to consaille

¶ Þat is soth seyde conscience · so me god helpe
# that paciens must be party Felow with ClergieM13.207 If pacience be owre partyng felawe · and pryue with vs bothe
# that paciens must be party Felow with ClergieM13.207 There nys wo in þis worlde · þat we ne shulde amende
# that paciens must be party Felow with ClergieM13.207 And confourmen Kynges to pees · and al-kynnes londes ·
# that paciens must be party Felow with ClergieM13.207 Sarasenes and surre · and so forth alle þe iewes ·
# that paciens must be party Felow with ClergieM13.207 Turne in-to þe trewe feith · and in-til one byleue

¶ Þat is soth quod clergye · I se what þow menest
I shal dwelle as I do · my deuore to shewen
And confermen fauntekynes · and other folke ylered
Tyl pacience haue preued þe · and parfite þe maked

¶ Conscience þo with pacience passed · pilgrymes as it were
# vitayles off paciens sobrete & soft spechM13.217 Þanne had pacience as pylgrymes han · in his poke vittailles
# vitayles off paciens sobrete & soft spechM13.217 Sobrete and symple speche · and sothfaste byleue
# vitayles off paciens sobrete & soft spechM13.217 To conforte hym and conscience · if þey come in place
# vitayles off paciens sobrete & soft spechM13.217 Þere vnkyndenesse and coueytise is · hungrye contrees bothe

¶ And as þei went by þe weye · of dowel þei carped
A loiterers lyfeCr3.13.219 Þei mette with a mynstral · as me þo þouȝte
A loiterers lyfeCr3.13.219 Pacience apposed hym fyrste · and preyed hym he sholde hem telle
A loiterers lyfeCr3.13.219 To conscience what crafte he couthe · an to what contree he wolde

¶ Beggeres and bidderes · of my bred crauen
Faitoures and freres · and folke with brode crounes
I fynde payne for þe pope · and prouendre for his palfrey
And I hadde neuere of hym · haue god my treuthe
Noither prouendre ne parsonage · ȝut of the popis ȝifte

¶ Ac if miȝte of miracle hym faille · it is for men ben nouȝt worthy
To haue þe grace of god · & no gylte of þe pope
For may no blyssyng done vs bote · but if we wil amende
Ne mannes masse make pees · amonges cristene peple
Tyl pruyde be purelich fordo · and þat þourgh payn defaute

¶ For ar I haue bred of mele · ofte mote I swete
Of þe dereyere . Cr1.13.267 And ar þe comune haue corne ynough · many a colde mornyng
Of þe dereyere . Cr1.13.267 So ar my wafres ben ywrouȝt · moche wo I tholye

—M13.275 ¶ I toke gode kepe by cryst · and conscience bothe
—M13.275 Of haukyn þe actyf man · and how he was yclothed
—M13.275 = C13.277 He hadde a cote of crystendome · as holykirke bileueth
—M13.275 = C13.277 Ac it was moled in many places · with many sondri plottes
—M13.275 = C13.277 Of pruyde here a plotte · and þere a plotte of vnboxome speche
—M13.275 = C13.277 Of scornyng and of scoffyng · and of vnskilful berynge
—M13.275 = C13.277 - C13.281 As in aparaille and in porte · proude amonges þe peple
—M13.275 = C13.277 - C13.281 Hypocrisye,Cr3.13.279 Otherwyse þan he hath · with herte or syȝte shewynge
—M13.275 = C13.277 - C13.281 Hypocrisye,Cr3.13.279 Hym willynge þat alle men wende · he were þat he is nouȝte
—M13.275 = C13.277 - C13.281 Hypocrisye,Cr3.13.279 For-why he bosteth and braggeth · with many bolde othes
—M13.275 = C13.277 - C13.281 Hypocrisye,Cr3.13.279 And in-obedient to ben vndernome · of any lyf lyuyng
—M13.275 = C13.277 - C13.281 Hypocrisye,Cr3.13.279 And so syngulere by hym-self · as to syȝte of þe poeple
—M13.275 = C13.277 - C13.281 Hypocrisye,Cr3.13.279 Was none suche as hym-self · ne none so pompe-holy

—M13.275 = C13.277 - C13.281 Hypocrisye,Cr3.13.279 Religion ofHeremytesC2.13.289 Lakkyng lettred men · and lewed men bothe
—M13.275 = C13.277 - C13.281 Hypocrisye,Cr3.13.279 Religion ofHeremytesC2.13.289 In lykyng of lele lyf · and a lyer in soule

¶ Baldest of beggeres a bostour þat nouȝt hath
In towne and in tauernes · tales to telle
And segge þinge þat he neuere seigh · and for soth sweren it
Of dedes þat he neuere dyd · demen and bosten
And of werkes þat he wel dyd · witnesse and seggen
Lo if ȝe leue me nouȝt · or þat I lye wenen
Axeth at hym or at hym · and he ȝow can telle
What I suffred and seighe · and some tymes hadde
And what I couth and knewe · and what kynne I come of
Gala iiCr2.13.307 Al he wolde þat men wiste of werkes and of wordes
Gala iiCr2.13.307 Which myȝte plese þe peple · and praysen hym-seluen
Gala iiCr2.13.307 Gala,i.Cr3.13.306 Si hominibus placerem cristi seruus non essem
Gala iiCr2.13.307 Gala,i.Cr3.13.306 Et alibi nemo potest duobus dominis seruire

¶ Bi criste quod conscience þo · þi best cote haukyn
Hath many moles and spottes · it moste ben ywassh

¶ Ȝe who-so toke hede quod haukyn · byhynde and bifore
What on bakke and what on bodyhalf · & by þe two sydes
Haukins garmente is foule .Cr3.13.311 Men sholde fynde many frounces · and many foule plottes

¶ And he torned hym as tyte · and þanne toke I hede
It was fouler by felefolde · þan it firste semed
It was bidropped with wratthe · and wikked wille
With enuye and yuel speche entysyng to fyȝte
Lyinge and laughynge · and leue tonge to chyde
Al þat he wist wykked · by any wiȝte tellen it
And blame men bihynde her bakke · and bydden hem meschaunce
And þat he wist bi wille · tellen it watte
And þat watte wiste · wille wiste it after
And made of frendes foes · þorugh a false tonge
Or with myȝte of mouthe or þorugh mannes strengthe
Auenge me fele tymes · other frete my-selue
Wyth-inne as a shepster shere · I-shrewed men & cursed
psal.xCr2.13.328 Psal.x,Cr3.13.325 Cuius maledictione os plenum est & amaritudine sub lingua eius labor & dolor
psal.xCr2.13.328 Psal.x,Cr3.13.325 & alibi filij hominum dentes eorum arma & sagitte & lingua eorum gladius acutus

¶ Þere is no lyf þat I louye · lastyng any while
For tales þat I telle · no man trusteth to me
notaM13.332 And whan I may nouȝt haue þe maistrye · with malencolye I take
notaM13.332 Þat I cacche þe crompe · þe cardiacle some-tyme
notaM13.332 - C13.355 Or an ague in suche an angre · and some-tyme a feure
notaM13.332 - C13.355 # quia contradicit wich CraftisM13.335 Þat taketh me al a twelf-moneth · tyl þat I dispyse
notaM13.332 - C13.355 # quia contradicit wich CraftisM13.335 +L13.339 Lechecrafte or owre lorde · and leue on a wicche
notaM13.332 - C13.355 # quia contradicit wich CraftisM13.335 +L13.339 And segge þat no clerke ne can · ne cryste as I leue

Besyloker ¶ I wayted wisloker · and þanne was it soiled
Besyloker With lykyng of lecherye · as by lokyng of his eye
Besyloker notaM13.343 For vche a mayde þat he mette · he made hir a signe
Besyloker notaM13.343 contra luxuriamM13.344 Semynge to synne-ward · and some-tyme he gan taste
Besyloker notaM13.343 contra luxuriamM13.344 Aboute þe mouth or bynethe · bygynneth to grope
Besyloker notaM13.343 contra luxuriamM13.344 Tyl eytheres wille waxeth kene · and to þe werke ȝeden
Besyloker notaM13.343 contra luxuriamM13.344 Yonge lechour old baude .Cr3.13.343. There is also a bracket? As wel in fastyng-days & frydayes · and forboden nyȝtes
Besyloker notaM13.343 contra luxuriamM13.344 Yonge lechour old baude .Cr3.13.343. There is also a bracket? And as wel in lente as oute of lente · alle tymes ylyche
Besyloker notaM13.343 contra luxuriamM13.344 Yonge lechour old baude .Cr3.13.343. There is also a bracket? Suche werkes with hem · was neuere oute of sesoun
Besyloker notaM13.343 contra luxuriamM13.344 Yonge lechour old baude .Cr3.13.343. There is also a bracket? Tyl þei myȝte namore · and þanne had merye tales
Besyloker notaM13.343 contra luxuriamM13.344 Yonge lechour old baude .Cr3.13.343. There is also a bracket? And how þat lechoures louyen · lauȝen an iapen
Besyloker notaM13.343 contra luxuriamM13.344 Yonge lechour old baude .Cr3.13.343. There is also a bracket? And of her harlotrye and horedome · in her elde tellen

The spottes of Haukins cote,Cr3.13.349 ¶ Thanne pacience parceyued of poyntes his cote
The spottes of Haukins cote,Cr3.13.349 - +L13.357 Was colmy þorw coueityse · and v[n]kynde desyrynge
The spottes of Haukins cote,Cr3.13.349 - +L13.357 xM13.355 More to good þan to god · þe gome his loue caste
The spottes of Haukins cote,Cr3.13.349 - +L13.357 xM13.355 And ymagyned how · he it myȝte haue
The spottes of Haukins cote,Cr3.13.349 - +L13.357 xM13.355 contra AuariciamM13.357 With false mesures and mette · and with false witnesse
The spottes of Haukins cote,Cr3.13.349 - +L13.357 xM13.355 contra AuariciamM13.357 Lened for loue of þe wedde · and loth to do treuthe
The spottes of Haukins cote,Cr3.13.349 - +L13.357 xM13.355 contra AuariciamM13.357 And awaited þorwgh which wey to bigile
The spottes of Haukins cote,Cr3.13.349 - +L13.357 xM13.355 contra AuariciamM13.357 And menged his marchaundyse · and made a gode moustre
The spottes of Haukins cote,Cr3.13.349 - +L13.357 xM13.355 contra AuariciamM13.357 Þe worste with-in was · a gret witte I lete hit
The spottes of Haukins cote,Cr3.13.349 - +L13.357 xM13.355 contra AuariciamM13.357 And if my neighbore had any hyne · or any beste elles
The spottes of Haukins cote,Cr3.13.349 - +L13.357 xM13.355 contra AuariciamM13.357 More profitable þan myne · many sleightes I made
The spottes of Haukins cote,Cr3.13.349 - +L13.357 xM13.355 contra AuariciamM13.357 How I myȝte haue it · al my witte I caste
The spottes of Haukins cote,Cr3.13.349 - +L13.357 xM13.355 contra AuariciamM13.357 And but I it had by other waye · atte laste I stale it
The spottes of Haukins cote,Cr3.13.349 - +L13.357 xM13.355 contra AuariciamM13.357 Or pryuiliche his purse shoke · vnpiked his lokkes
The spottes of Haukins cote,Cr3.13.349 - +L13.357 xM13.355 contra AuariciamM13.357 Or by nyȝt or by day · aboute was ich euere
The spottes of Haukins cote,Cr3.13.349 - +L13.357 xM13.355 contra AuariciamM13.357 Þorwgh gyle to gadren þe good þat ich haue

¶ Ȝif I ȝede to þe plow · I pynched so narwe
Þat a fote londe or a forwe · fecchen I wolde
Of my nexte neighbore · nymen of his erthe
+L13.375 And if [I] rope ouer-reche · or ȝaf hem red þat ropen
+L13.375 To seise to me with her sykel · þat I ne sewe neure

¶ And who-so borweth of me · aboute þe tyme
With presentes priueliche · or payed somme certeyne
woldeY13.381, corrects "nolde" in line So walde he or nouȝt wolde he · wynnen I wolde
woldeY13.381, corrects "nolde" in line And bothe to kyth and to kyn · vnkynde of þat ich hadde

The Image of a worldlingCr3.13.374 ¶ And who-so cheped my chaffare · chiden I wolde
The Image of a worldlingCr3.13.374 But he profred to paye · a peny or tweyne
The Image of a worldlingCr3.13.374 More þan it was worth · and ȝet wolde I swere
The Image of a worldlingCr3.13.374 Þat it coste me moche more · swore manye othes

¶ In halydayes at holicherche · whan ich herde masse
+L13.386 Hadde neuere wille wot god · witterly to biseche
+L13.386 Mercye for my mysdedes · þat I ne morned more
+L13.386 For losse of gode leue me · þan for my lykames giltes
+L13.386 As if I had dedly synne done · I dred nouȝt þat so sore
+L13.386 As when I lened and leued it lost · or longe ar it were payed
+L13.386 So if I kydde any kyndenesse · myn euen-cristene to helpe
+L13.386 Vpon a cruel coueityse · myn herte gan hange
+L13.386 And if I sent ouer-see · my seruauntz to Bruges
+L13.386 Or in-to Pruslonde my prentys · my profit to wayten
+L13.386 To marchaunden with monoye · and maken her eschaunges
+L13.386 Miȝte neuere me conforte · in þe mene-tyme
+L13.386 Noither messe ne matynes · ne none manere siȝtes
+L13.386 Ne neuere penaunce perfourned · ne pater noster seyde
+L13.386 Þat my mynde ne was more · on my gode in a doute
+L13.386 Þan in þe grace of god · and his grete helpes
+L13.386 Math,vii.Cr2.13.396 Math.viCr3.13.394 Vbi thesaurus tuus · ibi & cor tuumHereafter follow 13.399-408 in KD, from alpha, but they are not annotated.

¶ Ac flateres and foles þorw her foule wordes
Leden þo þat louen hem · to luciferes feste
With turpiloquio a lay of sorwe · and luciferes fithele
Thus haukyn þe actyf man · hadde ysoiled his cote
Til conscience acouped hym þere-of · in a curteise manere
Whi he ne hadde wasshen it · or wyped it with a brusshe

Passus quartus decimus


I Haue but one hatere quod haukyn · I am þe lasse to blame
Þough it be soiled and selde clene · I slepe þere-inne on niȝtes
And also I haue an houswyf · hewen and children
Luk.xiiiiCr3.14.4 Vxorem duxy & ideo non possum venire
Luk.xiiiiCr3.14.4 Þat wolen bymolen it many tyme · maugre my chekes

Haukins cote wyll not be cleane .Cr3.14.6 ¶ It hath ben laued in lente · and oute of lente bothe
Haukins cote wyll not be cleane .Cr3.14.6 With þe sope of sykenesse · þat seketh wonder depe
Haukins cote wyll not be cleane .Cr3.14.6 And with þe losse of catel · loth forto agulte
Haukins cote wyll not be cleane .Cr3.14.6 God or any gode man · bi auȝte þat I wiste
Haukins cote wyll not be cleane .Cr3.14.6 And was shryuen of þe preste · þat gaue me for my synnes
Haukins cote wyll not be cleane .Cr3.14.6 To penaunce pacyence · and pore men to fede
Haukins cote wyll not be cleane .Cr3.14.6 Al for coueitise of my crystenedome · in clennesse to kepen it

XF10.488, 7 lines high # quia difficile est sane viuereM14.13 Þat I ne soiled it with syȝte · or sum ydel speche
XF10.488, 7 lines high # quia difficile est sane viuereM14.13 Or þorugh werke or þorugh worde · or wille of myn herte
XF10.488, 7 lines high # quia difficile est sane viuereM14.13 Þat I ne flober it foule · fro morwe tyl eue

¶ Þanne laughed haukyn a litel · and liȝtly gan swerye
Who-so leueth ȝow by owre lorde · I leue nouȝte he be blissed

God geueth not lyfe, but he prouideth fode.Cr3.14.41 # vitells off paciensM14.42 ¶ No quod pacyence paciently · and out of his poke hente
God geueth not lyfe, but he prouideth fode.Cr3.14.41 # vitells off paciensM14.42 Vitailles of grete vertues · for al manere bestes
God geueth not lyfe, but he prouideth fode.Cr3.14.41 # vitells off paciensM14.42 And seyde lo here lyflode ynough · if owre byleue be trewe
God geueth not lyfe, but he prouideth fode.Cr3.14.41 # vitells off paciensM14.42 For lente neuere was lyf · but lyflode were shapen
God geueth not lyfe, but he prouideth fode.Cr3.14.41 # vitells off paciensM14.42 Wher-of or wherfore · or where-by to lybbe

of wylfull povertiL14.46 ¶ Firste þe wylde worme · vnder weet erthe
of wylfull povertiL14.46 - C14.47 Fissch to lyue in þe flode · and in þe fyre þe crykat
of wylfull povertiL14.46 - C14.47 The CurlewC2.14.48 Þe corlue by kynde of þe eyre · moste clennest flesch of bryddes
of wylfull povertiL14.46 - C14.47 The CurlewC2.14.48 And bestes by grasse and by greyne · and by grene rotis

fiat voluntasM14.55 ¶ But I loked what lyflode it was · þat pacience so preysed
fiat voluntasM14.55 And þanne was it a pece of þe pater noster · fiat voluntas tua ·

¶M14.57 ¶ Haue haukyn quod pacyence · and ete þis whan þe hungreth
¶M14.57 Or whan þow clomsest for colde · or clyngest for drye
¶M14.57 Shal neuere gyues þe greue · ne grete lordes wrath
¶M14.57 Prisone ne peyne · for pacientes vincunt
¶M14.57 - C14.59 fereS14.58 ¶ Bi so þat þow be sobre · of syȝte and of tonge
¶M14.57 - C14.59 fereS14.58 In etynge and in handlyng · and in alle þi fyue wittis

¶M14.57 - C14.59 fereS14.58 | - C14.61 Ne for drynke ne deth drede · but deye as god lyketh

¶ And lyueden with-oute lyflode · and atte laste þei woken
And if men lyued as mesure wolde · shulde neuere-more be defaute
Lacke of measure is cause of scarcitie .Cr3.14.79. There is also a bracket? Amonges cristene creatures · if crystes wordes ben trewe

Lacke of measure is cause of scarcitie .Cr3.14.79. There is also a bracket? And ouer-plente maketh pruyde · amonges pore & riche
Lacke of measure is cause of scarcitie .Cr3.14.79. There is also a bracket? Ac mesure is so moche worth · it may nouȝte be to dere

Where is chariteO14.106. Four ticks follow. ¶ Where woneth charite quod haukyn · I wiste neuere in my lyue
Where is chariteO14.106. Four ticks follow. Man þat with hym spake · as wyde as I haue passed

¶ Þere parfit treuthe and pouere herte is · and pacience of tonge
Þere is charitee þe chief chaumbrere for god hym-selue

¶ Ȝe quis est ille quod pacience · quik laudabimus eum
# terribile hocM14.115 Þough men rede of richchesse · riȝt to þe worldes ende
# terribile hocM14.115 · Nota · C14.113 I wist neuere renke þat riche was · þat whan he rekne sholde
# terribile hocM14.115 · Nota · C14.113 Whan it drow to his deth-day · þat he ne dred hym sore
# terribile hocM14.115 · Nota · C14.113 And þat atte rekenyng in arrerage fel · rather þan oute of dette

¶ There þe pore dar plede · and preue by pure resoun
To haue allowaunce of his lorde · by þe lawe he it cleymeth
Ioye þat neuere ioye hadde · of riȝtful iugge he axeth
And seith lo briddes and bestes · þat no blisse ne knoweth
And wilde wormes in wodes · þorw wyntres þow hem greuest
And makest hem welnyegh meke · and mylde for defaute
And after þow sendest hem somer · þat is her souereigne Ioye
MordounM14.126. See also M20.163 (KD20.164). And blisse to alle þat ben · bothe wilde and tame
MordounM14.126. See also M20.163 (KD20.164). Þanne may beggeres as bestes · after bote waiten
MordounM14.126. See also M20.163 (KD20.164). Neuer creature was with out ioye here and hence to.Cr3.14.126 Þat al her lyf han lyued · in langour and in defaute
MordounM14.126. See also M20.163 (KD20.164). Neuer creature was with out ioye here and hence to.Cr3.14.126 But god sent hem some-tyme · some manere ioye

¶ Ac god is of a wonder wille · by þat kynde witte sheweth
Nota · C14.134 To ȝiue many men his mercymonye · ar he it haue deserued
Nota · C14.134 Riȝt so fareth god by some riche · reuthe me it þinketh

¶ Ac pore peple þi prisoneres · lorde in þe put of myschief
Conforte þo creatures · þat moche care suffren
+L14.188 Þorw derth þorw drouth · alle her dayes here
+L14.188 Wo in wynter tymes · for wantyng of clothes
+L14.188 And in somer tyme selde · soupen to þe fulle
+L14.188 +L14.191 Conforte þi careful cryst in þi ryche
+L14.188 +L14.191 For how þow confortest · alle creatures ; clerkes bereth witnesse
+L14.188 +L14.191 · Nota · C14.192 Esa.xiv.Cr2.14.? Esai.xlv.Cr3.14.190 Conuertimini ad me & salui eritis

¶ Þus in genere of his genitrice · Ihesu cryst seyde
To robberes and to reueres · to riche and to pore
Þow tauȝtest hem in þe Trinitee · to take baptesme
+L14.197 And be clene þorw þat crystennynge · of alle kynnes [sinnes]
+L14.197 And vs fel þorw folye · to falle in synne after
+L14.197 +L14.199 Confessioun and kn[o]wlechyng & crauyng þi mercy
+L14.197 +L14.199 Shulde amende vs as many sithes · as man wolde desire
+L14.197 +L14.199 Ac if þe pope wolde plede here-aȝeine · and punyssh vs in conscience
+L14.197 +L14.199 A christen mans patente.Cr3.14.200 He shulde take þe acquitance as quik · and to þe qued schewe it
+L14.197 +L14.199 A christen mans patente.Cr3.14.200 Pateat &c per passionem domini

+L14.197 +L14.199 A christen mans patente.Cr3.14.200 nota beneM14.205 Ac þe perchemyn of þis patent · of pouerte be moste

+L14.197 +L14.199 A christen mans patente.Cr3.14.200 nota beneM14.205 paupertas SpiritusC2.14.207 - C14.212 For-þi crystene sholde ben in comune riche · none coueitouse for hym-selue

¶ For seuene synnes þat þere ben · assaillen vs euere
Þe fende folweth hem alle · and fondeth hem to helpe
# quia per diuicias cicius FallimurM14.218 Ac wiþ ricchesse þat Ribaude · rathest men bigyleth
# quia per diuicias cicius FallimurM14.218 For þere þat richesse regneth · reuerence folweth
# quia per diuicias cicius FallimurM14.218 And þat is plesaunte to pryde · in pore and in riche
# quia per diuicias cicius FallimurM14.218 And þe riche is reuerenced · by resoun of his richchesse
# quia per diuicias cicius FallimurM14.218 Þere þe pore is put bihynde and par-auenture can more
# quia per diuicias cicius FallimurM14.218 Of witte and of wysdom · þat fer awey is better
# quia per diuicias cicius FallimurM14.218 - C14.222 Þan ricchesse or reaute · and rather yherde in heuene
# quia per diuicias cicius FallimurM14.218 - C14.222 For þe riche hath moche to rekene · and riȝte softe walketh
# quia per diuicias cicius FallimurM14.218 - C14.222 Þe heigh waye to heuene-ward · oft ricchesse letteth
# quia per diuicias cicius FallimurM14.218 - C14.222 Ita possibile diuiti &c

# Audaciam paupertatis with a pak at his ruggeM14.228 ¶ Þere þe pore preseth bifor þe riche · with a pakke at his rugge
# Audaciam paupertatis with a pak at his ruggeM14.228 Apo.xiiii.Cr2.14.? Apo.xiiiiCr3.14.225 Opera enim illorum sequntur illos
# Audaciam paupertatis with a pak at his ruggeM14.228 Apo.xiiii.Cr2.14.? Apo.xiiiiCr3.14.225 Batauntliche as beggeres done · and baldeliche he craueth
# Audaciam paupertatis with a pak at his ruggeM14.228 Apo.xiiii.Cr2.14.? Apo.xiiiiCr3.14.225 For his pouerte and his pacience · a perpetuel blisse
# Audaciam paupertatis with a pak at his ruggeM14.228 Apo.xiiii.Cr2.14.? Apo.xiiiiCr3.14.225 Luke. viCr2.14.? Luke.viCr3.14.228 Beati pauperes · quoniam ipsorum est regnum celorum

¶ And pryde in ricchesse regneth · rather þan in pouerte
- C14.232 Arst in þe Maister þan in þe man · some mansioun he hath
- C14.232 Ac in pouerte þere pacyence is · pryde hath no myȝte
- C14.232 Ne none of þe seuene synnes · sitten ne mowe þere longe
- C14.232 pouertie with pacienceC2.14.235 Ne haue powere in pouerte · if pacyence it folwe
- C14.232 pouertie with pacienceC2.14.235 For þe pore is ay prest · to plese þe riche
- C14.232 pouertie with pacienceC2.14.235 And buxome at his byddyng · for his broke loues
- C14.232 pouertie with pacienceC2.14.235 # Buxom & bost be euer at werreM14.240 And buxomenesse and boste · aren euer-more at werre
- C14.232 pouertie with pacienceC2.14.235 # Buxom & bost be euer at werreM14.240 And ayther hateth other · in alle manere werkes
- C14.232 pouertie with pacienceC2.14.235 # Buxom & bost be euer at werreM14.240 If wratthe wrastel with þe pore · he hath þe worse ende
- C14.232 pouertie with pacienceC2.14.235 # Buxom & bost be euer at werreM14.240 For if þey bothe pleyne · þe pore is but fieble
- C14.232 pouertie with pacienceC2.14.235 # Buxom & bost be euer at werreM14.240 And if he chyde or chatre · hym chieueth þe worseHereafter follow 14.228-238 in KD from alpha, but they are no annotated.

¶ And if coueitise wolde cacche þe pore · þei may nouȝt come togideres
And by þe nekke namely · her none may hente other
For men knoweth wel þat coueitise · is of a kene wille
And hath hondes and armes · of a longe lengthe
id est vmbilicus · L14.248 And pouerte nis but a petit þinge · appereth nouȝt to his naule
id est vmbilicus · L14.248 # layke bytwen long & shortM14.250 And louely layke was it neuere · bitwene þe longe and þe shorte
id est vmbilicus · L14.248 # layke bytwen long & shortM14.250 And þough auarice wolde angre þe pore · he hath but litel myȝte
id est vmbilicus · L14.248 # layke bytwen long & shortM14.250 For pouerte hath but pokes · to putten in his godis
id est vmbilicus · L14.248 # layke bytwen long & shortM14.250 Þere auarice hath almaries · and yren-bounde coffres
id est vmbilicus · L14.248 # layke bytwen long & shortM14.250 And whether be liȝter to breke · lasse boste it maketh
id est vmbilicus · L14.248 # layke bytwen long & shortM14.250 A beggeres bagge · þan an yren-bounde coffre

Lecherye and glotony raigne not much in pouertye ¶ Lecherye loueth hym nouȝt · for he ȝeueth but lytel syluer
Lecherye and glotony raigne not much in pouertye Ne doth hym nouȝte dyne delycatly · ne drynke wyn oft
Lecherye and glotony raigne not much in pouertye # stewes sydeM14.258 A strawe for þe stuwes · it stode nouȝt I trowe
Lecherye and glotony raigne not much in pouertye # stewes sydeM14.258 Had þei none but of pore men · her houses were vntyled

¶ And þough sleuthe suwe pouerte · and serue nouȝt god to paye
Mischief is his maister · and maketh hym to thynke
id est gome C14.260 Þat god is his grettest helpe · and no gome elles
id est gome C14.260 And his seruaunt as he seith · and of his sute bothe
id est gome C14.260 And where he be or be nouȝte · he bereth þe signe of pouerte
id est gome C14.260 And in þat secte owre saueoure · saued al mankynde
id est gome C14.260 For-thi al pore þat paciente is · may claymen and asken
id est gome C14.260 After her endynge here · heuene-riche blisse

¶ Moche hardier may he axen · þat here myȝte haue his wille
Wylfull pouertye . In londe and in lordship · and likynge of bodye
Wylfull pouertye . +L14.269 nota/L14.269 And for goddis loue leueth al · an lyueth as a beggere
Wylfull pouertye . +L14.269 nota/L14.269 And as a mayde for mannes loue · her moder forsaketh
Wylfull pouertye . +L14.269 nota/L14.269 # quia puella dimittit patrem & matrem pro viro suoM14.272 Hir fader and alle her frendes · and folweth hir make
Wylfull pouertye . +L14.269 nota/L14.269 # quia puella dimittit patrem & matrem pro viro suoM14.272 Moche is suche a mayde to louie · of hym þat such one taketh
Wylfull pouertye . +L14.269 nota/L14.269 # quia puella dimittit patrem & matrem pro viro suoM14.272 More þan a mayden is · þat is maried þorw brokage
Wylfull pouertye . +L14.269 nota/L14.269 # quia puella dimittit patrem & matrem pro viro suoM14.272 As bi assent of sondry partyes · and syluer to bote
Wylfull pouertye . +L14.269 nota/L14.269 # quia puella dimittit patrem & matrem pro viro suoM14.272 More for coueitise of good · þan kynde loue of bothe

¶ So it fareth bi eche a persone · þat possessioun forsaketh
And put hym to be pacient · and pouerte weddeth
Paupertas .O14.277. This word is preceded by a parasign two lines in height, touched in red, and decorated with a flourish at the right and vertical slashes beneath. It may have been intended as a heading for O14.280 (KD14.276), since it appears over that portion of the line that extends into the right margin. Þe which is sybbe to god hym-self · and so to his seyntes

¶ Haue god my trouthe quod Haukyn · ȝe preyse faste pouerte
What is pouerte with pacience quod he · proprely to mene

¶ Paupertas quod pacience · est odibile bonum
definitio pauper=tatis cum patientiaL14.282 # discripcionem paupertatisM14.282 Remocio curarum · possessio sine calumpnia · donum dei · sanitatis mater
definitio pauper=tatis cum patientiaL14.282 # discripcionem paupertatisM14.282 Absque solicitudine semita · sapiencie temperatrix · negocium sine dampno
definitio pauper=tatis cum patientiaL14.282 # discripcionem paupertatisM14.282 Incerta fortuna · absque solicitudine felicitas ·

¶ I can nouȝt construe al þis quod haukyn · ȝe moste kenne þis on englisch
In englisch quod pacyence it is wel harde · wel to expounen
Ac somdel I shal seyne it ; by so þow vnderstonde
Pouerte is þe first poynte · þat pryde moste hateth
Thanne is it good by good skil · al þat agasteth pryde
- C14.286 Riȝte as contricioun is confortable þinge · conscience wote wel
- C14.286 And a sorwe of hym-self · and a solace to þe sowle
- C14.286 The praise of pouerty So pouerte propreliche penaunce and ioye
- C14.286 The praise of pouerty Is to þe body pure spiritual helthe
- C14.286 The praise of pouerty Ergo paupertas est odibile bonum
- C14.286 The praise of pouerty .1.F10.762, marks first of "solaces" in text. And contricioun confort & cura animarum

¶ Selde sitte pouerte · þe sothe to declare
Or as iustyce to iugge men · enioigned is no pore
Ne to be a Maire aboue men · ne mynystre vnder kynges
Selden is any pore yput · to punysshen any peple
Remocio curarum
Ergo pouerte and pore men · parfornen þe comaundement
Nolite iudicare quemquam þe þridde

¶ Selde is any pore riche · but of riȝtful heritage
.2.F10.770, marks second of "solaces" Wynneth he nauȝt with weghtes fals · ne with vnseled mesures
.2.F10.770, marks second of "solaces" Ne borweth of his neghbores · but þat he may wel paye
.2.F10.770, marks second of "solaces" Possessio sine calumpnia ·

¶ Þe fierthe is a fortune · þat florissheth þe soule
Wyth sobrete fram al synne · and also ȝit more
- C14.305 ..M14.307, perhaps a ¶ It affaiteth þe flesshe · fram folyes ful manye
- C14.305 ..M14.307, perhaps a ¶ A collateral conforte · crystes owne ȝifte
- C14.305 ..M14.307, perhaps a ¶ Donum dei

¶M14.310 ¶ Þe fyfte is moder of helthe a frende in alle fondynges
¶M14.310 And for þe land euere a leche · a lemman of al clennesse
¶M14.310 Sanitatis mater

¶ Þe sexte is a path of pees · ȝe þorw þe pas of altoun
Pouerte myȝte passe · with-oute peril of robbyng
For þere þat pouerte passeth · pees folweth after
And euere þe lasse þat he bereth · þe hardyer he is of herte
For-þi seith seneca · paupertas est absque solicitudine semita
And an hardy man of herte · amonge an hepe of þeues
Cantabit paupertas coram latrone viator

¶ Þe seueneth is welle of wisdome · and fewe wordes sheweth
For lordes alloweth hym litel · or lysteneth to his reson
He tempreth þe tonge to treuthe-ward · and no tresore coueiteth
Sapiencie temperatrix

¶ The eigteth is a lele laborere · and loth to take more
Þan he may wel deserue · in somer or in wynter
+L14.328 And if [he] chaffareth he chargeth no losse · mowe he charite wynne
+L14.328 Negocium sine dampno

Patience tedeth pouertye .Cr3.14.322 ¶ The nyneth is swete to þe soule · no sugre is swettere
Patience tedeth pouertye .Cr3.14.322 For pacyence is payn · for pouerte hym-selue
Patience tedeth pouertye .Cr3.14.322 And sobrete swete drynke · and good leche in sykenesse
Patience tedeth pouertye .Cr3.14.322 Þus lered me a lettred man · for owre lordes loue
Patience tedeth pouertye .Cr3.14.322 Seynt austyn a blissed lyf · with-outen bysynesse
Patience tedeth pouertye .Cr3.14.322 For body and for soule · absque / solicitudine felicitas
Patience tedeth pouertye .Cr3.14.322 Now god þat al good gyueth · graunt his soule reste
Patience tedeth pouertye .Cr3.14.322 Þat þus fyrst wrote to wyssen men · what pouerte was to mene

nota beneL14.338 ¶M14.336 ¶ Allas quod haukyn þe actyf man þo · þat after my crystendome
nota beneL14.338 ¶M14.336 ...?...M14.337 I ne hadde ben ded and doluen · for doweles sake
nota beneL14.338 ¶M14.336 ...?...M14.337 # quia defficele est sine peccato viuereM14.338 So harde it is quod haukyn · to lyue and to do synne
nota beneL14.338 ¶M14.336 ...?...M14.337 # quia defficele est sine peccato viuereM14.338 Synne suweth vs euere quod he · and sori gan wexe
nota beneL14.338 ¶M14.336 ...?...M14.337 # quia defficele est sine peccato viuereM14.338 And wepte water with his eyghen · and weyled þe tyme
nota beneL14.338 ¶M14.336 ...?...M14.337 # quia defficele est sine peccato viuereM14.338 Þat euere he dede dede · þat dere god displesed
nota beneL14.338 ¶M14.336 ...?...M14.337 # quia defficele est sine peccato viuereM14.338 Swowed and sobbed · and syked ful ofte
nota beneL14.338 ¶M14.336 ...?...M14.337 # quia defficele est sine peccato viuereM14.338 Þat euere he hadde londe or lordship · lasse other more
nota beneL14.338 ¶M14.336 ...?...M14.337 # quia defficele est sine peccato viuereM14.338 Or maystrye ouer any man · mo þan of hym-self
nota beneL14.338 ¶M14.336 ...?...M14.337 # quia defficele est sine peccato viuereM14.338 I were nouȝt worthy wote god quod haukyn · to were any clothes
nota beneL14.338 ¶M14.336 ...?...M14.337 # quia defficele est sine peccato viuereM14.338 Ne noyther sherte ne shone · saue for shame one
nota beneL14.338 ¶M14.336 ...?...M14.337 # quia defficele est sine peccato viuereM14.338 To keure my caroigne quod he · and cryde mercye faste
nota beneL14.338 ¶M14.336 ...?...M14.337 # quia defficele est sine peccato viuereM14.338 And wepte and weyled · and þere-with I awaked

Passus Quindecimus finit dowel & incipit dobet


[a pointing hand]CHECK FOR OTHER NOTES BY EDITOR AT TOP OF EACH PASSUS It declareth what the soule is, and how of diuers offices it hath diuers names, that we shoulde not searche Gods secretes, the preachers dutye, what shal become of euyll gotten goods, the true pylgrimage, what compenye charitye haunteth, that we should take no giftes of wicked men, that it is sacrilege to spend the tithes otherwyse than vppon the poore, that no course is certaine, whan and howe Makometes law began, that the Apostles turned all the worlde to the faithe, that children differ not from wilde beastes, tyl they be instructed in Christ, that couetise of the cleargy wyl destroy the church, that possession poysoned the churche, what the Byshops duty is, and that Christ was declared by his miracles to be Messias. Anima One with-outen tonge and teeth · tolde me whyder I shulde
[a pointing hand]CHECK FOR OTHER NOTES BY EDITOR AT TOP OF EACH PASSUS It declareth what the soule is, and how of diuers offices it hath diuers names, that we shoulde not searche Gods secretes, the preachers dutye, what shal become of euyll gotten goods, the true pylgrimage, what compenye charitye haunteth, that we should take no giftes of wicked men, that it is sacrilege to spend the tithes otherwyse than vppon the poore, that no course is certaine, whan and howe Makometes law began, that the Apostles turned all the worlde to the faithe, that children differ not from wilde beastes, tyl they be instructed in Christ, that couetise of the cleargy wyl destroy the church, that possession poysoned the churche, what the Byshops duty is, and that Christ was declared by his miracles to be Messias. Anima - And wher-of I cam and of what kynde · I conIured hym atte laste
[a pointing hand]CHECK FOR OTHER NOTES BY EDITOR AT TOP OF EACH PASSUS It declareth what the soule is, and how of diuers offices it hath diuers names, that we shoulde not searche Gods secretes, the preachers dutye, what shal become of euyll gotten goods, the true pylgrimage, what compenye charitye haunteth, that we should take no giftes of wicked men, that it is sacrilege to spend the tithes otherwyse than vppon the poore, that no course is certaine, whan and howe Makometes law began, that the Apostles turned all the worlde to the faithe, that children differ not from wilde beastes, tyl they be instructed in Christ, that couetise of the cleargy wyl destroy the church, that possession poysoned the churche, what the Byshops duty is, and that Christ was declared by his miracles to be Messias. Anima - If he were crystes creature · for crystes loue me to tellen

¶ I am crystes creature quod he · and crystene in many a place
In crystes courte · I-knowe wel · and of his kynne a partye
Is noyther peter þe porter · ne poule with his fauchoune
+ Þa wil defende me þe dore · dynge ich neure so late
+ At mydnyȝt at mydday · my voice so is yknowe
+ Þat eche a creature of his courte · welcometh me fayre

What are ye caldLater hand, not a gloss but a repetition (though MS spells "called") ¶ What ar ȝe called quod I in þat courte · amonges crystes peple

- C15.41 BishopsL15.42 ¶ Ȝe ben as a bisshop quod I · al bourdynge þat tyme
- C15.41 BishopsL15.42 Bishops haue many namesCr3.15.43 For bisshopes yblessed · þei bereth many names
- C15.41 BishopsL15.42 Bishops haue many namesCr3.15.43 [arabic 5 with line through it]G16.43, followed by ten medieval forms of this number as pen trials. See Benson and Blanchfield p.43. Presul and pontifex · and metropolitanus

Jon RycW15.44, 15th century hand, the same as on folios 1r (KDP.19) and 147v (flyleaf?) And other names an hepe episcopus & pastor

¶ Þat is soth seyde he · now I se þi wille
Þow woldest knowe and kunne · þe cause of alle her names
And of myne if þow myȝtest · me þinketh by þi speche

¶ Ȝe syre I seyde by so no man were greued
Nota · C15.49 Alle þe sciences vnder sonne · and alle þe sotyle craftes
Nota · C15.49 I wolde I knewe and couth · kyndely in myne herte

¶ Þanne artow inparfit quod he · and one of prydes knyȝtes
For such a luste and lykynge · lucifer fel fram heuene
Esai.xiiiiCr3.15.54 Ponam pedem meum in aquilone & similis ero altissimo

¶ It were aȝeynes kynde quod he · and alkynnes resoun
Þat any creature shulde kunne al · excepte cryste one
Aȝein such salomon speketh · and dispiseth her wittes

¶ Or to a wal þat were whitlymed · and were foule wyth-inne
Riȝt so many prestes · prechoures and prelates
faier wordes.C15.116 Ȝe aren enblaunched with bele paroles · and with clothes also
faier wordes.C15.116 Ac ȝowre werkes and ȝowre wordes þere-vnder · aren ful vnlouelich

ChrysostomasCr3.15.122 ¶ Iohannes crysostomus · of clerkes speketh and prestes
ChrysostomasCr3.15.122 Nota crisostomusL15.126 NBM15.124, same ornate abbreviation is found on fol. 73v. notaW15.124, 15th century hand, same as on 56r (KD10.266α and 10.270, there marked as hand5x) Sicut de templo omne bonum progreditur · sic de templo · omne malum procedit
ChrysostomasCr3.15.122 Nota crisostomusL15.126 NBM15.124, same ornate abbreviation is found on fol. 73v. notaW15.124, 15th century hand, same as on 56r (KD10.266α and 10.270, there marked as hand5x) Si sacerdocium integrum fuerit ; tota floret ecclesia · si autem coruptum fuerit · omnium fides marcida est / Si sacerdocium fuerit in peccatis · totus populus co[n]uertitur ad peccandum

Prestis .O15.123 ¶ If lewed men wist · what þis latyn meneth
Prestis .O15.123 And who was myn auctor · moche wonder me þinketh
Prestis .O15.123 # prestis BaselardisM15.127 But if many a prest bere · for here baselardes and here broches
Prestis .O15.123 # prestis BaselardisM15.127 A peyre bedes in her hande · and a boke vnder her arme
Prestis .O15.123 # prestis BaselardisM15.127 Sire Iohan & sire Geffray · hath a gerdel of syluer

¶ Curatoures of holykirke · as clerkes þat ben auerouse
contra Curatos AuarosM15.142 Liȝtlich þat þey leuen · loselles it habbeth
contra Curatos AuarosM15.142 Or dyeth intestate · and þanne þe bisshop entreth
contra Curatos AuarosM15.142 And maketh murthe þere-with · and his men bothe
contra Curatos AuarosM15.142 nyȝt The scribe appears to have offered marginal nyȝt to hypercorrect the alliteration. And seggen he was a nygarde · þat no good myȝte asspare
contra Curatos AuarosM15.142 nyȝt The scribe appears to have offered marginal nyȝt to hypercorrect the alliteration. To frende ne to fremmed · þe fende haue his soule
contra Curatos AuarosM15.142 nyȝt The scribe appears to have offered marginal nyȝt to hypercorrect the alliteration. For a wrecched hous he helde · al his lyf-tyme
contra Curatos AuarosM15.142 nyȝt The scribe appears to have offered marginal nyȝt to hypercorrect the alliteration. And þat he spared and bispered · spene we in murthe

¶ By lered by lewed · þat loth is to spende
Þus gone her godes · be þe goste faren
Ac for good men god wote · gret dole men maken
And bymeneth good mete-ȝyueres · and in mynde haueth

¶ What is charite quod I þo · a childissh þinge he seide

¶ Ac charite þat poule preyseth best · and most plesaunte to owre saueoure
Roma xiii.Cr2.15.161 Rom.xiiiCr3.15.162 As non inflatu[r] non ambiciosa non querit que sua sunt
Roma xiii.Cr2.15.161 Rom.xiiiCr3.15.162 I seigh neuere such a man · so me god helpe
Roma xiii.Cr2.15.161 Rom.xiiiCr3.15.162 That he ne wolde aske after his · and otherwhile coueyte
Roma xiii.Cr2.15.161 Rom.xiiiCr3.15.162 Þinge þat neded hym nouȝt · and nyme it if he myȝte

¶ Clerkis kenne me þat cryst · is in alle places
Ac I seygh hym neuere sothly · but as my-self in a miroure
i.Cor.xiiiCr3.15.168 It[a] in enigmate tunc facie ad faciem
i.Cor.xiiiCr3.15.168 i.Cor.x.ii.Cr2.15.168 And so I trowe trewly · by þat men telleth of charite
i.Cor.xiiiCr3.15.168 i.Cor.x.ii.Cr2.15.168 It is nouȝt championes fyȝte · ne chaffare as I trowe

ChariteO15.170 ¶ Charite quod he ne chaffareth nouȝte · ne chalengeth ne craueth
ChariteO15.170 quomodo laudatur caritasM15.173 As proude of a peny · as of a pounde of golde
ChariteO15.170 quomodo laudatur caritasM15.173 And is as gladde of a goune ; of a graye russet
ChariteO15.170 quomodo laudatur caritasM15.173 As of a tunicle of tarse · or of trye scarlet
ChariteO15.170 quomodo laudatur caritasM15.173 +L15.180 He is gladde with alle gladde · and good ty[l] alle wykked
ChariteO15.170 quomodo laudatur caritasM15.173 +L15.180 And leneth and loueth alle · þat owre lorde made
ChariteO15.170 quomodo laudatur caritasM15.173 +L15.180 Curseth he no creature · ne he can bere no wratthe
ChariteO15.170 quomodo laudatur caritasM15.173 +L15.180 Ne no lykynge hath to lye · ne laughe men to scorne
ChariteO15.170 quomodo laudatur caritasM15.173 +L15.180 Al þat men seith he let it soth · and in solace taketh
ChariteO15.170 quomodo laudatur caritasM15.173 +L15.180 And alle manere meschiefs · in myldenesse he suffreth
ChariteO15.170 quomodo laudatur caritasM15.173 +L15.180 Coueiteth he none erthly good · but heuene-riche blisse

questio de CaritateM15.183 ¶ Hath he any rentes or ricchesse · or any riche frendes

¶ Of rentes ne of ricchesse · ne reccheth he neuere
For a frende þat fyndeth hym · failled hym neuere at nede
Fiat voluntas tua fynt hym euer-more
And if he soupeth ette but a soppe of spera in deo
Goynge on pilgrimageCr3.15.186 He can purtreye wel þe pater noster · and peynte it with aues
Goynge on pilgrimageCr3.15.186 And other-while is his wone · to wende in pilgrymage
Goynge on pilgrimageCr3.15.186 Þere pore men and prisones liggeth · her pardoun to haue
Goynge on pilgrimageCr3.15.186 Þough he bere hem no bred · he bereth hem swetter lyflode
Goynge on pilgrimageCr3.15.186 Loueth hem as owre lorde biddeth · and loketh how þei fare

¶ And whan he is wery of þat werke · þanne wil he some-tyme
- C15.189 Labory in a lauendrye · wel þe lengthe of a myle
- C15.189 And ȝerne in-to ȝouthe · and ȝepliche speke
- C15.189 Pryde with al þe appurtenaunce · and pakken hem togyderes
- C15.189 And bouken hem at his brest · and beten hem clene
- C15.189 And leggen on longe · with laboraui in gemitu meo
- C15.189 And with warme water at his eyghen · wasshen hem after
- C15.189 And þanne he syngeth whan he doth so · & some-tyme seith wepyng
- C15.189 Psal.iiCr2.15.198 Psal.liCr3.15.200 Cor contritum & humiliatum deus non despicies

¶ By cryst I wolde þat I knewe hym quod I · no creature leuere

Piers · C15.198 ¶ With-outen helpe of Piers plowman quod he · his persone seestow neuere

¶ Where clerkes knowen hym quod I · þat kepen holykirke

¶ Clerkes haue no knowyng quod he · but by werkes and bi wordes
Ac piers þe plowman · parceyueth more depper
Luke,x.Cr2.15.204 +L15.211 Þat is þe wille and wherfore · þat many wyȝte suffreth
Luke,x.Cr2.15.204 +L15.211 Luke,ii[?]Cr3.15.207 Et vidit deus cogitaciones eorum
Luke,x.Cr2.15.204 +L15.211 Luke,ii[?]Cr3.15.207 · nota · C15.204 For þere ar ful proude-herted men · paciente of tonge
Luke,x.Cr2.15.204 +L15.211 Luke,ii[?]Cr3.15.207 · nota · C15.204 And boxome as of berynge · to burgeys and to lordes
Luke,x.Cr2.15.204 +L15.211 Luke,ii[?]Cr3.15.207 · nota · C15.204 And to pore peple · han peper in þe nose
Luke,x.Cr2.15.204 +L15.211 Luke,ii[?]Cr3.15.207 · nota · C15.204 And as a lyoun he loketh · þere men lakketh his werkes

¶ For þere ar beggeres and bidderes · bedmen as it were
Loketh as lambren · and semen lyf-holy
Ac it is more to haue her mete · with such an esy manere
Þan for penaunce and parfitnesse · þe pouerte þat such taketh

¶ Þere-fore by coloure ne by clergye · knowe shaltow hym neuere
Noyther þorw wordes ne werkes · but þorw wille one
And þat knoweth no clerke · ne creature in erthe

¶ Edmonde and Edwarde · eyther were kynges
And seyntes ysette · tyl charite hem folwed

¶ I haue seyne charite also · syngen and reden
Ryden and rennen · in ragged wedes

¶ Riche men he recomendeth · and of her robes taketh
Þat with-outen wyles · leden her lyues
Beatus est diues · qui &c

ConsistorieO15.248 ¶ In þe constorie bifor þe comissarie · he cometh nouȝt ful ofte

¶ Ac I ne lakke no lyf · but lorde amende vs alle
And gyue vs grace good god · charite to folwe
For who-so myȝte mete with hym · such maneres hym eyleth
Noyther he blameth ne banneth · bosteth ne prayseth
Lakketh ne loseth · ne loketh vp sterne
Craueth ne coueiteth · ne crieth after more
Psal iiii.Cr2.15.257 Psal.iiii,Cr3.15.259 In pace in idipsum dormiam &c ·
Psal iiii.Cr2.15.257 Psal.iiii,Cr3.15.259 Love in goddys passionC2.15.260 Þe moste lyflode þat he lyueth by · is loue in goddis passioun
Psal iiii.Cr2.15.257 Psal.iiii,Cr3.15.259 Love in goddys passionC2.15.260 Noyther he biddeth ne beggeth · ne borweth to ȝelde
Psal iiii.Cr2.15.257 Psal.iiii,Cr3.15.259 Love in goddys passionC2.15.260 Misdoth he no man · ne with his mouth greueth

nota beneL15.268 ¶ Amonges cristene men · þis myldnesse shulde laste
nota beneL15.268 # quanta erat humilitas CristiM15.265 In alle manere angres · haue þis at herte
nota beneL15.268 # quanta erat humilitas CristiM15.265 Þat þough þei suffred al þis · god suffred for vs more
nota beneL15.268 # quanta erat humilitas CristiM15.265 In ensample we shulde do so · and take no veniaunce
nota beneL15.268 # quanta erat humilitas CristiM15.265 Of owre foes þat doth vs falsenesse · þat is owre fadres wille
nota beneL15.268 # quanta erat humilitas CristiM15.265 · nota · C15.264 For wel may euery man wite if god hadde wolde hym-selue
nota beneL15.268 # quanta erat humilitas CristiM15.265 · nota · C15.264 Sholde neuere Iudas ne iuwe · haue Ihesu don on Rode
nota beneL15.268 # quanta erat humilitas CristiM15.265 · nota · C15.264 Ne han martired peter ne Poule · ne in prisoun holden
nota beneL15.268 # quanta erat humilitas CristiM15.265 · nota · C15.264 Ac he suffred in ensample · þat we shulde suffre also
nota beneL15.268 # quanta erat humilitas CristiM15.265 · nota · C15.264 And seide to suche þat suffre wolde · þat pacientes vincunt

¶ Verbi gratia quod he ; and verrey ensamples manye

antonyeL15.293 ¶ Antony adayes · aboute none-tyme
antonyeL15.293 Had a bridde þat brouȝte hym bred · þat he by lyued
antonyeL15.293 And þough þe gome hadde a geste · god fonde hem bothe

Paulus primus heremitaL15.296 ¶ Poule primus heremita · had parroked hym-selue
Paulus primus heremitaL15.296 Þat no man miȝte hym se · for mosse and for leues
Paulus primus heremitaL15.296 Foules hym fedde · fele wynteres with-alle
Paulus primus heremitaL15.296 quid coquerisM15.295 Til he founded freres · of austines ordre
Paulus primus heremitaL15.296 quid coquerisM15.295 Poule after his prechyng · panyers he made
Paulus primus heremitaL15.296 quid coquerisM15.295 And wan with his hondes · þat his wombe neded
Paulus primus heremitaL15.296 quid coquerisM15.295 PeterL15.302 andrewL15.302 Peter fisched for his fode · and his felawe andrewe
Paulus primus heremitaL15.296 quid coquerisM15.295 PeterL15.302 andrewL15.302 Some þei solde and some þei sothe · and so þei lyued bothe

¶ Who perfourneth þis prophecye · of þe peple þat now lybbeth
Psa,xxii.Cr2.15.328 Psal.iiiCr3.15.330 Optime dicit & verumM15.331 Dispersit dedit pauperibus &c

A vertical line in the same ink runs from G16.333 to G16.347. If any peple perfourme þat texte · it ar þis pore freres

¶ Ac clerkes & knyȝtes · and comuneres þat ben riche
SimilitudoC2.15.336 Fele of ȝow fareth · as if I a forest hadde
SimilitudoC2.15.336 - C15.333 Þat were ful of faire trees · and I fonded and caste
SimilitudoC2.15.336 - C15.333 How I myȝte mo þer-inne · amonges hem sette
SimilitudoC2.15.336 - C15.333 Riȝt so ȝe riche · ȝe robeth þat ben riche
SimilitudoC2.15.336 - C15.333 And helpeth hem þat helpeth ȝow · and ȝiueth þere no nede is
SimilitudoC2.15.336 - C15.333 As who-so filled a toune · of a fressh ryuer
SimilitudoC2.15.336 - C15.333 Caste water into temes.Cr3.15.342 And went forth with þat water · to woke with themese
SimilitudoC2.15.336 - C15.333 Caste water into temes.Cr3.15.342 Quid est dare impijsC2.15.343 Quid est dare impijsO15.343 Riȝt so ȝe riche · ȝe robeth and fedeth

NotaM15.399 ¶ And so may sarasenes be saued · scribes and iewes
NotaM15.399 Allas þanne but owre loresmen · lyuen as þei leren vs
NotaM15.399 And for her lyuynge þat lewed men be · þe lother god agulten
NotaM15.399 For sarasenes han somwhat · semynge to owre bileue
NotaM15.399 For þei loue and bileue · in o parsone almiȝty
NotaM15.399 And we lered and lewede · in on god bileueth

¶ And sitth owre saueoure suffred · þe sarasenes so bigiled
Þorw a crystene clerke · acursed in his soule

¶ Ancres and hermytes · and monkes and freres
Ancres hermites &c ·L15.430 Peren to apostles · þorw her parfit lyuynge
Ancres hermites &c ·L15.430 Wolde neuere þe faithful fader · þat his ministres sholde
Ancres hermites &c ·L15.430 # ¶ quod de rebus male adquisitis non debet dari elemosinaM15.428 Of tyrauntz þat teneth trewe men · taken any almesse
Ancres hermites &c ·L15.430 # ¶ quod de rebus male adquisitis non debet dari elemosinaM15.428 But done as Antony did · dominik and Fraunceys
Ancres hermites &c ·L15.430 # ¶ quod de rebus male adquisitis non debet dari elemosinaM15.428 Benet & Bernarde · þe which hem firste tauȝte
Ancres hermites &c ·L15.430 # ¶ quod de rebus male adquisitis non debet dari elemosinaM15.428 To lyue bi litel & in lowe houses · by lele mennes almesse
Ancres hermites &c ·L15.430 # ¶ quod de rebus male adquisitis non debet dari elemosinaM15.428 Grace sholde growe & be grene · þorw her good lyuynge
Ancres hermites &c ·L15.430 # ¶ quod de rebus male adquisitis non debet dari elemosinaM15.428 And folkes sholde fynde · þat ben in dyuerse sykenesse
Ancres hermites &c ·L15.430 # ¶ quod de rebus male adquisitis non debet dari elemosinaM15.428 Þe better for her byddynges · in body and in soule

- C15.439 ¶ Elleuene holy men · al þe worlde torned
- C15.439 The Apostles turned al the worlde to the fayth .Cr3.15.443 In-to lele byleue · þe liȝtloker me thynketh
- C15.439 The Apostles turned al the worlde to the fayth .Cr3.15.443 Shulde al maner men · we han so manye Maistres
- C15.439 The Apostles turned al the worlde to the fayth .Cr3.15.443 Prestes and prechoures · and a pope aboue
- C15.439 The Apostles turned al the worlde to the fayth .Cr3.15.443 Þat goddes salt shulde be · to saue mannes soule

· Nota · C15.444 ¶ Al was hethenesse some-tyme ; Ingelond and wales
· Nota · C15.444 Til Gregory gerte clerkes · to go here and preche
· Nota · C15.444 Austyn at Caunterbury · crystened þe kynge
· Nota · C15.444 And þorw myracles as men may rede · al þat marche he torned
· Nota · C15.444 To cryst and to crystendome · and crosse to honoure
· Nota · C15.444 And fulled folke faste · and þe faith tauȝte
· Nota · C15.444 More þorw miracles · þan þorw moche prechynge
· Nota · C15.444 As wel þorw his werkes · as with his holy wordes
· Nota · C15.444 And seyde hem what fullynge · and faith was to mene

~ C15.453 Nota beneM15.463 ¶ Cloth þat cometh fro þe weuyng · is nouȝt comly to were
~ C15.453 Nota beneM15.463 Tyl it is fulled vnder fote · or in fullyng stokkes
~ C15.453 Nota beneM15.463 FullyngM15.465 Wasshen wel with water · and with taseles cracched
~ C15.453 Nota beneM15.463 FullyngM15.465 Ytouked and ytented ; & vnder tailloures hande
~ C15.453 Nota beneM15.463 FullyngM15.465 And so it fareth by a barne · þat borne is of wombe
~ C15.453 Nota beneM15.463 FullyngM15.465 Tyll the chyld be instructed in Christ as a wilde beasteCr3.15.461 Til it be crystened in crystes name · and confermed of þe bisshop
~ C15.453 Nota beneM15.463 FullyngM15.465 Tyll the chyld be instructed in Christ as a wilde beasteCr3.15.461 It is hethene as to heueneward · and helpelees to þe soule

¶ Hethene is to mene after heth · and vntiled erthe
As in wilde wildernesse · wexeth wilde bestes
crepersO15.467. Substitution is indicated by a caret/punctus accompanying marginal crepers, but the reason for it is unclear since no change is made. Of all B manuscripts, only R has the correct reading, keperes. Rude and vnresonable · rennenge with-out creperes

deficitM15.473, Kane and Donaldson argue that the sidenote indicates that "a corrector of M knew of a manuscript which possessed XV 472-85, missing from the larger group" (p. 51n7). This seems unlikely, since the note is placed ten lines too early, and furthermore Kane and Donaldson themselves admit that "there is no evidence that M was corrected to (RF)." The note may simply refer to the fact that M alone among B manuscripts lacks "how" before "a man". ¶ Ȝe nymmen wel how matheu seith · how a man made a feste
deficitM15.473, Kane and Donaldson argue that the sidenote indicates that "a corrector of M knew of a manuscript which possessed XV 472-85, missing from the larger group" (p. 51n7). This seems unlikely, since the note is placed ten lines too early, and furthermore Kane and Donaldson themselves admit that "there is no evidence that M was corrected to (RF)." The note may simply refer to the fact that M alone among B manuscripts lacks "how" before "a man". He fedde hem with no venysoun · ne fesauntes ybake
deficitM15.473, Kane and Donaldson argue that the sidenote indicates that "a corrector of M knew of a manuscript which possessed XV 472-85, missing from the larger group" (p. 51n7). This seems unlikely, since the note is placed ten lines too early, and furthermore Kane and Donaldson themselves admit that "there is no evidence that M was corrected to (RF)." The note may simply refer to the fact that M alone among B manuscripts lacks "how" before "a man". But with foules þat fram hym nolde · but folwed his whistellynge
deficitM15.473, Kane and Donaldson argue that the sidenote indicates that "a corrector of M knew of a manuscript which possessed XV 472-85, missing from the larger group" (p. 51n7). This seems unlikely, since the note is placed ten lines too early, and furthermore Kane and Donaldson themselves admit that "there is no evidence that M was corrected to (RF)." The note may simply refer to the fact that M alone among B manuscripts lacks "how" before "a man". Math.xxCr2.15.468 Math.xxCr3.15.469 Ecce altilia mea & omnia parata sunt &c
deficitM15.473, Kane and Donaldson argue that the sidenote indicates that "a corrector of M knew of a manuscript which possessed XV 472-85, missing from the larger group" (p. 51n7). This seems unlikely, since the note is placed ten lines too early, and furthermore Kane and Donaldson themselves admit that "there is no evidence that M was corrected to (RF)." The note may simply refer to the fact that M alone among B manuscripts lacks "how" before "a man". Math.xxCr2.15.468 Math.xxCr3.15.469 And wyth calues flesshe he fedde · þe folke þat he loued
deficitM15.473, Kane and Donaldson argue that the sidenote indicates that "a corrector of M knew of a manuscript which possessed XV 472-85, missing from the larger group" (p. 51n7). This seems unlikely, since the note is placed ten lines too early, and furthermore Kane and Donaldson themselves admit that "there is no evidence that M was corrected to (RF)." The note may simply refer to the fact that M alone among B manuscripts lacks "how" before "a man". Math.xxCr2.15.468 Math.xxCr3.15.469 Þe calfe bytokeneth clennesse · in hem þat kepeth lawes

¶ For as þe cow þorw kynde mylke · þe calf norissheth til an oxe
So loue [&] lewte · lele men susteyneth
And maydenes and mylde men mercy desiren
Riȝt as þe cow calf · coueyteth swete mylke
So don riȝtful men · mercy & treutheHereafter follow 15.472-485 in KD, from alpha, but they are no annotated.

¶ Ac who beth þat excuseth hem · þat aren persounes and prestes
Þat heuedes of holycherche ben · þat han her wille here
With-oute trauaille þe tithe del · þat trewe men biswynkyn
nota · C15.477 Þei wil be wroth for I write þus · ac to witnesse I take
nota · C15.477 Bothe Mathew and Marke · and Memento domine dauid
nota · C15.477 What Pope or prelate now · perfourneth þat cryst hiȝte
nota · C15.477 Mar.xvi.Cr2.15.483 Mat.xviCr3.15.483 Ite in vniuersum mundum & predicate & c ·

¶ Allas þat men so longe · on Makometh shulde byleue
So many prelates to preche · as þe Pope maketh
Of Nazareth of Nynyue · of Neptalim and damaske
Þat þei ne went as cryst wisseth · sithen þei wil a name
¶ To be pastours and preche · þe passioun of Ihesus
And as hym-self seyde · so to lyue and deye

+L15.547 ¶ Ȝif presthod were parfit · þe peple solde amende
+L15.547 Þat contrarien crystes lawe · and crystendome dispise
+L15.547 For al paynym prayeth · and parfitly bileueth
+L15.547 In þe holy grete god · and his grace þei asken
+L15.547 And make her mone to makometh · her message to shewe
+L15.547 Þus in a faith lyueth þat folke · and in a false mene
+L15.547 And þat is routhe · for riȝtful men · þat in þe Rewme wonyen
+L15.547 And a peril to þe pope · and prelatis þat he maketh
+L15.547 Þat bere bisshopes names · of Bedleem & babiloigneHereafter follow 15.511-528 in KD, from alpha, but they are not annotated.
+L15.547 Þat hippe aboute in Engelonde · to halwe mennes auteres
+L15.547 And crepe amonges curatoures · confessen ageyne þe lawe

¶ Euery bisshop þat bereth crosse · by þat he is holden
Thorw his prouynce to passe · and to his peple to shewe hym
Tellen hem and techen hem · on þe Trinite to bileue
[& feeden hem with goostly foode / & nedy folk to f[yn]den .KD15.573-576 are given here from F, as they are missed in L but annotated in F.

¶ Ac we crystene creatures · þat on þe crosse byleuen
| C15.555 Aren ferme as in þe faith · goddes forbode elles
| C15.555 And han clerkes to kepen vs þer-Inne · and hem þat shal come after vs

· nota · C15.557 ¶M15.568 ¶ And iewes lyuen in lele lawe · owre lorde wrote it hym-selue
· nota · C15.557 ¶M15.568 In stone for it stydfast was · and stonde sholde eure

¶ And ȝit knewe þei cryst · þat crystendome tauȝte
For a parfit prophete · þat moche peple saued
Of selcouth sores · þei seyne it ofte
Bothe of myracles & meruailles · and how he men fested
+L15.580 With two fisshes an fyve loues · fyue thousande peple
+L15.580 And bi þat maungerye men miȝte wel se · þat Messye he semed
+L15.580 And whan he luft vp lazar · þat layde was in graue

¶ Danyel of her vndoynge · deuyned and seyde
Cum sanctus sanctorum veniat · cessabit vnxio vestra
And ȝet wenen þo wrecches · þat he were pseudo-propheta
And þat his lore be lesynges · and lakken it alle
And hopen þat he be to come · þat shal hem releue
Moyses eft or Messye · here maisteres ȝet deuyneth

Passus Sextus Decimus & primus de dobet


Now faire falle ȝow quod I þo · for ȝowre faire shewynge
For haukynnes loue þe actyf man euere I shal ȝow louye
Ac ȝet I am in a were · what charite is to mene

# declaracionem caritatis ¶ It is a ful trye tree quod he · trewly to telle ·
# declaracionem caritatis A discription of charitie. XF12.7, drypoint Mercy is þe more þer-of · þe myddel stokke is reuthe

nota bene ¶ It groweth in gardyne quod he · þat god made hym-seluen
nota bene Amyddes mannes body · þe more is of þat stokke
nota bene Herte hatte þe erber · þat it in groweth
nota bene And liberum arbitrium · hath þe londe to ferme
nota bene Vnder Piers þe plowman · to pyken it · and to weden it
nota bene Piers þe plowman quod I þo · and al for pure ioye
nota bene Þat I herde nempne his name · anone I swouned after
nota bene And laye longe in a loue-dreme · and atte laste me þouȝte
nota bene Þat Pieres þe plowman · al þe place me shewed
nota bene And bad me toten on þe tree · on toppe and on rote

¶ For wyndes wiltow wyte quod he · to witen it fram fallyng

¶ Þanne sette I to þe secounde pile · sapiencia dei patris
Þat is þe passioun and þe power · of owre prynce Ihesu
Þorw preyeres and þorw penaunces · and goddes passioun in mynde
I saue it til I se it rypen · & somdel yfruited
And þanne fondeth þe fende · my fruit to destruye
With alle þe wyles þat he can · and waggeth þe rote
And casteth vp to þe croppe · vnkynde neighbores
Bakbiteres breke-cheste · brawleres and chideres
And leith a laddre þere-to · of lesynges aren þe ronges
And feccheth away my floures sumtyme · afor bothe myn eyhen
Ac liberum arbitrium · letteth hym some-tyme
Þat is lieutenant to loken it wel · by leue of my-selue
Math,xCr2.16.50 Mat.xii.Cr3.16.49 Videatis qui peccat in spiritum sanctum numquam remittetur &c
Math,xCr2.16.50 Mat.xii.Cr3.16.49 Hoc est idem qui peccat per liberum arbitrium non repugnat ·
Math,xCr2.16.50 Mat.xii.Cr3.16.49 Ac whan þe fende and þe flesshe · forth with þe worlde

Math,xCr2.16.50 Mat.xii.Cr3.16.49 Pierces defenceCr3.16.51 - C16.53 And helpe of þe holy goste · and þus haue I þe maystrie

¶ Now faire falle ȝow Pieres quod I · so faire ȝe discryuen
Þe powere of þis postes · and her propre myȝte
- C15.57 Ac I haue þouȝtes a threve · of þis þre piles
- C15.57 In what wode þei woxen · and where þat þei growed
- C15.57 For alle ar þei aliche longe · none lasse þan other
- C15.57 And to my mynde as me þinketh · on o More þei growed
- C15.57 And of o gretnesse · and grene of greyne þei semen

¶ Þat is soth seide Pieres so it may bifalle
I shal telle þe as tite · what þis tree hatte
Þe grounde þere it groweth · goodnesse it hiȝte
The tre & the frutes thereof.Cr3.16.65 And I haue tolde þe what hiȝte þe tree · þe trinite it meneth
The tre & the frutes thereof.Cr3.16.65 And egrelich he loked on me · & þer-fore I spared
The tre & the frutes thereof.Cr3.16.65 To asken hym any more ther-of · and badde hym ful fayre
The tre & the frutes thereof.Cr3.16.65 To discreue þe fruit ; þat so faire hangeth

¶ Here now bineth quod he þo · if I nede hadde
Matrymonye I may nyme · a moiste fruit with-alle
Þanne contenence is nerre þe croppe · as calwey bastarde
Þanne bereth þe croppe kynde fruite · and clenneste of alle
Maydenhode angeles peres · and rathest wole be ripe
And swete with-oute swellyng · soure worth it neuere

xjF12.77, lighter brown ink ¶ I prayed pieres to pulle adown · an apple and he wolde
xjF12.77, lighter brown ink And suffre me to assaye · what sauoure it hadde

¶ And pieres caste to þe croppe · and þanne comsed it to crye
And wagged wydwehode · and it wepte after
And whan it meued Matrimoigne · it made a foule noyse
Þat I had reuth whan Piers rogged · it gradde so reufulliche
For euere as þei dropped adown · þe deuel was redy
And gadred hem alle togideres · bothe grete and smale
Adam & abraham · and ysay þe prophete
Nota notabileM16.85 Sampson and samuel · and seynt Iohan þe baptiste
Nota notabileM16.85 Bar hem forth boldely · no-body hym letted
Nota notabileM16.85 And made of holy men his horde · in lymbo inferni
Nota notabileM16.85 There is derkenesse and drede · and þe deuel Maister

¶ And Pieres for pure tene · þat o pile he lauȝte
And hitte after hym · happe how it myȝte
Filius bi þe fader wille · and frenesse of spiritus sancti
To go robbe þat raggeman · and reue þe fruit fro hym

¶ And þanne spakke spiritus sanctus · in Gabrieles mouthe
To a mayde þat hiȝte Marye · a meke þinge with-alle
- C16.58 Þat one Ihesus a iustice sone · moste iouke in her chambre
- C16.58 Tyl plenitudo temporis · fully comen were
- C16.58 Þat Pieres fruit floured · and fel to be ripe
- C16.58 And þanne shulde Ihesus iuste þere-fore · bi iuggement of armes
- C16.58 Whether shulde fonde þe fruit · þe fende or hym-selue

¶ Þe mayde myldeliche þo · þe messager graunted
And seyde hendelich to hym · lo me his hande-mayden
